PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; believing that its implementation would result in:-
1. Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

2. ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The previous Government commissioned the Commonwealth Institute of Health to undertake a study of birth anomalies and Vietnam service. The study was completed in January 1983 and the report on it was released by Senator Messner, the former Minister, my predecessor, on 20 February. Because of the importance of the report I believe it should be tabled. In accordance with the procedures for release of documents out of parliamentary sessions, copies were distributed to all senators and members of the previous Parliament. Copies will be distributed to newly elected senators and members. I draw attention to the conclusions reached by the study team. The main conclusion was that there is no evidence that Army service in Vietnam has increased the risk of the birth of a child with an anomaly. The study also showed that neither the length of service in Vietnam not the time between return from Vietnam and conception of a child nor the calendar year of service in Vietnam had an effect on the risk of fathering a malformed child. I am sure that the report will be taken into account by the royal commission which is soon to be set up to inquire into the effects of chemical agents on Vietnam veterans.

—by leave-The report which was released in January by the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, I think caused a fair amount of concern, amongst Vietnam veterans in particular, that possibly the item would not be taken up. Of course, the current Government has anounced that it will pursue the item and many others by the means of a royal commission. The Australian Democrats certainly welcome that. However, I think that the aspect of the report that was of most concern to the Vietnam veterans was that while the study was certainly well conducted, no control study was made of possible spontaneous abortion by mothers who may have had foetuses which were deformed in some way. Since the medical evidence shows that abortions are much more likely to be the case under such conditions, it would seem that the study may be biased in that way. DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL ANIMAL HEALTH LABORATORY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The reason I rise to speak to this report is that it relates to an issue that has come up in other reports to the Senate on which I have spoken in the past. On this occasion the Australian Science and Technology Council has reported on the proposal for the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory to import live , exotic animal pathogens. It has been a matter of great controversy within the Australian community, or that part of it that has an interest in the subject of the import of live virus, that there is a proposal to import live foot and mouth virus into Australia for the purpose of certain scientific work.

I note in the letter presenting the report to the then Acting Prime Minister that the Chairman, Professor Badger, and the Deputy Chairman have taken the fairly unusual step of stressing certain recommendations in relation to the import of foot and mouth disease virus. I briefly draw to the attention of the Senate some comments made by ASTEC, a very eminent scientific body. I am sure that the Government will pay very close regard to what it says. It points out that, because of our geographical isolation and more recently Australian importation and quarantine controls, Australia has remained relatively free of serious animal diseases. It is the concern of those who have been opposed to the import of the live foot and mouth disease virus that we should remain free of that virus. It has been their concern that with such imports there would be a risk that we would have in this country exotic diseases which would be enormously damaging to it. I would like to quote very briefly from the report to underline the concern that is obviously shared by ASTEC on this matter. The report states:

No one is able to give a guarantee that there is absolutely no risk of an exotic pathogen escaping from ANAHL. Therefore, notwithstanding the excellent containment offered by ANAHL, the importation of an exotic pathogen to the Laboratory must be considered to represent an additional risk over and above that posed by its accidental or deliberate introduction by other means.

Furthermore, there is a clear need for an agreed procedure to ensure that full consultation takes place between CSIRO and Commonwealth and State authorities, producer organisations and other interested parties.

This will ensure adequate consultation with government authorities, but it is important that all organisations with a legitimate interest be consulted at an early stage. ASTEC has concluded that the ANAHL Consultative Committee should have the responsibility to give formal notice, when an application for importation is made by CSIRO, to interested parties, including the National Farmers' Federation and the Australian Veterinary Association, and to transmit their advice and comments to the Minister for Health as well as to the Executive of CSIRO.
The report gives quite separate consideration to the foot and mouth disease virus from the general consideration it gives to other viruses and points out:

ASTEC has given separate consideration to the importation of live Foot-and- Mouth Disease (FMD) virus. It is important to understand that FMD has a special significance for Australia, greater than that of any other animal disease. A single outbreak would result in an immediate prohibition on most, if not all, of Australia's main animal exports. Major markets for beef would be closed and the domestic price would collapse; exports of live sheep and sheepmeat would also be seriously affected, and shipment of wool might also be banned by some countries. Furthermore, a proven disease-free period of six to twelve months after the last case might elapse before export markets were re-opened. It is clear, therefore, that FMD poses a special threat to Australia; there are few other countries with a major export industry dependent on freedom from the disease.

I conclude by just saying, as I said at the beginning, that the importation of live foot and mouth disease virus has been a matter of great controversy. Beef producers in particular have opposed it. I think it is very welcome that ASTEC should sound a very strong note of caution. I believe that in this report it has laid down procedures which are very reasonable and which should go a long way, if they are followed, to allaying the fears of our animal producers as to what might happen if this virus is introduced. I strongly recommend that the Government implement the recommendations of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The report from the Australian Science and Technology Council has followed a previous report on the same subject by the Australian Academy of Science. Both of these reports have made recommendations which suggest that there is no justification for research involving live virus at the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory. This matter has been of enormous concern to primary industry groups around Australia ever since the previous Government announced that live virus would be imported by the Laboratory. It has been a matter of agenda discussion at every primary industry peak council that I know of over the past two or three years. I believe that after last year's conference on this matter which was, one could probably say, inconclusive it would now seem that the weight of scientific opinion has moved against the importation of such virus certainly at any time that we do not actually have an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Academy of Science draws attention to the fact that research no longer requires live virus to be able to engage in adequate protection measures. Artificial viruses are quite capable of being used. They have none of the lethal effects but all of the operating characteristics. I believe that we can await a fairly rapid announcement on the part of the Government that it has no intention of importing live virus for the Laboratory. If this is the case one needs to look again at that Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation facility and consider whether the initial discussions surrounding that facility and the initial decisions that were taken to establish it were made with the type of input that one would think was necessary. It could very well be argued that the establishment of that facility was a needless expense in terms of the other pressing requirements of research in CSIRO. The development of such a facility on the mainland to undertake those types of activities was, even at the time it was suggested, a very controversial proposition and it has simply become more so.

The alternative suggestion which was put forward at the time the decision was made was to establish such a facility on one of the Australian territories or off-shore islands. This decision seems to me to have been preferable even at that time. Hindsight shows that that decision should have been made, bearing in mind the problems that Australia faces in terms of its animal husbandry with any possibility of the outbreak of such lethal diseases in Australia affecting not only the cattle themselves but also our entire primary industry. I hope that we get from this Government much more decisive statements in this regard than we got from the dithering of the previous Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATIONS OF THE REGISTERED MEDICAL AND HOSPITAL BENEFITS ORGANISATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a paper which may not be a best seller in the community but which, nevertheless, is an important document. It is the report to the Parliament made each year on the operation of the health funds. It provides parliamentarians and the public with a bird's eye view of the size, vigour and health of the health insurance industry and sector. It identifies the problems, the benefits, the money paid and the way in which the health funds organise their finances and pay their money. What emerges from this report, which covers the year 1981-82, is that it was a year of fairly rapid change in the provision of medical benefits in Australia. It was a year during which the Fraser Government conferred significant extra benefits upon people and when a large amount of activity took place through the health funds-the medical and hospital insurance funds.

The report, at page 1, identifies the changes in medical and hospital benefits during the year of report. It is worth reminding ourselves of what the government of the day was able to do for the people of Australia during that year. As is set out in the report, Commonwealth medical benefits were identified at a flat rate of 30 per cent of the scheduled fee and they were restricted in that year to those people with at least basic medical cover with a registered organisation. But during that year the basic level of medical insurance was increased from 75 per cent to 85 per cent of the scheduled fee. So people did benefit from that change which took place in health insurance provisions during that year. The Government identified a maximum patient payment of $10 per service in cases where the scheduled fee was charged. Again, that was a move designed to help people and to limit the costs they faced from health insurance.

The Commonwealth, during the year 1981-82, assumed full responsibility for nursing home benefits. It did this from 1 September. Of course, this had implications for the registered funds and that year the Government contributed to the Hospital Benefits Reinsurance Trust Fund a smaller amount of, still, $ 100m to help cover the costs of those who were chronically ill and who were heavy drawers upon hospital and medical insurance in Australia. During that year the Commonwealth Government increased its bed-day subsidy for private hospital patients receiving prescribed surgical procedures to almost double the amount, from $16 to $28 per day. During that year a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar was introduced for cost of basic hospital and medical insurance with registered organisations.

The effect of all these changes was to confer upon people in Australia greater security, support and benefits. It is interesting in looking at the report and the aggregated figures to see the size of medical and hospital insurance as offered through these registered funds in Australia. On the medical benefits side I note that Australia-wide something just under $1,000m in medical benefits was paid to contributors. Mr President, in our State of New South Wales over $ 400m was paid out in the year under study. In the hospital sector something over $300m was paid in New South Wales and Australia-wide something more than $1,000m was paid. If one looks at what these funds cover one sees that they involve the collection of money from Australian citizens, the organisation and safe-keeping of the money and the paying of something like $2,000m on behalf of Australians.

What emerges from this report for the years 1981-82 is that the system of voluntary health insurance and the operation of that insurance by the funds have been something of which Australia can be proud. The funds have attracted no great criticism in this report. The activities of the funds are recorded fairly factually. It is obvious that it is a very large, well established, well organised, available and accessible system. If the new Government determines, in line with its election mandate, to change the system, it should do so knowing the size, extent and success of the system that it does change. I remind the Government that fixed assets of something like $120m, assets which belong to Australians, will have to be taken into account if and when a different system of health insurance is brought in. One thing which this report demonstrates is that Australians have been well served for a long time by the funds which are the subject of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

We should all welcome this report recommending that a Museum of Australia be set up. I remind the Senate that the Museum of Australia was established by the Museum of Australia Act which received royal assent in September 1980 and the Interim Council was set up by the then Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr R. J. Ellicott. The report is an excellent one and is, of course, on matters of great significance to Australians.

I notice that the first recommendation to the Government is that it endorse the concept of a Museum of Australia and that the Museum of Australia be opened in 1990. There are a number of matters of great interest in the recommendations. What is welcome is some emphasis on the role that Aboriginals can play in this Museum. When the Fraser Government moved to have this report prepared it laid down that there should be three main themes of the Museum: Firstly, the history of Aboriginal people; secondly, the history of non-Aboriginal people; and thirdly, the interrelationship between people and the Australian environment. They are all important themes but I think it is particularly welcome that such strong recognition is given in the recommendations in this report that special steps be taken to make sure that Aborigines be involved.

Too few Australians realise that the prehistory of Australia-that is, the history of Australia prior to European settlement-is a very rich one indeed. We should consider that that part of Australia's history is part of the history of the world because there are things to be learned about Aboriginal civilisation and culture in Australia which are of great significance throughout the world. Of course, the significance is not confined simply to Aborigines. There are uniquenesses, particularly in the fauna of this country, which have relevance throughout the world. I am sure that we will all look forward with great enthusiasm to the Government's acceding to the recommendations in this report and to the opening of what promises, from this report at least, to be an outstanding Museum in 1990.

—Can the Minister for Social Security explain what he means by the concept 'least restrictive alternative' in respect of special services to the handicapped?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that Senator Robertson was referring to a statement which was released yesterday in which I announced that the Government will be reviewing funds which will be available under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Program to apply the concept of the least restrictive alternative in assessing funding for special services which include such things as activity therapy, sheltered employment, special training and residential accommodation for the disabled. The principle basically recognises the individual's right to live in an environment which is as supportive as possible, and as supportive as is needed by the disabled without unreasonably restricting personal freedom. It implies for the handicapped person the least possible restriction on living an ordinary life in the community. It is a concept which is well accepted by all those who are concerned with the welfare of the disabled in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: It is particularly important, when considering applications for funding for residential accommodation for these people, to move away from the institutionalisation which has developed in the past. The Government has decided to review future applications, and indeed existing applications, on this basis. I have asked organisations which seek funds in future, and those which already have funding applications which are being examined by the Government, to review those applications and their policies in this light. In the past many of these organisations have not had many disabled people on their boards of management or on the main bodies of their associations. I hope that, as a result of the International Year of Disabled Persons and the increased interest in this area, as seen by the development of organisations such as Disabled Persons International, other organisations will take their cue in this regard and ensure that the disabled and their views are represented both within their organisations and within the umbrella organisations which oversee the policies of the various societies and groups in the community which care for the disabled . Briefly, we wish to ensure that groups of disabled people are assisted by the Government to live as normal lives as possible with regard to residence, occupation and their ability to take part in our society. TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I thank the Minister for his answer. In the past they have had too little say. In the future, we will ensure that they have more say.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is the Government giving consideration to the call from the honourable member for Fraser for the abolition of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation and its replacement by a different type of intelligence organisation?

—The abolition of ASIO is not Australian Labor Party policy and never has been. The accountability of ASIO has always been a matter of considerable concern to us. As I indicated yesterday, the question of how best to ensure that accountability is the subject of active review at the moment and, indeed, will be the subject of announcements shortly by the Government.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to the article in Business Review Weekly on the different treatment given to certain capital gains for social security and tax purposes? What will the Government do about differences in interpretation of this type?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did read the article in Business Review Weekly. It draws attention to a problem which has bedevilled Ministers for Social Security, Ministers for Finance and Treasurers before me. A problem for the Department of Social Security, for instance, in relation to property growth trusts to which the article largely referred and to other capital growth schemes, is that it is difficult in practice to establish that a person has an immediate legal entitlement to a sum of money and therefore it is difficult to assess income in these circumstances. One of the basic problems is in defining just what income is. It is a matter which I raised during the National Economic Summit Conference . For instance, the Social Services Act contains for pension and benefit purposes the following definition of income:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . any personal earnings, moneys, valuable consideration or profits earned, derived or received by that person for his own use or benefit by any means from any source whatsoever, within or outside Australia . . .

The Income Tax Assessment Act, despite its title, contains no definition of income. Consequently, under the Income Tax Assessment Act the term is understood in its general meaning according to the ordinary concepts and usages. It causes great difficulties in trying to define income when the Act which has the word ' income' in its title has no definition but the Act which does not has a fairly strict and rigid definition. Quite clearly, the taxation authorities in this country and the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Finance, the Department of Social Security and other departments involved in supervising means tests and income tests, must eventually get together so that we get a common definition of income to avoid the sorts of confusions which arise now and which were pointed to in the article.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General a question. It concerns permanent proposals for a commission to investigate organised crime and corruption in Australia. Did the Attorney, when he took on his ministerial post, state that there would be a six-months delay in implementing the proposals for a national crimes commission? Does he agree that while ad hoc royal commissions may be of some use, it is vital, if we are to investigate thoroughly and prosecute organised crime in all States, that there be a federal body with the jurisdiction to do so? Specifically, if a person is arrested and charged with an offence against Commonwealth law, say the importation of heroin, brought before a State court of summary jurisdiction, say in New South Wales, and wrongly discharged by a magistrate, is the existing legislation for a crimes commission adequate to allow it to intervene?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the Government remains committed to the concept of a federal crimes commission operating in close consultation and co- operation with the States. The precise form that that commission should take in terms of its composition, powers and functions is, as I indicated in a public statement jointly with the Special Minister of State a few weeks ago, under further consideration. It will be the subject of a Green Paper to be published shortly, I hope, and of an open seminar during the winter recess at which the kinds of issues which Senator Chipp has canvassed on this and previous occasions can be closely considered by the Government. The issues are simply too momentous in their significance and the risks to individuals and the credibility of the law enforcement process too great for any government to go off in any half-baked fashion in this area. It is important to get the machinery right and that is what the present Government proposes to do.

ANSWER.PARA: The more specific matter that Senator Chipp raised about the situation of a possible offender under Commonwealth law being discharged under State law is one that can arise and has arisen on occasions in the whole course of the administration of criminal law in this century. I am not sure that it raises questions of any special difficulty in this area but to the extent that it does we will look into them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology whether she saw the article in the Age of 8 April headed 'Antarctic beauty spoiled by man's wreckage' in which Peter Roberts described the old Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition station on Heard Island as a graveyard for old buildings, machinery, stores and equipment. He stated that the roofs of most buildings have collapsed inwards, that those buildings that are not roofless have sunk in their foundations and that their floors are filled with stinking water. The article also referred to a jumble of old food cans spilling out into the mud, piles of rusting drums, sheet iron and so forth. Can the Minister explain why nothing has been done to clean up the rubbish over the 25 years since the base was last used? Will this Government undertake to care for the Antarctic environment by cleaning up the mess at Heard Island? Finally, can she assure me that the Government is not taking the view expressed by Dr Phillip Law, opposing the clean-up, on the basis that, as he says:

QUESTION.PARA: The storms over the years will obliterate the evidence of our short period of occupation and, in any case, the seals and penguins will be the only ones to observe the untidiness . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —The brief supplied to me on this matter by my colleague the Minister for Science and Technology implies that the criticisms of the conditions on Heard Island stated in the honourable senator's question are right . I have some briefing notes to the effect that essentially no maintenance of the original buildings has been carried out since 1954-55. Succeeding parties have provided their own temporary accommodation. The buildings are now in an advanced state of disrepair due to the effects of weather and seals. Over the summer of 1982-83 two private expeditions visited the island and it is understood that members of those expeditions made some attempt to tidy up the debris. The Australian National Antarctic Research Expedition's ship Nella Dan visited the island for one day in March 1983. Detailed reports on the conditions of the station and its environs are being prepared. There is no undertaking in the brief supplied to me by my colleague in another place as to the Government's intentions in this matter. I will convey to the Minister the concern raised in this question by Senator Coates and get a response for him as to the Minister's intention.

—I ask the Attorney-General: Is it true, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday, that the Government has given consideration to prosecuting a senior Australian Labor Party figure who the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation has told the Government is a potential security risk? If so, what is the outcome of those considerations?

—I advise the honourable senator and the Senate that the Prime Minister proposes to make a statement on this matter at the earliest possible hour today. Until then I have nothing further to say on that question.

—Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware that it has been claimed by the Vice-Chancellor of Griffith University, Professor John Willett, that Queensland tertiary institutions are funded at a lower level than the national average? Will the Minister investigate this claim, which assumes that Australia-wide funding decisions have not previously allowed for significant population growth in Queensland?

—I am not aware of Professor Willett's claims in respect of unequal funding provisions for Queensland. It is certainly a matter of great concern to the Government that education standards in all States and territories be improved and maintained at a high level. We certainly would not acquiesce in a situation where one State or territory is discriminated against in any way and thus is unable to contribute to improved educational standards. I will seek information about the allegations raised in Professor Willett's reported comments and inform the honourable senator of the results.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. By what principles of natural justice or good government does he justify the Prime Minister's action of depriving his former friend and colleague , Mr David Combe, of his livelihood without a fair hearing?
—I do not propose to discuss the principles of natural justice involved. The Prime Minister will make a statement about this matter later today .

—Has the Minister for Social Security received representations regarding funding for the centre for intellectually handicapped persons in Alexandra, Victoria? If so, can he give an indication of the likely outcome of those representations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received many representations from organisations such as the organisation in Alexandra which runs the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre and which received from the Minister for Social Security before last approval for a grant for a training centre on its site. This organisation since then has had some difficulty because of the uncertainty of the Government's response. For instance, I have learned that many promises and many guarantees of funding were given by the last Minister and by the Minister before last. They will have to be financed by this Government, and they go back a very long way. It may be that many of the priorities of the previous Government in this area are not mine or are not necessarily the Government's. Where such organisations, which are doing good work for those in the community who need assistance, have received such assurances, unless there are very strange circumstances, I and this Government will honour those commitments, as any government should, so that the people who have worked so hard and the people for whom they are caring will not suffer. For this reason I have just approved a grant of about $90,000 under the Handicapped Persons Assistance Act for the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre in Alexandra. It will be able to proceed with its project.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, other projects have piled up over the years. We are reviewing many of them, particularly those which have been on the drawing board since before 1981, with a view to finalising them one way or another-by asking the organisations whether they are capable of getting on with the projects which have been approved, seeing whether they need assistance to get on with them or seeing whether the funds would not be better used in another area. However, the Dame Pattie Menzies Centre has had its grant approved. I hope now that the uncertainty which has bedevilled it in recent years will be gone to enable it to get on with the job it wishes to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and preface it by noting the apparant linkage in the answers given by the Leader of the Government and the Attorney-General to the separate questions which were asked of them relating to Mr David Combe and the report in the Sydney Morning Herald concerning a senior Australian Labor Party figure. I ask: Is that linkage one which should be made? Are the statements referred to by the two Ministers in their answers the same statements? Given that Mr Combe has been barred from access to Ministers for lobbying purposes, has any similar ban been placed on contact with Mr Wran, the National President of the ALP?
—I do not propose to comment on Senator Chaney's dragging red herrings into the issue. A statement will be made later today.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Last week the Minister for Health introduced a new pharmaceutical benefits form, a form that meets current needs for identifying patients and their various eligibilities while doing away with the chaos, confusion and distress that the previous forms caused. In the light of recent changes to the revised Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, suspending for six months the changes proposed under that Scheme, has any thought been given to incorporating the Repatriation Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme under the general Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, particularly as the new form now seems readily adaptable to repatriation requirements?

—Senator Crowley has asked me a question which relates to the rationalisation of the existing benefits available under the assistance from the Department of Health and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. A number of matters are currently under review by the two departments and the two Ministers concerned, Dr Blewett and me. We are anxious to facilitate such rationalisation but not at the expense, of course, of any of the existing beneficiaries. The informal discussions we have had at the ministerial level will be discussed by our departments. It is the Government's intention to introduce the Medicare proposals in the Budget session, or maybe even prior to that, with a view to their implementation early in 1984. Extensive changes are mooted in those new proposals. If it is possible for us to minimise the degree of bureaucracy or form filling by patients, whether under the National Health Scheme or the Department of Veterans' Affairs, we will certainly be seeking to simplify the whole process because that is in the interests of citizens generally, whether they are covered by my Department or the Department of Health.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. The Special Minister of State has in recent days declared the Government's intention of legislating for public funding of elections. Obviously one of the main concerns of the public will be the cost of such a scheme. Can the Minister inform the Senate, firstly, of the approximate cost to the public of elections under the present arrangements, particularly the current unlimited claims that can be made via the taxation system and, secondly, the prospective cost of the Government's contemplated scheme and whether it will cost more than the current scheme?
—Rather than try to produce figures out of the air, I undertake to refer the honourable senator's question to the Minister and to get an early reply for him.

—I refer the Minister for Social Security to the fact that the unemployment benefit for 16 and 17-year-olds fell by something like 50 per cent in real terms during the life of the Fraser Government. Whereas it represented 24.5 per cent of average weekly earnings in June 1975, it now represents only 11 per cent. I ask the Minister: When will the Government grant an increase in the unemployment benefit paid to 16 and 17-year-olds? Does the Government intend to restore the level of this benefit to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings or at least to a more humane and realistic level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Foreman has said, the unemployment benefit for those under the age of 18 years was $36 a week in 1975 and stayed at that level until the last Budget, when it was increased to $40 a week. It is my recollection that over that time the drop in value of that benefit was indeed 50 per cent, taking into account inflation. The great tragedy, of course, was that over that time youth unemployment rose rapidly so that people of this age group now have, in some regions of the country, an unemployment level of anything up to 40 per cent . The tragedy of that is that that unemployment resulted of course from the direct policies of the previous Government, first of all by its contracting of the economy and screwing down on the economy generally and, secondly, by its doing nothing about providing alternatives for young people of this age group. We have a tragedy of considerable proportions.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly I accept, as I think most honourable senators on both sides of Parliament should accept, that the unemployment benefit is inadequate. It is particularly inadequate for those who are living away from home, as so many are, to seek work or for other reasons. Whether the unemployment benefit for that group will be increased, and to what extent, is a matter for Budget discussions. It is not a matter on which I can commit the Government at the moment, but obviously we will view it with considerable sympathy. What level the unemployment benefit eventually will be increased to and how this will be done, will involve wider considerations. For instance, in this country 66 per cent of people aged 15 to 19 years are in the work force or receiving an unemployment benefit. Quite clearly they are there because basically they have the alternative of either working or taking the unemployment benefit, as inadequate as it is. In comparable countries-for instance, the social democracies of Western Europe and Canada-the participation rate in the work force is only 30 per cent or 34 per cent. I think we should look at why this is so.

It is for this reason that a working party under me, Senator Ryan, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, and Mr Willis, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, is looking at this whole area, and indeed at the some 16 various forms of income support payments we make to young people in this age group, to see whether we cannot, through a better scale of benefits, a better and more appropriate education system, better training schemes and even assistance to private industry to assist in training, reverse this situation in Australia where so many young people are in the work force when it may be appropriate that they not be there. In addition, of course, our employment projects will be aimed at the young unemployed and our general economic policy will be aimed at improving employment opportunities for the young unemployed.

The previous Government apparently viewed this situation with no concern. It showed no concern for the young unemployed for the seven years it was in government. This is demonstrated by the fact that the unemployment benefit did not increase, as Senator Foreman pointed out. In fact, it made no effort to do anything about the difficult economic situations in which these people and their families found themselves. But the matters that the honourable senator has raised and the matters that I have raised are matters for budgetary consideration. They are under active consideration. I can assure Senator Foreman that we have this group in particular in mind in making our decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Will the Government consider the appointment of a judicial inquiry to enable Mr Combe to clear his name?
—The Prime Minister will be making a statement about that matter later this afternoon. If I can convey to him in the meantime Senator MacGibbon's bizarre suggestion I am sure that he will look at it.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Can the Leader of the Government in the Senate assure the Senate that he will make a statement in the Senate similar to the Prime Minister's report? If so, at what time will that report be delivered?
—In answer to the second part of the question, I am unable to say . The answer to the first part of the question is yes, a statement will be made in the Senate.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to several instances of Western Australian visitors to Singapore who were found to be carrying prescribed medications having been harassed by Singaporean officials and, in one case, arrested, manacled and locked up overnight? What action has been taken to protect Australian tourists from such treatment in the future? Has any official complaint been made to the Singapore Government on behalf of these Australian citizens whose holidays have been ruined?

—Yes, the recent cases to which Senator Giles refers and the Press report of them in the West Australian of 26 April have been drawn to my attention. As yet no official complaint has been made to the Government of Singapore. The Department of Foreign Affairs has been told of the cases by the Australian High Commission in Singapore. A booklet entitled 'Hints for Australian Travellers' is provided to all Australians travelling overseas. That booklet is designed to assist Australian travellers; I am told that it does. It indicates that all persons are subject to the laws of the country which they enter and that extreme care should be taken in respect of drugs. No specific action has been taken to warn Australian travellers in this case. However, it is proposed that the next edition of that booklet of helpful hints will include a section about this problem, which does not appear previously to have arisen.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation seen the results of a Spectrum Research Pty Ltd poll which was held in February this year in which some 72 per cent of almost 2,000 people surveyed considered that South African Airways should be allowed to continue operations into and out of Australia and only 9 per cent expressed a negative view, and 78 per cent of people considered that Qantas Airways Ltd should be allowed to fly to South Africa whereas only 10 per cent indicated the opposite, once again a very strong positive response? Is the Government considering allowing Qantas to fly direct to South Africa instead of forcing Australians to fly to Zimbabwe, then to join a South African Airways aircraft which is scheduled specially to meet the Qantas plane and in which most of them then fly on to Johannesburg in South Africa? I am sure the Minister will agree that that is a quite ridiculous situation. If the Minister is not able to advise me, will he undertake to have the matter examined and report to the Senate as soon as possible?

—Senator Townley asked a question about the availability of transport by air to South Africa. The honourable senator referred to a survey which I have not seen and on which I have no advice. I am aware of the fact that the Government curtailed the number of flights from Australia to South Africa. I presume that two factors were involved, namely, the economic factor as well as what I understood to be the bipartisan attitude in the Parliament in respect of our relationship with that country, which practises the evil of apartheid. However, as the honourable senator seems to believe that there is a demand for an increased passenger service to South Africa and objects to the current arrangements continuing, I will undertake to have the matter discussed with Mr Beazley, the Minister whom I represent in this place. I do not know of any circumstances that would cause this Government to change the decision.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask: Does the Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board receive any funding from the Commonwealth Government? If so, what amount? Does the Commonwealth have free access to the financial records of the Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board? Further, can the Minister supply the names of the members of that Board and their occupations?

—Assuming that the Queensland Rural Reconstruction Board is the State body which administers the rural adjustment arrangements, the answer to the first part of Senator Jones's question is yes, the Commonwealth does provide funds to it. Indeed, the Commonwealth provides all of the funds less only the cost of administration. As to the second part of the question, I cannot say, at this stage, how much is provided, but I can find that out from the Treasurer. The third part of the question asked who were the members of the Board. I cannot say who they are at this stage, but I will consult with the Treasurer and find out.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. My purpose is to probe a little further into the rather peculiar ministerial relationships of the present Government. Is Mr Duffy, the Minister for Communications, ministerially responsible for the Australian Broadcasting Commission? Is Senator Button his ministerial assistant? If so, if he had complaints about the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission which were sufficiently serious for him to write formally about them-they seemed pretty trivial to everyone else-why did he not tell his ministerial superior about them instead of leaving him in embarrassing ignorance? With regard to Senator Button's quaint likening of his petty complaints to the Falklands war it is obvious that he has cast Professor Kramer as Mrs Thatcher. Whom has he cast as General Galtieri-himself, Mr Duffy or the Prime Minister? Has he noticed what happened to General Galtieri and who won the war?

—I will deal, first of all, with the reference to the Falklands war. Senator Hamer, as a keen student of all these matters, will know that the Falklands war was escalated over a considerable period from what to many people seemed to be a relatively small incident. That was the context in which that reference was made. The answer to the first part of the question is yes, Mr Duffy is the Minister for Communications. I am the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications. I am the Minister who represents the Minister for Communications in the Senate. I think anybody who was not desperately thrashing around to create an issue but who was studying gallup polls and the declining fortunes of the Liberal Party would understand why its fortunes are declining when he looked at the level of questions raised in the Senate today and in the last week or so regarding this and other issues. Let me make the simple point for Senator Hamer that when I first responded to that question I said that in my view a certain situation relating to the ABC had pertained in the past-I emphasise the words 'in my view'-and that it was a matter peculiarly within my knowledge. For that reason I expressed the answer in those terms-'in my view'. It is not the responsibility of anyone else to substantiate my view or otherwise . If honourable senators opposite want to go back over the years in relation to this chamber where Ministers-leaders of the government-have expressed views about the ABC, I will read a few of those views to honourable senators after lunch.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I refer to the Government's provision of $90m in extra capital to Trans Australia Airlines. Will the extra capital funds enable TAA to meet the heavy demand for cheaper air travel in Australia by introducing new lower air fares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The undercapitalisation of TAA has worried the Australian Labor Party for a considerable number of years. It is fairly clear that the Liberal conservative governments have deliberately carried into effect policies which were designed to constrain that organisation. I remind the Senate that on every occasion in the post-war years when the airline agreement has been renegotiated it has been done by the Liberal conservative governments and, invariably, on the eve of an election. So the Labor Party would have had very little influence on that agreement. Of course, if an organisation operates in an undercapitalised way it would have a lot of economic difficulties, particularly if those difficulties occur during a period of economic downturn.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's decision to increase TAA's capital by $90m was designed to improve the efficiency of the organisation. That step reflects the Government's commitment to a public airline and, of course, to the principles that exist in the two-airline agreement, which is of a competitive nature involving both the Government airline and the private airline organisation. Therefore, if we are to have an efficient air service in Australia it is essential that both organisations-Ansett Airlines of Australia and TAA-be given a real opportunity to compete on an equal, commercial basis. That has not been the position in the past. As a result of that competition consumers as well as the airlines will benefit. Without that capital which the Government has recently made available to TAA the two-airline system, in the view of the Government, will not satisfy the requirements of the Australian travelling public.

As the honourable senator would know, air fares for both TAA and Ansett are set on a nationally consistent basis by the Independent Air Fares Committee. However , the Government believes that the improvement of TAA's capital situation will lead to decreased interest payments for the airline which, together with self- help arrangements and measures already instituted by TAA, will allow it to contain costs and thus minimise the extent of future general air fare increases. This will put it on a competitive basis. The Government is confident that that will also enhance TAA's ability to develop new low-cost discount fare initiatives. I believe that answer replies to the purport of the question asked of me by Senator Maguire.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and refers to the decision by the Brisbane City Council that Brisbane bid for the 1987 World Student Games which, of course, is second in size only to the Olympic Games. Is it a fact that, as reported in the Press, Brisbane's Lord Mayor has been lobbying Federal Cabinet Ministers for several weeks in an attempt to get a continuing commitment of support from the Hawke Government and that all he has for his trouble is an agreement from some Ministers that they will inspect the project? In view of the fact that Brisbane must bid for the 1987 World Student Games during this year's games at Edmonton in July, will the Government give an immediate undertaking of financial support for this world sporting event?

—Despite the honourable senator having indicated to me yesterday her interest in this matter, I have not been able to get up-to-date information from the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, in reply to her question. However, I will make sure that he is aware of her interest and her requests for confirmation of Government intentions in this matter as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT REPORTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the Government resist the temptation to amend Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development reports in order to gain domestic political advantage? Secondly, will the Government encourage the OECD to include comparative tables that would measure Australia's economic performance with that of other comparable countries?

—I can safely assure Senator Ray that this Government would no more fiddle OECD reports than it would fiddle estimates of Budget deficits. Of course , as I am sure Senator Ray knows very well, the discredited Government which was thrown out of office a couple of months ago was exposed before the election as having fiddled the OECD report, and was exposed after the election as having fiddled the Budget deficit.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT REPORTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, arises from his answer to the last question that he was asked. Is he telling the Senate, on behalf of the Government, that the Department of the Treasury will not be permitted to comment on draft reports which are prepared by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development or to put views to the OECD which differ from those contained in the draft report and that in turn Ministers will not, in consultation with the Department of the Treasury or alone , put views to the OECD as to what should be in the reports?

—Of course information will be supplied to the OECD as it is supplied by all member governments. What will not be done in the future is a blatant attempt by the Treasurer-as the previous Treasurer did-to amend for partisan, political purposes the conclusions which the OECD comes to.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I again ask the Minister representing the Treasurer: Is he saying that, if a draft report is prepared by the OECD with which the Government and/or the Department of the Treasury do not agree, contrary views will not be put by the Government and/or the Department of the Treasury to the OECD before the report is published ?

—The situation outlined by Senator Chaney does not cover the actions of the previous Treasurer; it refers to a different set of circumstances . One of the things that struck me immediately after the election was to see on the Sunday television program the former Treasurer, who two weeks before had been speaking with the prestige and authority of his office and the Department of the Treasury, looking and sounding like a sordid bookkeeper who had been caught out fiddling the accounts.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware that the Brisbane City Council's transport operations are being severely affected by the failure of the Queensland State Government to allocate funds, including Commonwealth funds for metropolitan public transport, to the Council for its bus operations? Will the Minister ask the Department of Transport to investigate the way in which Federal funds associated with metropolitan transport have been applied by the State Government and what can be done to channel an acceptable amount to the Brisbane City Council?

—The problems of urban transport systems are viewed by the Minister for Transport and, indeed, the Government with quite a degree of concern because we are interested in improving urban transport systems. However, the matters specifically asked by Senator Colston refer to matters on which I have not been adequately briefed. I will certainly seek to have the matters discussed with Mr Morris, whom I represent in this place, with a view to providing the honourable senator with some information which I hope will be of assistance to the citizens of Brisbane and ensuring that the funds made available are spent for the purpose for which they have been allocated.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL AUSTRALIAN AIR FORCE FLIGHTS OVER TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General and relates to his contradictory answers as to whether all documents relevant to the Royal Australian Air Force spy flights over South West Tasmania have been tabled. I ask: Why has he not tabled documents held by the Department of Aviation? Will he now table those documents? Does he not agree that the aviation documents on the spy flights might have some relevance?
—This is the first time on which I have become aware of a request for the tabling of documents from the Department of Aviation. If the honourable senator--
—You said that all relevant documents were tabled.

—There were two flights over Tasmania relating specifically to photographic surveillance of the dam site. If the honourable senator wants the precise navigational details of those flights-the mapping co-ordinates and the radio frequency on which the pilots communicated to miscellaneous control towers around the nation in the course of those flights-I am sure that information can be made available to her. What on earth she proposes to do with it remains a matter of considerable mystery to me, but I would be only too delighted to assist her if that is her request.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Those are not the documents I am referring to. I ask Senator Evans whether he believes that the aircraft movement messages might have some relevance in the area.
—Do not be tempted.
—No. Many movements are assuming relevance, but not aircraft movements at this stage.
—I have sought them and have been told I cannot get them without the Minister's permission.

—If the honourable senator seeks information about aircraft movements or any other kind of movements I will be only too delighted, as I keep saying, to extract the information for her. If she wants information about aircraft movements and messages that may be relevant to those movements I will endeavour to ascertain whether such documents exist and, if they do exist, to make them available to her.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ORGANISATION FOR ECONOMIC CO-OPERATION AND DEVELOPMENT REPORTS

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I again ask him: If this Government receives draft reports from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development with which the Government does not agree, or with which the Department of the Treasury does not agree, does he say that that disagreement will not be recorded with the OECD and that changes in those draft reports will not be sought?

—I have in my files, and I will bring them along for Senator Chaney tomorrow if he likes, several letters written during May and April of 1982 from the Secretary to the Treasury in which he assured me that it was not normal practice-indeed, if I recall correctly, he went beyond saying that it was not normal practice; he gave an unequivocal assurance that officers of the Treasury did not attempt to do it-to bring pressure to bear on the OECD when it was writing its reports concerning the conclusions which were reached about the Australian economy. Twelve months ago the Secretary to the Treasury said that that just was not done. We know that in, I think, January this year the former Treasurer virtually instructed the OECD to change the conclusions contained in the report which was about to be issued and certainly leaned on Commonwealth officers with a view to having that done. That was completely incompatible with the previous practice followed by the Treasury and outlined by the Secretary in his letters to me of May last year, which I will be happy to bring in--
—It was shonky, too.

—It was certainly shonky-just as shonky as fiddling the accounts and misleading the electorate in the week before the 5 March election. Twice during that week he had received official advice from the Treasury on the deficit: In the first case that it would be $9 billion; in the second case that it would be $9.6 billion. He then told the public it would be $6 billion.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The same question has been addressed to the honourable senator three times. He has refused to answer the question. He has addressed himself to a quite separate matter relating to the previous Government. I ask that he be sat down.
—There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition knows that it is the prerogative of any Minister to answer a question in the way he chooses.

—Thank you, Mr President. If I may proceed with the point I was making immediately before being interrupted, the former Treasurer was told by the Treasury on the Tuesday before the election that the projected 1983-84 deficit on the then Government's expenditure program was $9 billion. On the day before the election he was told that it was $9.6 billion. On one or both of those occasions he went to the then Prime Minister and said: 'What should be done with this?' Both of them had been telling the public that the projected deficit was $6 billion. Of course, the then Prime Minister said: 'Keep the lid on it until after the election'. That is precisely what the former Treasurer did . The former Treasurer is now the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party of Australia. It is a fair indication of the depths to which the Liberal Party has sunk, that it could elect as Deputy Leader somebody who had so grievously misled the public for the most sordid political reasons in the week prior to a Federal election.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest to the Minister that he should look at Standing Order 100 which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: In answering any such question, a Senator shall not debate the matter to which the same refers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, naturally I accept your ruling.
—Sit down.

—Oh no, I have not finished with you by a long way. If Senator Chaney wishes, tomorrow I will bring into the Senate the relevant extracts of the correspondence-or the letters, if he prefers-between Mr Stone and me about one year ago, with the assurances Mr Stone gave in that letter as to what was normal behaviour by Treasury officers when dealing with the OECD. I will also provide-if I can find them in time, and I think I can-transcripts and other reports of what the former Treasurer did with regard to the OECD in January this year, when he completely departed from what the Treasury Secretary said was normal practice. In other words, the former Treasurer established a new practice of leaning on the OECD, attempting what was tantamount to falsification of the OECD conclusions, for the most sordid political reasons which were expedient for the government of the day.

—Will the Minister representing the Minister for Trade take steps to correct the current trade practice whereby some goods produced overseas are labelled 'Made in Australia'? Will the Minister also inquire into the common practice whereby packaged goods are labelled in small print with the country of origin, but the labelling of the packaging itself, which is made in Australia, is prominently displayed, thus deceiving members of the public into thinking that they are buying locally made products?

—I certainly was not aware of the mislabelling or misrepresentations, if that is a fair term to use, to which Senator Elstob referred. I will refer the inquiry to the Minister for Trade. I am sure that he will have the matter thoroughly investigated and will supply an answer to Senator Elstob either by private correspondence or by providing additional information for the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Minerals and Energy. It concerns the union bans presently in force on the mining and export of coal from the Drayton mine in New South Wales. Is the Minister aware of reports that this ban, together with the decision to block South Korean investment in the Jackson pipeline in Queensland, could have wide ramifications for future employment growth on the Queensland and New South Wales coalfields? Does this situation not run contrary to the Government's pre-election promises of greater employment opportunities under a Hawke Labor Government? Is the Minister not concerned that these two setbacks could bring retaliation from the Koreans by their taking their coal, iron ore and beef business elsewhere, not only significantly reducing Australia's export earning capacity but also helping to compound the unemployment problem in this country? What does the Minister intend to do about this situation? Is he content to let Australia's trade relations suffer and dwindle as the unemployment queues grow longer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has, of course, been concerned throughout its period in office, and members of the Government were concerned even before their party came to office, about the industrial dispute surrounding Drayton. We have endeavoured in various forums to have negotiated a settlement which will enable that mine to commence producing and which will resolve the industrial dispute. Among those initiatives are the original meeting of the Coal Conference which was held in this chamber on 30 March, a subsequent meeting of the Australian Coal Consultative Council, the involvement of Commonwealth officers in discussions between Mr Dolan and other officers of the Australian Council of Trade Unions with the unions concerned and a number of other private discussions involving Ministers in the New South Wales Government as well as Ministers in the Federal Government. I do not want to have too much made of this matter, but I believe that there are some grounds to be more optimistic about a satisfactory resolution of this dispute than appeared to be the case a few weeks ago.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the first part of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question, concerning the Jackson pipeline, I can only repeat what I said here yesterday: There seems to have been an extraordinary departure from the free enterprise rhetoric of the Queensland Government for that Government to have interfered against the wishes of the Australian partners in this proposal. The Australian partners in the Jackson pipeline had the plans made, they had all the money, construction had actually commenced and the Queensland Government, with a heavy dose of Brisbane centralism, intervened and compelled the Australian partners to take a 25 per cent ICC equitity. That move, of course, was ultimately blocked by the Foreign Investment Review Board with the support of the Treasurer. I do not believe the Jackson incident will have any ramifications on subsequent Australian trade with Korea. It might have some ramifications on contributions to the Bjelke-Petersen trust.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING COMMISSION

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President has received a letter from Senator Peter Baume proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to justify charges against the Chairman of the A. B.C. and the implications of this for the future independence of the National Broadcasting Authority.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance is not about criticism of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The issue is not criticism of the ABC; it never has been. No doubt governments and oppositions will criticise the ABC on issues as they have done in the past. They will continue to do so. It is not a debate about public criticism of the ABC. But to use an inelegant phrase introduced into public debate a few weeks ago by the President of the Australian Labor Party, this has been an exercise by Labor politicians of applying a blowtorch to the belly of the Chairman of the ABC. It has been seen as such in the public place. It carries with it threats for the future of the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not a debate about this Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Dame Leonie Kramer; but it is a debate about the most senior Minister of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, the Minister for Industry and Commerce, what he and his Government stand for and matters on which they stand condemned. It is about the conduct of the Minister for Industry and Commerce. It is about his failure to justify his allegations and his failure to produce adequate explanations for an ungenerous, unnecessary, unsubstantiated and cowardly attack in this place upon a distinguished Australian. It is about the subsequent revelation that he and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who was then Leader of the Opposition, had tried to influence the programming of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It is about his confirmation yesterday that he would have expected interference with the staff of the ABC by the management in response to complaints of the kind that he made. I remind him of the response that he made to an interjection by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The series of events which have come to light recently are matters of grave concern to the Opposition.

This Government has been in office just three months and already it has displayed its ineptitude on this as on so many matters. To trace the extraordinary set of circumstances surrounding this most unfortunate affair--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order 406. The honourable senator, despite his years of experience in the chamber, is clearly reading his speech-prepared by somebody else.
—There is no point of order.

—I will trace this most extraordinary set of circumstances. First of all, Senator Button, in this place, cast aspersions on the impartiality and, thus, on the integrity of the Chariman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Under parliamentary privilege he alleged here that the Chairman had not always acted without fear or favour. At best, Senator Button's remarks in the Senate on 4 May could have been attributed to a slip of the tongue, even if it was an unfortunate one. At worst, it could be seen-it is seen now-as a deliberate slur and reflection on the current Chairman. Senator Button's spirited and continuing defence of his comment indicates that it was deliberate, that it was intentional and that he stands by it. In addition, Senator Button, having made the slur, was not prepared to elaborate with details here in the Parliament. Instead, he offered to elaborate privately to members of the Senate outside the chamber in the privacy of his office. His attack in Parliament is serious enough. It is hard enough for Dame Leonie Kramer to be able to defend herself. But it was impossible for her to try to defend herself when no details were given of the offences which she was supposed to have committed and when Senator Button, in this place, refused an invitation to produce the details in the Parliament where he made the allegation.

SPEECH.PARA: To make the serious allegation under parliamentary privilege and then to refuse to substantiate it in the Senate was reprehensible. The place to elaborate the charge was here where he made it. That Senator Button should then go on and express his surprise that Dame Leonie Kramer should mount a defence on her own behalf is incredible. After all, she was, like the Falkland Islands, to use Senator Button's own unfortunate analogy, the subject of a sneak surprise attack last week.

Understandably, the Chairman of the ABC immediately called for Senator Button to spell out the nature of allegations which he made. He declined to do so here. He was not prepared to do so at the time of his statement; he elected to write to Professor Kramer. The contents of the correspondence reveal that the hapless Senator Button could not even establish a case to justify what he said. As I understand it, the nature of Senator Button's complaint, certainly from the letter he wrote, went as follows: That a supervisor had reprimanded or counselled a reporter; that knowing of this Senator Button informed Dame Leonie Kramer of the matter and of his concern arising out of it. Senator Button, in his letter, acknowledged that Dame Leonie did investigate the matter. She made a judgment; and he disagreed with the judgment she made. This series of events, as I have set them out now, was offered by Senator Button as evidence to support a most serious charge, probably the most serious charge one could make against someone holding an office of the kind held by Dame Leonie. That is what he used to justify the charge.

Dame Leonie Kramer responded by letter. Her response was, first, that Senator Button was wrong in terms of the context he set; he was wrong as to the nature of the interaction; he was wrong as to whether there was a Press conference or the circumstances in which the comments were made. But she went on to put it in these terms. I will use her words. She said:

You then refer to those aspects of this incident which are 'not a matter of public knowledge'. Again, your recollection is at variance with the facts. It was not you who raised the matter with me, but Mr Hawke. He telephoned me on February 8, 1983, and having informed me that you were present, proceeded to register his displeasure at certain aspects of the programs of February 4, 1983.

That is what Dame Leonie Kramer said. It was not Senator Button who raised the matter with her; it was Mr Hawke who raised the matter with her. I wonder why the honourable senator got that wrong. She went on to refer to certain other matters in which criticism was raised of the fact that an ABC officer is supposed to have had ties with the Liberal Party. She said:

In referring to Ms O'Neil's comment, and the rebuke she received, he remarked that a member of the A.M. Staff 'had ties with the Liberal Party,' and criticised the senior officer who spoke to Ms O'Neil, adding, 'This warrants a change.' Mr Hawke then said, 'I'm damned if I'm going to put up quietly with this situation.'

What are they talking about? I know an officer who is associated with AM who was previously a Press officer for a Minister in a Liberal Government. The Minister was Senator the Honourable Sir Robert Cotton. He stopped being a Minister on 20 December 1977. He left the Senate in July 1978. This officer may, I think, have spent some time in Macquarie Street in the State Parliament, but he then went back to the ABC to take up duty as an officer with the ABC. I do not know whether he has ever been a party member. I do not know and I would not ask him. But, has no one heard of George Negus who worked on the staff of Mr Murphy? Has no one heard of Kerry O'Brien who worked with Mr Bowen? Has no one heard of Mr Holgate who worked on the staff of Mr Barnard? Has no one heard of Garry--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who?

—Mr Holgate, who worked with Mr Barnard and who later went on to be Labor Premier of Tasmania. Has no one heard of Gary Scully who even now will be moving to head the Government Information Unit or whatever it is called? Of course, officers of the ABC can move in and out of government. What is it supposed to mean when Mr Hawke talks about supposed links with the Liberal Party ? It does not mean a thing, except that it was another way for Mr Hawke to display some kind of paranoia about what was going on inside the ABC. Dame Leonie's letter raises one other very important matter which reflects credit upon her. It stated, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: I think you should know that great care was taken to keep the source of the complaint confidential so as not to give rise to any suspicion within the ABC or outside it, that Mr Hawke and you were trying to influence its internal affairs, particularly during an election period.

I would say that that is an act of great generosity by Dame Leonie Kramer. She went to great lengths to protect Mr Hawke and Senator Button even while, as she said, they were moving to try to influence the internal affairs of the ABC during an election campaign. It is pathetically indulgent and is asking too much of the credibility and intelligence of the Australian public to offer such a piffling incident as justification for the attack the honourable senator made in this place under privilege on Dame Leonie Kramer. No commentator, no newspaper and no editorial writer in the country has accepted what Senator Button said, has accepted the argument or has accepted that it is adequate. I will give the Senate some examples of what the papers had to say. Mr Geoffrey Barker of the Age said:
The whole exercise . . . stinks of a witch hunt. It is the politics of the smear made under the cloak of Parliamentary privilege.
He is talking about Senator John Button when he says that. He continues:
His examples are frivolous and vexatious and do not justify the grave allegations he made against Dame Leonie.
The Australian Financial Review in its editorial of 9 May stated:
At the start it has to be said that the examples of supposed political partiality cited by Senator Button are trivial in the extreme.
The Australian newspaper in its weekend edition of 7-8 May said:
. . . the instance he cites scarcely justifies the magnitude of his charge that she failed, has failed, to act 'without fear or favour'.
Finally, what did Michelle Grattan say in the Age newspaper? She wrote:

When Senator Button released the correspondence yesterday and his 'notes' of complaints made by Labor during the campaign his position appeared weaker than ever-and left some serious questions about his performance.

That is what the newspaper writers had to say. That is how they regard the charge he made and his failure to substantiate it. It is not good enough for Senator Button to suggest that the reason his letter mentioned only the Helen O' Neil incident was that this was all that was needed to prove his point. No editorial writer accepted that it proved his point. No writer of a newspaper article accepted that it proved his point, and his own office later fed out other material which was the subject of complaint. The fact is that he must have realised the frivolous nature of his objection and he must have sought to put out more material to try to bolster a weak case. The rest of Australia certainly made the judgment that he had failed to substantiate a most serious charge made against a worthy Australian. But most importantly, Senator Button's letter misrepresented the central fact: It was not he who raised the matters with Dame Leonie Kramer; it was Mr Hawke, now the Prime Minister of Australia.

What has emerged is that he and Mr Hawke have acted to put pressure on the Australian Broadcasting Commission. They have attempted to put pressure on its programming policy, and this goes right to the basis of ABC independence. Senator Button and Mr Hawke sought, first, to interfere with an AM program and to interfere with its staff. What did the phrase 'there has to be a change' mean ? It means that they wanted some change either in the staffing or the program. It means quite clearly that Mr Hawke was seeking more favourable treatment for himself during the election campaign and doing this by way of a quiet and tough approach behind the scenes in an attempt to heavy the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Senator Button and Mr Hawke are trying now to punish Dame Leonie Kramer, because her response to the queries, and her response throughout, has been impeccable; it has been fair. In fact she went to some lengths to protect members of the Australian Labor Party by not revealing to officers of the Australian Broadcasting Commission that it was they who were making the complaints.
