She did not carry out the partial and what would have been improper interference with programming which was sought.

Against this action by Senator Button and Mr Hawke we have a reassurance by Senator Button on AM on 6 May that the role of the Chairman should be in asserting the independence of the ABC without fear or favour in all circumstances. This is precisely what Dame Leonie Kramer did. She did assert the independence of the ABC without fear or favour even in the face of pressure from the man who hoped to be the Prime Minister of Australia.

When examined in the context of the imminent changes to the ABC this whole episode is particularly significant. At this moment the Government is seeking parliamentary approval to dismantle the existing Commission and to establish a broadcasting corporation. This change will give the Government the power and the opportunity to sack all the existing commissioners and to establish a new board. The Opposition has recently sought assurances in the Senate that there will not be a wholesale sacking of the present commissioners. The responses we have received give little confidence that the present commissioners will receive a fair go. We seek other assurances, and we have received some, that there will be no interference with the defence case mounted by the ABC in the current defamation proceedings and that a hand-picked board will not settle with Mr Wran out of court, thus preventing an airing of the defamation charges. We sought assurances that there will be no threat to the independence of programs of the kind that has already been attempted.

Far from modifying his position or giving assurances to the Senate and the Australian public, Senator Button actually continued and extended his attack upon Dame Leonie Kramer in the Senate yesterday. The real basis of Senator Button's complaint is the opposite of what he alleged. He alleges that Dame Leonie Kramer did not act without fear or favour. Clearly, she did. She acted without fear or favour, and that is why the boot has gone in. He demanded that she intervene directly in a program about which he had a complaint. She refused to do this. The Prime Minister called her on the telephone and abused her-he has so much to say about consensus-and she refused to intervene. It appears that consensus today means the capacity to do what Mr Hawke asks and to agree with him.

Senator Button seems incapable of comprehending the difference stressed by Professor Kramer between defending the principle of non-intervention in management decisions and condoning the action taken. They are different matters. She did carry out the principle of non-intervention, even though Senator Button and she disagreed on the subject. The continued independence of the ABC is fundamental. It is widely recognised. On AM on 6 May Dame Leonie said:

Well, the Government has said what I can only endorse-that it regards the independence of the ABC as absolutely important and I take it that that means it doesn't expect the Chairman to be sensitive in a way which means yielding to pressure.

Of course, that is what it means even when Mr Hawke and Senator Button phone her during an election. Let the Australian Labor Party declare that what is good for other political parties and groups is good for the ALP as well.

This is not just an Opposition exercise; it is a genuine matter of public distress and concern. Every editorial writer and every newspaper article has said so. The cartoonists have had a field day with Senator Button. Not one article that I have seen in a major newspaper has anything but derision for Senator Button. Not one article has anything but criticism for what he has done or concern for the implications. Not one of them has anything but contempt for his performance and approach. But the role of Mr Hawke is more sinister. The man who tried muscle on the ABC by attempting to bully its Chairman is now Prime Minister of Australia. The Chairman-the person who stood up for the independence of the ABC when it mattered-has now come under attack in the Parliament. It reflects little credit upon the Government. It is not fair. It is not fair treatment of the Chairman. It is unncessary. It was done deliberately in Parliament by a senior Minister in such a way as to hurt someone not able to answer him here. Inevitably, it leaves a feeling of unease and suspicion about the fate likely to befall anyone who does not do just as is demanded. The incident shows just how shallow is consensus-the right to agree with Mr Hawke or to suffer attack. It is not good enough for Australia. Dame Leonie Kramer and the ABC deserve better. I submit the matter of public importance as one that warrants the serious consideration of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that the motiviations for this matter of public importance were revealed at the end of Senator Baume's speech when he said that the issue shows how shallow is consensus. That is the most profound wish of the Opposition; having failed in seven years to establish any consensus in this country, it is now critical of the consensus which the new Government has obtained. That, of course, is the main concern.
—Where is the consensus?

—Senator MacGibbon is, of course, desperate to establish a lack of consensus because it is upon that that he thrives. Let us look at the charge by Senator Baume, first of all that I behaved ungenerously and in a cowardly fashion by raising the matter in the Senate in the way in which I did. It is now suggested that it may have been a slip of the tongue. Senator Baume did not give me that indulgence on the day I said it; he said it was a deliberate attack. He implied that it was defamatory and that I should say it outside. Everything I have said in Parliament on this matter I have been prepared to say outside.
—You want to say it privately.
—I have been prepared to say it outside and I will continue to do so.
—You invited us to your rooms to tell us.
—I did not invite the honourable senator to my room and I assure the Senate that I never will. I am not going to fall into that trap.
—We didn't fall into your trap.

—Senator Sir John Carrick is very clever. Such an old fox ought to know better. We will hear about him in a minute. I want to go back to what actually took place. On 4 May in the Senate I applauded the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission for saying that the Commission had acted without fear or favour in what we can now call the Four Corners Wran matter, the matter about which the Opposition was directing questions at that stage to try to suggest that this Labor Government would connive in some way to nobble the ABC. Senator Baume is at it again today. It was in that context that I applauded the Chairman of the ABC for acting without fear or favour. I volunteered the additional comment that she had not always acted without fear or favour in the past. If honourable senators are interested to follow that set of facts through again, let us do so. I want to establish one thing: If the Opposition says that it is not the right of a member of parliament to criticise the Chairman of the ABC in this place, the Opposition has found some new values in the past fortnight or so.
—Give us some details when you do it.
—I am going to give some details.
—That was the criticism.

—The honourable senator must decide what the criticism is. He has not mentioned that today. He has levelled a number of others. First of all, this whole issue arose in the context of a grubby campaign to discredit the Premier of New South Wales, to do it in the context of the ABC, and to try to dictate from Opposition what the Government should do about its relationship with the Australian Broadcasting Commission.
—Four Corners was grubby, was it?

—I think I said the Opposition was grubby; I did not mention Four Corners as being grubby. As I have already mentioned, I said that 'without fear or favour' was the appropriate comment for the Chairman of the ABC to make in relation to the Four Corners program.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the issue of the complaint made by Mr Hawke, the Prime Minister and then Leader of the Opposition, and me in relation to matters which were on ABC programs on 4 February, I believe. Let me be quite clear about that: In one day on ABC programs three things were said relating to Mr Hawke, and by implication to me, as well as to the then Prime Minister. These three matters were put to the Chairman of the ABC, who is the self-acknowledged receiver of complaints on behalf of the ABC, in a sense as one complaint as they all happened on one day. Look what happened. It is said that we were trying to muzzle the ABC. One of the matters which were put to Dame Leonie Kramer as Chairman of the ABC was that the AM program had said that the Leader of the Opposition in Australia was named in a secret volume of the Costigan report dealing with criminality amongst ship painters and dockers, that that report was in a safe in Canberra and that the truth would come out in the course of an election campaign. That was said by an ABC program at the start of the 1983 Federal election. That rumour about the secret volume of the Costigan report was about throughout the lobbies and the Press Gallery in Canberra. Not one newspaper or other media outlet in Australia covered it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It just shows how they think.

—If the honourable senator wants to cover it, let him go outside this House to say it when he talks about cowards. Let Senator Lajovic, the great beneficiary of libel actions, talk about the Prime Minister and see how he gets on. Not one media organisation covered it, except the independent national broadcasting service. The same thing was said about me in relation to negotiations with Mr Hayden; the same sort of allegation was made. No newspaper or other media outlet in Australia mentioned it, although that story was about, because they realised that it was defamatory and untrue. Only the independent national broadcasting service ran those two stories on 4 February. On the same day, when a journalist for the ABC asked a totally innocuous question of Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, in answer to a stupid comment which he made, she was reprimanded. That was the package that was put to Dame Leonie Kramer by way of complaint. If we had wanted to silence the ABC in respect of those first two complaints we would have issued writs then and there. The ABC would not have talked any more about any of those things for the duration of the election campaign. But we did not want to do that against the Australian Broadcasting Commission, so we made a complaint to the Chairman. That was the appropriate course for us to take. If any honourable senators complain seriously about that, I really do not understand it at all.

SPEECH.PARA: What happened after 4 May this year, when I referred to that matter? Dame Leonie Kramer ought to have known what I was talking about. She involves herself in decisions of program makers in the ABC. She ought to have known what I was talking about. On the evening of Wednesday 4 May she said on television that there were no complaints in the course of the election campaign. She was probed by interviewers about the issue of complaints. Honourable senators can all read the transcript for themselves. I make no comment about it. She said: 'There were no complaints'. I thought it would be appropriate to jog the good Dame's memory about what took place. The appropriate way to do that, of course, was to send her a letter. That is the course of events which took place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you mention only one incident in that letter?

—I mentioned one incident because it seemed to me to be the most politically neutral issue to mention to her. I thought it would jog her memory about what took place. It has been said in the Senate in the course of debate-Mr Deputy President, this morning it was said impliedly by you-that I, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, should not say anything about Dame Leonie Kramer. Mr Deputy President, I do not know whether that was your view because she is a Dame or because she is Chairman of the ABC, but you said that I, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, should not say anything about her in this place because to do so is the function of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). Is that seriously the view of honourable senators opposite? If it is, I want them to have a little look at the record of Liberal Ministers in this place in relation to the ABC. In 1976, Senator Withers, then Leader of the Government in the Senate--
—We made no such assertion, Senator.
—Senator Baume should stop giggling like a girl and listen. Senator Withers said:

SPEECH.PARA: Do not raise the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Australian Labor Party has been leaning on it for years. It is full of the Labor Party's supporters and has been pumping out the Labor Party's propaganda . . . That is not a matter of opinion; it is a matter of notoriety. The sooner it is cleared up the better as far as I am concerned.

That is what Senator Withers, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, said in the Senate. Was he not entitled to say that? Where is the answer from all the noisy people opposite? I ask them whether Mr Nixon was entitled to say, prior to the 1975 election:
Never in its history will the Australian Broadcasting Commission be under such close scrutiny as during the coming election campaign.
ABC news and public affairs programs must expect unprecedented watchfulness by the National Country Party . . .
He talked also about the then Chairman of the ABC and said:
ABC Commissioner (Professor Downing) is either a naive academic or is part of the plot to disseminate socialist propaganda Australia-wide over ABC radio news.
At best, Professor Downing is so naive that he has had his head in the clouds for the past 20 years.

But they are all matters of history. Only last year, after the Premiers Conference, David Barnett, the Press Secretary to the former Prime Minister of Australia, leaned on two ABC journalists to stop a program going ahead which embarassed the Prime Minister and the then Treasurer, Mr Howard. I raised this matter in the Senate but did not get much of an answer from the then Minister responsible. When this matter was raised Senator Sir John Carrick, on behalf of the then Prime Minister, gave an answer in the following terms:

I am advised that my Press Secretary, David Barnett, did express to John Penlington his concern that Nationwide should have a balanced presentation on the final two evenings of television before the electronic media blackout.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—That was said by Senator Sir John Carrick in answer to a question. That was his advice from the then Prime Minister. That was a nice way of saying what the journalists concerned said-that they were leant on to stop a program going ahead. I invite honourable senators to contrast that behaviour with the sort of complaint about which honourable senators opposite are bellyaching today-the complaints made by Mr Hawke and me. I invite them to contrast the response we got then and the sort of response which has been given by Dame Leonie Kramer-a series of silly little points in a letter about whether it was actually Mr Hawke or me who spoke to her, as if that were relevant to the substantial issue about which she was quite clear.

SPEECH.PARA: The latter part of the matter of public importance states that honourable senators opposite are concerned about the future independence of the ABC under a government that they allege does this horrendous sort of thing. We are babes in the woods compared with the mob opposite and the way in which it has leaned on the ABC over the years. I have just given four examples out of many. Mr Hawke and I tried to save the ABC from repeating untrue allegations, made by no other media outlet in Australia, and from being sued, because that is what would have happened. It was in that context that these three matters were put to the Chairman of the ABC-the recipient of complaints.

Senator Peter Baume has given a lot of attention to these past matters and has not dealt at great length with his concern about the future independence of the ABC under a Labor government. Senator Baume even went out of his way to suggest that we were introducing legislation to get rid of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and to replace it with a new corporation. The former Government introduced that legislation, not us. It was introduced last year and we supported it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No argument.
—That is not what the honourable senator tried to suggest in his speech today.
—You misheard me, Senator.

—I did not mishear Senator Baume at all. That is what he was trying to suggest. It was his Government's legislation; essentially it is bipartisan legislation. But there is one important difference between the legislation which will be introduced this year and the legislation which the former Government introduced last year. The important difference is that enshrined in the legislation introduced last year was the most classic and notorious interference with the Australian Broadcasting Commission that this country could ever imagine. The former Government had included in that legislation a procedure for dealing with complaints which would have enabled journalists, program makers, members of the management and staff of the ABC to be investigated in relation to program content, to be penalised, fined and otherwise dealt with in a punitive way in the course of their work as members of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. There has been no more horrendous potential interference with the Australian Broadcasting Commission and its future than the legislation that the former Government introduced. I just want to tell honourable senators opposite what the Chairman of the British Broadcasting Commission, who was in Australia last year, had to say about the former Government's legislation for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. He said that it was the most terrifying legislation. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: 'The whole package of legislation is so bad and so discriminatory that if I were a member of the ABC I would say, Let's down tools and walk off in protest,' . . .
Mr George Howard, Chairman of the British Broacasting Commission and owner of a stately home in the area where Brideshead Revisited was made, also stated when visiting Australia last year:
If such legislation were introduced in Britain I could not speak for the consequences . . .

He went on to make other comments of the same kind. But he described the former Government's legislation for the ABC-in respect of its interference, its punitive powers with journalists-as 'terrifying legislation'. That legislation was introduced by honourable senators opposite, yet they talk about their concern for the future of the Australian Broadcasting Commission under a Labor government on the basis of this petty little incident which arose in the Senate a week ago. Of course they are doing it because they have nothing better to talk about as an opposition. They are going down the slippery pole of political fortunes day after day. Every election shows that they are getting worse and worse because they have nothing to talk about. Honourable members opposite are an empty-headed lot. They will thrive on any little bit of scuttle-butt that comes into this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did well in Wannon! How many per cent did you lose?

—I am sorry if I have disturbed the honourable senator in any way . I was going to say to her that I would think again about that invitation to my room, but on second thoughts I will not. Next week we will introduce into the Senate legislation which deals with the ABC. It will not have in it a complaints procedure which will make it, in the words of the Chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation, 'terrifying legislation', as was that which was introduced by honourable senators opposite last year. It will have procedures for the appointment of a new corporation which is bipartisan and common ground.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, in determining the membership of the board of that corporation we will be guided by only one set of criteria; that is, business competence, knowledge of broadcasting and capacity to serve on a board for what can again be a great broadcasting organisation. It will not be a broadcasting organisation which, in the words of Sir Henry Bland, the Chairman in 1976 under the Fraser Government, was cut to the bone by that Government. Five years later it said that its funds had been cut by the Government by 22 per cent since that description of being cut to the bone was given by the Chairman. Those are the things that go to the independence of a great broadcasting service, those are the things which will be enshrined in the legislation which we will introduce in this Parliament. We, as a party, look forward to a much more independent and vigorous Australian Broadcasting Commission than any we have seen in recent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today debating a matter of public importance in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to justify charges against the Chairman of the ABC and the implications of this for the future independence of the National Broadcasting Authority.

The Senate has just listened to a somewhat spirited defence by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) but, unfortunately, not in answer to the charge that has been laid. Nobody on this side of the chamber disputes the right of the Government or anyone else in this chamber to criticise the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The charge in this matter relates to the personal attacks of the Leader of the Government against the current Chairman of the ABC and the implications of those attacks. It is a most important subject to debate.

There is now considerable public disquiet as to the relationship between the ABC and the new Government. It follows the unsubstantiated attack by Senator Button on Professor Kramer, which I just mentioned, which one can only suspect was linked with the annoyance of the Australian Labor Party with the ABC Four Corners program in which such serious allegations were made against Labor's Premier Wran. It follows the attempted bullying of Professor Kramer by Mr Hawke during the election campaign and what that means in relation to the future independence of the ABC. It follows the concern as to who actually takes responsibility in this Government for the Department of Communications. Is it the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in the other place, or Senator Button ? I will detail further the amazing lack of communication between the two of them. It is also feared that the new board will be structured to reflect the Government's view arising from comments from Senator Button that he regretted the appointment of Professor Kramer. There is real concern in the ABC and in the community in relation to this matter. It is a matter of public importance notwithstanding that Senator Button, late in his speech, attempted to laugh it off. The debate is timely and appropriate and it is important that it is taking place today.

I will remind the Senate and those listening to the debate of the brief history of this unfortunate matter. It began just over a week ago after the Four Corners program, when Senator Button was asked whether the ABC had resources to defend itself in litigation arising from the program, litigation instituted by Mr Wran, and to assure the Senate that there would be no interference with the ABC in defending itself. They are both quite reasonable and legitimate questions. But Senator Button, exhibiting considerable irritation, presumably at the subject being raised at all, said in passing that the Chairman of the ABC, Professor Kramer, had not always acted without fear or favour. He therefore imputed a lack of professional integrity, possibly the most serious charge that could be laid against the chairman of a national broadcasting commission. Having raised the subject publicly, he condemned her in vague and unspecific terms. He then said he would explain what he meant only privately; he would leave the Parliament, the media and the Australian public to speculate. He lost all credibility on the subject when he added that he would not use Question Time to 'enumerate a long history of what I would regard as a lack of independence by the Chairman of the ABC'. He has not attempted to substantiate that charge to this day. It is not surprising that this led to speculation as to what the Government intended in relation to the current Australian Broadcasting Commission and the composition of the future board. That speculation was inflamed by the Minister for Communications in the other place refusing to deny that mass changes were planned. He said:
No decision has been made in respect of the board at this stage. I have no further comment.

Was this a planned exercise to soften the public for the changes, or an attempt to justify them? Was it even a plan to remove the Chairman of the ABC in order to change the ABC's policy in relation to not settling defamation actions, as has been suggested by some, the defamation action in relation to this matter being that instituted by the Labor Premier in New South Wales? It is not surprising that the Minister's attitude inflamed speculation that the Government was annoyed that the Four Corners program had not been censored and raised questions of whether the ABC would be independently secure under this Government . It emphasises how important it is to protect the ABC from political pressure which is a particularly important reason why this debate is of such consequence today. The ABC will stand or fall by the responsibility exhibited by its officers. Accepting that the subject matter was properly researched and verified it would have been a disgrace if the Chairman had not had the courage to support the integrity of her staff and the program had been censored. As a result of that courage, the allegations are now the subject of a royal commission. That is the proper place for the charge to be laid.

I will deal further with the history of this matter. Senator Button's allegations left Professor Kramer no ability to respond because the accusation was in such a general form. It was an impossible and embarrassing position in which to find herself. It exhibited a lack of respect not only for her, but also for the position she holds. We gather that Senator Button is particularly critical of one raising the subject, but what did the editorial writers say? I refer to the Age of 6 May. The editorial is headed: 'Button puts his foot in it' . It states:
Senator Button does himself and the Government no credit when he uses parliamentary privilege to attack the chairman of the ABC. It is an odd--
I ask honourable senators to note this point-
position for the senator to take, to stress the Government's commitment to the ABC's independence, while at the same time publicly impugning the integrity of its chairman.

Senator Button's incautious statement about Professor Kramer is a surprising display of ineptitude on the part of a senior Minister. His allegation that Professor Kramer had not always discharged her responsibilities without 'fear or favour' is a serious one. What Senator Button is saying, in effect, is that Professor Kramer has exhibited bias in the conduct of her duties, that she has not fulfilled the obligations laid down for members of the ABC under its charter .
An editorial in the Australian of the same date speaking of Senator Button stated:
He has cast a serious reflection on the integrity of the nationally-owned radio and television service and on an individual unable to confront her accuser inside the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't one of the papers say he should button his lip?

—I think it did say that he should button his lip. We then had the astonishing admission of Mr Duffy that he did not know of the examples Senator Button had of Professor Kramer's alleged lack of objectivity. What form of communication does that exhibit within the Ministry? Astonishingly, Mr Duffy then added:

SPEECH.PARA: I've no doubt he has instances.

He said that having admitted that he has no knowledge of them. Is that a responsible statement from the Minister? Senator Button then wrote to Professor Kramer but, equally astonishingly, he did not even show the letter to the Minister for Communications in the other place. Just how is the Ministry to operate within this Government? How it is to operate is difficult to imagine. It appears to have a communications problem. Then the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) waded in and said that it is up to Professor Kramer to make the letter public. It is not up to her at all. Senator Button, who made the allegation in such vague and ambiguous terms, made it in public. He should have substantiated it in public and the Government should have taken appropriate action.

What did Senator Button say? Firstly, he said that he thought the issue fairly insignificant. It appears to have been insignificant for him and insignificant for no one else. Secondly, he said that the issue had concerned what objective commentators now call an aside-a somewhat inappropriate aside-in an interview with the Prime Minister in which the interviewer somewhat harmlessly, I concede, commented on President Reagan having been an actor. That interviewer was warned to be more careful about asides. That was the alleged bias-that the interviewer was warned to be more careful about asides. When Professor Kramer was told to take action what did she determine? She determined that:
It was not an unreasonable caution at the start of a campaign in which the ABC saw itself as having to be particularly careful to be evenhanded.

That was Professor Kramer failing to act without fear or favour! The situation is ridiculous. It shows how unsubstantiated the allegation was and how improper it was to make the allegation. Then we learn that during the campaign the Opposition Leader, Mr Hawke, had got involved also. He telephoned Professor Kramer and in not mild terms said:
I'm damned if I'm going to put up quietly with this situation.

He demanded an investigation within 24 hours. They were the bully tactics of the man who is now Prime Minister of Australia. What did the editorial writers say about these activities? Firstly, in regard to Senator Button and his further involvement I refer to Senator Jessop's good memory of an editorial appearing in the Daily Telegraph headed: 'Button your lips'. The article appearing in the Daily Telegraph stated:

Hard on his heels came Senator Button with his off the cuff remark about the impartiality of the Chairman of the ABC. In his letter to Dame Leonie Kramer elaborating on his comment, Senator Button then wrote: 'I thought the matter was fairly insignificant, and I did not anticipate that this remark would become a matter of public controversy'.

It is an amazing admission that a Federal Minister should think that he can impugn the motives of the chairman of the ABC with a loaded aside in the privileged sanctuary of the Senate and not expect to be called on to explain.

In one respect, however, Senator Button was right. The matter he was complaining of was fairly insignificant. It's challenge to Dame Leonie's impartiality rested on a mere three instances of alleged anti-Labor reporting by the ABC during the entire month long federal election campaign.
The Australian Financial Review of 9 May, speaking of Mr Hawke's involvement, stated:

Attempts to intimidate the ABC are usually crude and ineffectual. For the then Leader of the Opposition to attempt to bully the chairman of the ABC over the telephone is evidence of his errors of judgment, not of partiality by the ABC. There is indeed much to complain of in terms of prejudices and bias expressed by members of the ABC staff, and there is occasional evidence of political commitment, usually not to any major political party.
But these are matters which a strong management, given sufficient authority by the board and the Government, should be able to deal with.

That, of course, is the strong position of Dame Leonie Kramer, a courageous person who is prepared not to be bullied by the Hawkes of this world. Finally, we have the allegation that the Vice-Chairman of the ABC, Mr Laurie Short, who recently retired as Federal Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association, described in the Sydney Morning Herald as a close friend and adviser to Mr Wran, wanted references to Mr Wran censored. All major public institutions need to be headed by men and women with courage who will not act in fear or for favour. It appears that the ABC is so headed. Professor Kramer deserves a public apology. It appears from the actions of Senator Button-the principal author of the Labor Party's policy on communications -Mr Duffy and Mr Hawke that the public disquiet in this area is well justified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happily oppose the matter of public importance and support the Government and my colleague and leader, Senator Button. I have heard a definition of junk food as being something prepared for profit but not for nourishment. Indeed, that definition can be extended to junk mail and junk information. But I think that in the Senate this afternoon we can apply that definition to a new area-a junk MPI. This matter of public importance has been put forward for political profit but not for the nourishment of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It is, after all, a storm in a teacup or, some could say, a storm in a radio dish. It is an attempt by the Opposition to try to beat up a Melbourne Truth-like headline out of a matter which does not in any sense merit that.
—Does Professor Kramer agree with you?

—I know the honourable senator wants to stifle my contribution but I will not be so stopped. Let me turn to the terms of the junk MPI that has been advanced by the Opposition. Firstly, it calls on the Government to justify charges against the Chairman. I believe Senator Button has rebuked those who framed those words more adequately than I. Therefore, I turn to the second part of the MPI which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the implications of this for the future independence of the National Broadcasting Authority.

I think it is proper to take those words and to look at the record of the Opposition when it was the Government in terms of the ABC. We should see what the record of the then Government and now Opposition was on the integrity, the authority and the independence of the ABC. Shortly after the Fraser Government was elected in 1976, in an effort which obviously showed that the Government could not wait to get its hands on the ABC, the famous Sir Henry Bland appointment was made. Quite clearly that appointment had the effect of dismaying and outraging many people in the community and most of the listeners, staff and employees of the ABC. I remind the Opposition that it gave rise to the establishment of a friends of the ABC organisation as a community organisation to protect the ABC from the acts of the now Opposition, the then Government. As well, a legend began to appear on bumper stickers around Australia stating: ' Stop screwing the ABC'. That is what the public of Australia thought about the Fraser Government's appointment and the move of Sir Henry Bland into the ABC.

Perhaps more important than those comments is an examination of what the Fraser Government did to the ABC. An examination will reveal its true intent. If we look at the net operational appropriations per annum, starting with 1974-75 and taking that analysis through until the 1981-82 period, we find that in 1974-75, under Mr Whitlam, an appropriation of $110m was made. Using constant figures, in real terms the appropriations declined under Mr Fraser and under Sir Henry Bland 's axe to $98m the next year, $95m the following year, $93m the year after that and $91m-the rock bottom allocation-in 1979-80. It is true that in 1980-81 the allocation rose again to $95m but that figure, in real terms, was still below the level of allocation in 1974-75 under Mr Whitlam. They were the appropriations for the operational activities of the ABC.

Capital appropriations have suffered even more devastatingly. In 1974-75, under Mr Whitlam, an allocation of $18m plus was made to the ABC for capital appropriations. Let us look at 1978-79. Under the administration of Sir Henry Bland there was an allocation of $7m. That was a savage reduction. In 1981-82, when in real terms there was an appropriation of $14m, that in real terms was $ 4m below the appropriation in the period of the Labor Government. One can talk about the independence of an organisation but if one starts cutting off the flow of funds one causes that organisation to suffer considerable deprivation. Its services, morale and ability to deliver the services Australians expect will fall.

The cuts in funding have had three major effects. The quality of transmission and staffing have been affected. Those cuts in staff have been matched by a reduction in real terms. The reduction in staffing has been brought about by the inflexible law of natural wastage. This means that the ABC, in various aspects of its operation, has developed gaps in its administration and has developed an unbalanced structure by not replacing people when they leave or retire. In the regrowth of some fundings towards the latter period it has also meant that the ABC has created some high positions without the base backup of staffing. It has maintained the concentration of its national and State office in Sydney and this has led to a confusion of roles and consequential problems for the regional areas. If we look at the Fraser record, in relation to money and staffing, we see that they are the conclusions that we come to. Of course we have had an inquiry into the ABC-the Dix Committee of Review into the Australian Broadcasting Commission-and that paints a sorry picture of what happened to the ABC during the period of the Fraser Government. I want to take some time in order to cite some of the quotations from the Dix report. The Dix Committee identified acute management problems in the ABC. It received submissions that stated:
low morale was pervasive in the organisation and was reducing efficiency;
there were organisational and management shortcomings;
staff had lost faith in senior management;
there had been a failure of communications between management and staff;
there was no confidence among staff that management would stand up for them.
Criticisms of management were borne out by the ANOP survey commissioned by the Dix Committee.
ANOP found that contributing factors to lack of confidence within the ABC were:
insufficient resources--
given to the ABC-something over which the Fraser Government had control--
insufficient information about audiences;
lack of clear management guidelines and direction, particularly in relation to overall goals.
I will quote some of the findings of the Dix Committee as set out in volume 1, paragraph 68, which state:

The organisation structure of the ABC has developed by increment, rather than rational appraisal and review in many areas. Several current organisational groupings conflict with one another, generating waste and inefficiency. This lack of harmony contributes to the general sense of unbridled bureaucracy which people within and outside of the organisation often feel. It is a major factor in the alienation of staff, including some who have left the organisation.
Elsewhere, in paragraph 65, volume 1, it is stated:
Successive Commissions seem to have given high priority to creating a 'career service' and this has diverted the ABC from concentrating on the creative aspects of its role.
Paragraph 55, volume 1, states:

A degree of criticism and restlessness among staff is a characteristic of a healthy organisation, especially one engaged in creative activities. We were bound to find some in the ABC. But the level of morale in the organisation is poor to the point where its effectiveness is reduced.

I have taken time to cite those quotations and discuss the funding given to the ABC by the former Government to come to the point of the Opposition's matter of public importance which is about the integrity and independence of the ABC. The Opposition's record in this area shows that it has tried, by one means or another, to impugn that integrity and independence. I believe that that demonstration of what has happened under the Fraser Government is clearly the greatest indictment of the honourable senators who have brought forward this MPI . However, I want to contrast that with the position of the current Government. The Labor Government wants a free, independent ABC with a bipartisan charter. It wants to give the ABC its own Act and bring it out from under the Broadcasting and Television Act. It wants to give it a clear charter to be innovative and provide comprehensive radio and television services. Under the charter it wants to provide a contribution to our national identity, to reflect cultural diversity and to recognise the multicultural nature of Australia.

The Government's attitude to the appointments to the Board of the ABC is clear. There is no ambiguity. The arguments that have been forthcoming from the Opposition benches cannot be sustained. The position of the Government, in terms of appointments to the ABC Board, is that those who will be appointed must have business competence or competence in some relevant area of broadcasting and television, or some ability that is useful to the running of a free and independent ABC. On that basis people will be appointed to the Board to carry out the charter that has been established. Senator Button made this point extraordinarily clear in his address on the MPI: The ALP has introduced into the Bill a provision for a community affairs officer to be appointed so that complaints can be dealt with properly within the ABC. That is to be compared with provisions of the Dix report, provisions that the Liberals under Fraser wanted to support.

The MPI is wrongly founded. It attacks the Government; it attacks the implications for the ABC. None of those attacks have been sustained. Senator Button has made the defence par excellence in terms of his role but the role of the ABC in the future is one that the ALP is committed to ensuring is independent and free from interference. That is in marked contrast to the activities of those who have supported the MPI today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHIPP
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance raised by Senator Peter Baume is a political exercise. By saying that I am not being critical at all of Senator Baume or the Liberal Party of Australia. It was a political exercise that was virtually invited by some indiscreet comments made by Senator Button. It is the nature of this chamber and of this place that if an opponent makes an error, even though it might be a small one, one jumps in and tries to score points off it. The matter of public importance before us has two components. One is the preservation of the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and about that ongoing saga of Button v. Kramer which brings one to remember that other saga of Kramer v. Kramer. The Button v. Kramer saga is no less dramatic, no less intense or no less entertaining than its counterpart which was made on film.
—We never had that initial relationship, though, I assure you.

—Those sorts of remarks make me lose my rhythm. I wish Senator Button would desist. Firstly, I will talk about the first component relating to the alleged independence of the ABC. Senator Peter Baume and the Liberal Party are absolutely right in raising this question as often as they can in Opposition because we cannot talk often enough in this place about the preservation of the independence of the ABC. Why? Because Australia has an extraordinary concentration of ownership of the media in so few hands in the private sector. If one takes away the Packers, the Murdochs, the Fairfaxes and the Melbourne Herald group one has very few owners in print, electronic or radio media left in Australia. Therefore, if at any point of time that little quartet becomes fused to a stage when it denies the rights of a political party or a minority group to a fair go then the whole process of democracy is at threat. When Senator Baume talks about the independence of the ABC we are looking at a situation that is so near disaster proportions. If that quartet fused, became one, and became corrupt in a sense that it would deny or distort news, we have only the ABC left in this country upon which to rely for fair reporting. Therefore it is well worth while discussing the matter of public importance that Senator Peter Baume introduced today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the independence of the ABC. How independent is it? In my 23 years as a politician I suppose I could point, with any sort of vivid memory, to five or six times when I have been badly misrepresented by the ABC, which I think is a fantastic average for the ABC and something about which it can be proud. When I look at those incidents closely I concede that some of them were honest errors. All of us who have been to the studios of the ABC here or over in Civic know the pressure of time and space under which the staff members work. If a crisis blows up here at 5 o'clock it is broadcast on national radio with exquisite efficiency one hour later for one million or two million people to hear. Of course there will be errors, and many of those errors will be unconscious errors. There are none more paranoid about themselves than politicians, particularly when they think they either have been misrepresented or are not getting a fair go. Generally speaking, the record of the ABC over the years has been quite outstanding, which of course is no reason for us to become complacent.

I, as one of the many champions of the ABC in this place, have a very high regard for the journalists it employs. Not many of them-if any-are people of my own persuasion, but every time I walk into an ABC studio, whether it is a television or radio studio, I know I am in for a rugged time. I know that I will meet a most efficient, well-informed and very aggressive interviewer, which of course is the very kind of interviewer a politician should want and should appreciate because the milk run interviewer causes the interviewee to perform less efficiently than he or she otherwise may perform. But the sort of aggression in such interviews should not be interpreted as being against the persuasion of the interviewee. Of course, the documentaries that have been made about us as individuals or as parties are never exactly what we want. Why should they be? The documentaries of the ABC quite properly portray us and our political parties warts and all.

The precious independence that the ABC has enjoyed, sometimes notwithstanding the wishes of governments, and the objectivity the ABC has maintained, despite pressure by various governments of both political complexions, are qualities that we ought to maintain. But 'the independence of the ABC' is the sort of phrase that we can pass over almost like a cliche. What does it mean? Does it mean that every member of the staff has to be fair, unbiased? That would be an impossibility. Very few members of the staff of any media enterprise are unbiased and do not have a political point of view. If I were a newspaper editor I do not think I would buy a political neuter as a journalist. I would expect the person to have some sort of bias one way or another, some sort of political philosophy and some sort of gut feeling about issues. Otherwise, that person would not be the kind of journalist I would be looking for.

What would we look for in a journalist? We would look for professional integrity, notwithstanding his or her bias. We would also look to the supervision, management or proprietorship to ensure that objectivity was maintained. How do we get that? Do we appoint unbiased managers of the ABC? That again is an impossibility because of the points I made a moment ago. So we come to the proprietorship, the commissioners, the corporation or the directors-call it what you will; the people who control the staff. We have to look to them to maintain and supervise objectivity. How in the name of goodness do we get independent, objective directors or commissioners of the ABC? It is all very well for the Liberal Party to be critical of Senator Button's or the Australian Labor Party's interference or lack of objectivity. Let Senator Peter Baume nominate one rampant socialist that his Government appointed to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Let us see recorded in Hansard the name of someone with known left wing sympathies. I will not name anyone, but let Senator Peter Baume contemplate how many people of right wing sympathies were appointed by his Government. Let us not kid ourselves. Let us not be pious or hypocritical. Senator Peter Baume and the Liberals should not blame the Labor Government for trying to do something. Notwithstanding that, the ABC has maintained its objectivity and its independence.

I do not know how we can take political interference out of this area. I suppose it is human nature. If the Liberal Party is in government is there any motivation for it to appoint to the Commission a group of left wing socialists who are capable of bias and appointing biased journalists? It is human nature. How do we take out human nature from the appointment of directors or commissioners? One way I suggest, with respect, is by means of a joint party committee. If I may be mildly critical of my friend Senator John Button, I shall quote his letter to the Australian of 8 March 1982. It is a very commendable letter in which he deals with the ALP policy regarding the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Amongst other things, he stated:
The further suggestion in our paper is that the board of directors should be chosen in a bipartisan way.
Applications would be called for publicly and an all-party parliamentary committee would make recommendations to the minister.
In that way, criticism of politically-motivated appointments to the commission would abate.

That proposition is in fact Australian Democrat policy. We can think of no fairer way of removing this danger to objectivity than by means of an all-party committee. Unhappily, the Government has departed from that in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the legislation, but do not assume that we have departed from it.

—I am now more confused than ever, Mr Deputy President. Either the Government has departed from it or it has departed from it in the legislation. I do not see the distinction. I hear Senator Button's point but I do not understand it. Another way, of course, would be to ask electors to elect ABC commissioners at a time at which politicians are elected. The only difficulty with that course is that previous governments have truncated the terms of parliaments. If we had done that we would have had a turn-around of ABC commissioners every two years and five weeks, or whatever the time is. Once we have fixed terms of parliament I think the people ought to be allowed a voice about who should be the commissioners of the ABC. I do not regard that as an impossibility, particularly if by then we have electronic voting.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the second prong of the matter of public importance; that is, the reference to Dame Leonie Kramer. I think she is a woman of remarkable courage, remarkable intellect and untouchable integrity. Leaving aside the subject matter of the Four Corners interview that is in dispute, think of the courage that it must have taken for this woman to say yes, knowing full well that the program would automatically attract at least one or two writs for defamation against the Commission which she administers. In the belief that it was in the public interest to run that program, she agreed to do it. That is the kind of courage I want in the management of the ABC. One can argue whether Dame Leonie has acted a little impulsively since the event, whether she has offered herself for too many ABC or radio interviews or whatever; but certainly one cannot argue against the woman's integrity. When I was Minister for Customs and Excise I had no hesitation in appointing-in fact, I regard it an honour to appoint-this remarkable women to the National Literature Board of Review, where she served with great distinction. What sort of people do we want on the proposed corporation? I genuinely believe that this Government still has the name of Dame Leonie Kramer before it for consideration. I do not think that it will be petty or small minded about this. She is a remarkable Australian. Nothing that Senator Button has said has indicated that the Government is turning its eye against this woman. ''She enjoys controversy,'' says one of her colleagues from the conservative literary magazine Quadrant.

Her rise to power over the past 10 years has coincided with a conservative, right-wing political phase in which the values of elitism and conformity, which she champions, have resurfaced in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -We are discussing this afternoon a matter of public importance raised by my colleague Senator Peter Baume, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to justify charges against the Chairman of the ABC and the implications of this for the future independence of the National Broadcasting Authority.

It is no news to any honourable senator in this chamber, or anybody who is listening, that this has been brought about by some rather flippant or, as Senator Chipp has said, indiscreet remarks by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, in answer to a question asked last week. As a matter of fact, one might well say, at a time when we are discussing whether frozen viruses should be allowed to be kept in the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong, that foot and mouth disease is alive and well in this chamber. We have progressed further down the track than anybody would have imagined when Senator Button offered those flippant remarks. I also say, with some relief, that the terms 'fear and favour' have taken over from the terms ' consensus and reconciliation'. I think we were getting a little sick of those terms. We now have other terms that are high in the vocabulary of the Australian Labor Party.

It is interesting that when the Labor Party was in opposition it twice proposed matters of public importance in the Senate-I believe that they were discussed concurrently in the House of Representatives-once in September 1976 and once in September 1978, about the integrity of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The one proposed by Senator Button in September 1976 was:
The failure of the Government to ensure the independence, integrity and high repute of Australia's National Broadcasting Service.
In May 1978 the matter of public importance was:
The failure of the Government to maintain the independence, objectivity and high standard of national broadcasting.
It is interesting that in May 1978 the then Senator James McClelland took part, as I did, in the debate. Following the then Senator Carrick in the debate, he opened his remarks by saying:

Despite the lofty tone adopted today by the Minister for Education, Senator Carrick, the attitude of the conservative parties towards the Australian Broadcasting Commission can only be described as paranoid.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I put it to you: Who is paranoic about the ABC? The present Government, when in opposition, was paranoic about the ABC. The reports in the Press, including the published letters to and from Professor Dame Leonie Kramer, show that the present Government, particularly Senator Button, is very paranoic about the ABC. As I said, the first of those matters of public importance was raised by Senator Button. In those days the proposer of the motion spoke for 30 minutes. His speech for the entire 30 minutes was taken up in castigating the then Chairman of the Commission, Sir Henry Bland. Nothing else was introduced during his speech at that time. A further interesting thing, upon reflection, was that the debate concerned the fact that Sir Henry Bland had chosen to have the ABC withdraw one episode-my recollection is a little hazy-of the serial Alvin Purple. Senator Button has had some sort of twisted consistency because today we are discussing once again a matter of public importance about a chairman of the ABC. It happens to be the current Chairman, Professor Dame Leonie Kramer. This time the attack is not because of the withdrawal of a program; it is because a program which, for obvious reasons, was repulsive to the ALP was not withdrawn. One can draw conclusions about Senator Button's television tastes. It is interesting that during the debate on the second matter of public importance Senator Ryan, who proposed the motion, made some remarks with regard to the Four Corners program. She is recorded at page 2133 of Senate Hansard of 31 May 1978 to have stated:

The program Four Corners, now in its eighteenth year, was the first to attract controversy because it broke new ground in Australian journalism. It was consistently innovative and I think most honourable senators would agree that it brought depth, maturity and respectability to television journalism.

I suppose most people would say that is what the Four Corners program, which caused all the furore, was all about. I think that most of us, even though we might disagree with some of the Four Corners programs, would agree with Senator Ryan's summation of Four Corners. That summation was made in 1978 and I believe it stands now. Of course, Senator Button disagrees because Four Corners is doing what it set out to do and what Senator Ryan believes it is doing. Surely Four Corners-as I said, even though I and many of my colleagues disagree with some of its programs-is attempting to do all of those things enunciated by Senator Ryan. Another interesting point with regard to Senator Ryan's speech during that debate is that she said:

Only two women are members of the Commission. The Fraser Government introduced an amendment to provide for two women commissioners. One hopes that in future appointments that very small number will be increased and that the interests of women staff members will be reflected in the choice of commissioners.

Of course, the previous Government, I think for the first time in the history of the ABC, appointed a woman Chairman of that Commission. I think honourable senators of every political persuasion in this chamber will agree that Professor Dame Leonie Kramer is a remarkable woman. Yet, because she exercised her right as Chairman to sit back and let the current affairs journalists do their job and put to air a program that did not meet with the best wishes of the ALP she has been criticised and castigated in this place. That has happened because the Commission did precisely what it was set up to do. The sequence of events has been discussed by my colleagues during the debate today. But it is worth repeating the point at which the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) bought into the subject. Of course, honourable senators will recall that it concerned an interview with the then Prime Minister, the Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser. It has been brought out in Professor Dame Leonie Kramer's reply to Senator Button that this occurred not at a Press conference but during a telephone interview between Parliament House and the Lodge. Part of Professor Dame Leonie Kramer's letter states:

The transcript clearly reveals that Ms O'Neil did not ask a question relating to the President of the United States, but made an aside about him to which Mr Fraser elected to respond. Having myself heard the recording of the interview, I did not form the impression that Mr Fraser had difficulty in developing his remarks. It is a fact, as you say, that Ms O'Neil was telephoned by senior officers of her department, who warned her to be careful about asides in interviews. This was not an unreasonable caution at the start of a campaign in which the ABC saw itself as having to be particularly careful to be even-handed.

All those who have had anything to do with the ABC during an election campaign would agree that it bends over backwards, almost too much, to try to be even handed. A government has no chance of getting on an ABC program if the opposition has not had the same amount of air time. Once again, I disagree with the ABC's version of even handedness. I instance as a criticism-I will not ring up Professor Kramer and go crook-the two Four Corners programs on which the three interviewers interviewed first Mr Hawke and secondly Mr Fraser. They almost handed Mr Hawke marshmallows, the questions were so mild. When it came to Mr Fraser I had never seen such unabashed and unashamed confrontation and hostility to a person in any interview on any television program anywhere in the world. That is my criticism. Be that as it may, members of the Liberal Party never rang the ABC saying: 'You had better ease off'. That is because we accept the role of the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a load of rubbish and you know it.
—The point I am making is that we criticise but we do not interfere as Mr Hawke did. Professor Kramer went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: You then refer to those aspects of this incident which are 'not a matter of public knowledge'. Again, your recollection is at variance with the facts. It was not you who raised this matter with me, but Mr Hawke. He telephoned me on 8 February 1983, and having informed me that you were present, proceeded to register his displeasure at certain aspects of the program of 4 February 1983.
In referring to Ms O'Neil's comment, and the rebuke she received, he remarked that a member of the AM staff 'had ties with the Liberal Party'-
My colleague Senator Peter Baume quite effectively dealt with that matter in his opening remarks-
and criticised the senior officer who spoke to Ms O'Neil, adding, 'this warrants a change'. Mr Hawke then said, 'I'm damned if I'm going to put up quietly with this situation.'

Not only was a criticism made in public but also a rebuke-it was more than a veiled threat-was given over the phone to the Chairman of the Commission. Professor Kramer then went on to point out very vividly that she had never brought this matter to public light. She said that she had tried to remain even handed as Chairman of the Commission. She said:

I think you should know that great care was taken to keep the source of the complaint confidential, so as not to give rise to any suspicion within the ABC or outside it, that Mr Hawke and you were trying to influence its internal affairs, particularly during an election period.

Members of the Liberal and National Parties disagree with the points of some of the programs and the way in which some of the programs are handled. What concerns me and my colleagues in the Opposition is the fact that the structure of the ABC is about to be changed. That has been legislated for. Attitudes such as those of the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, are prevalent, and those who hold them are quite unashamed of them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has laid a charge in the matter of public importance which is raised today that somehow the remarks of Senator Button last week placed the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in some sort of jeopardy. I say quite frankly and honestly that I have listened to the debate as objectively as possible, and I assert that the Opposition has failed absolutely to forge any such link between Senator Button's remarks and the future integrity and independence of the ABC. It has failed dismally. It has been shameless in its raising of this matter of public importance. The charge comes very ill from a former government which only last year conceived and brought into this Parliament legislation concerning the ABC which provided for a monstrous, censorious creature under the title commissioner for complaints. It comes doubly ill from the proposer of this matter of public importance, as I will demonstrate.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation, brought in last year by the now Opposition, contained a proposal to establish a censor on the ABC. From where did this proposal emanate? It did not come from the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. That independent inquiry spent many months travelling around Australia. It took evidence from all those who wished to participate in that review of the ABC and the creation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, in which we can all take pride. After months of travelling around the country and after hearing many hours of evidence and submissions, the Dix committee proposed not a commissioner for complaints with draconian powers to force people under threat of heavy fine or imprisonment, to incriminate themselves; it merely concluded that the community affairs officer could handle such complaints as were made. But the then Government decided that it would create this censorious commissioner for complaints.

What did the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills have to say of this proposal? This Committee was established by the Senate, as is well known, in order to protect the liberties of Australians. The thirteenth report to the Senate in September 1982 of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-a bi-partisan committee, let it be added-alerted senators, in that restrained and formal language which is its custom, to its view that certain powers to be vested in the commissioner for complaints might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties. It went on to question the severity of the penalties to be imposed, such as a $1,000 fine or imprisonment for three months for refusing to comply with directions given by the commissioner. We also found that the Bill introduced by the former government in relation to the ABC reversed the onus of proof in many serious aspects. Once again this drew comment from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee which this chamber established in order to help us to protect more effectively the rights and liberties of Australians.

What did the Chairman of the British Broadcasting Corporation have to say of this proposal and its colouring of the whole legislation which the then Government brought to this chamber last year? He saw clear-sightedly enough what it indicated about the present Opposition's attitude to the ABC. Speaking, I believe, in an interview with the media in Australia, he made a statement to the effect that the legislation was so discriminatory and horrifying to a man of his sensibilities and in light of the traditions of the BBC that employees of the ABC ought to pack their bags and go home rather than be employed under those conditions. There we had it-a proposal brought to this chamber last year by the now Opposition concerning the ABC which was spoken of in such terms by the then chairman of the BBC concerning a matter which, as I have said, did not emanate from the Dix Committee report. It must have come from some dark and musty room in the confines of the government corridors of this place. Who was the Minister who then represented the Minister for Communications in this place? Who was the Minister who introduced that legislation with those terrible effects-it was spoken of in those terms-into this chamber and justified and defended it in his second reading speech? Why, it was the very shadow Minister who today raised this matter of public importance, Senator Peter Baume. It comes very ill from his lips to mount this sort of attack.

I do not think there is any need for the full derision of this chamber to be visited solely on Senator Peter Baume because it was the Liberal-National Party of Australia coalition as a whole which, with a few honourable exceptions within the confines of the party room, did so much to seek to undermine the independence and integrity of the ABC in the last seven years of office. It sought to sap the strength and the resolve of the ABC to produce, so fearlessly, as it does, and with as much expertise as it can command, its news gathering and news distributing programs and its current affairs programs which are of such excellent quality. The Opposition sought to do that; it sought to undermine that ability but it never quite succeeded.

This charge is not merely made by me as a member of the Australian Labor Party. It can be found in the forty-eigthth annual report of the Australian Broadcasting Commission which was presented in this chamber. Senator Cook ably pointed out in his contribution this afternoon that nothing is more threatening to the viability, integrity and independence of the ABC in gathering and relaying news and its ability to conduct and present public affairs programs, exposing and highlighting areas of life and of national interest which are of concern to us all, than starving it of the funds it needs to carry out that task which we wish it to carry out to the maximum of its ability. We have found that in the years when the Opposition held power over the purse strings of the ABC constraints were placed on its funds and personnel. These were meant, I believe, to lead to an allocation of resources away from the areas of news gathering and public affairs programs, which are, of course, the core of its independence in our national lives.
The forty-eighth annual report of the ABC to Mr Staley, then then Minister for Communications, stated:
The Commission recorded its view that the ABC has carried an unreasonably heavy burden in this matter.
That relates to staffing. It continued:
Public Service Board figures reveal that staff reductions in the ABC are running at significantly higher levels than the proportion within the Public Service . . .

The imposition of staff ceilings is clearly in conflict with section 43 (2) of the Broadcasting and Television Act, which states 'the Commission shall appoint such other officers and engage such temporary employees as it thinks necessary'.

It is quite clear that the former Government, in setting staff ceilings at an unrealistically low level, was preventing the Commission from appointing those employees which were necessary for the discharge of its functions. In relation to finance and funding, the Commission, at the end of 1980, stated:

For the past five years the Commission has received from the Government continually smaller amounts, measured at constant prices, with which to provide programs for the national radio and television service . . .
The falling real income of the ABC has prevented the Commission from maintaining former levels of output, regardless of any wish to extend and improve services.

That was the tone of the report that year. What a cry and a plea to come from the commissioners of the ABC. It was not listened to by this Opposition which had the hide to bring this matter of public importance before the chamber this afternoon. In fact, in the middle of 1981 the cries from the ABC commissioners became more well known to the general public as the then Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Mr John Norgard, felt obliged to go public in June of that year with the claim that Canberra had broken its pledge on funding of the ABC. One recalls that famous letter to the National Times of 14 June 1981 written by Robyn Williams, Huw Evans, Norman May, James Dibble, Tim Bowden, Paul Murphy, Peter Manning, Gary Scully, Julie Rigg, Robyn Ravlich, all well known to the Australian public as broadcasters. It stated:
Sir, What can be done to save the ABC?
Make no mistake about it, the future of the organisation is in grave jeopardy due to the punitive financial treatment it is receiving from the Federal Government.

Indeed, that was one of the conclusions of the independent Dix committee a few days later. The conclusion of that independent inquiry was, amongst other things , that there was no question that cuts in staff funding and consequent staff shortages had adversely affected the ABC over recent years. There we have it. There is no doubt that the record is very plain that the Opposition, when in Government, sought to so constrain the funds available to the ABC that the allocation of resources to enable it to maintain its independence and integrity as a news gathering and public affairs programmer was very seriously put in jeopardy.
In contrast to all this the platform of the Australian Labor Party, under the heading 'National Broadcasting', states among other things:
The ABC is to be funded by parliamentary appropriations with no advertising or corporate underwriting, to a level necessary to establish the ABC as a great national broadcasting institution.
Again, it states:
Maintenance of an independent adequately funded ABC National News gathering operation and separately organised Public Affairs service without reliance on any commercial domestic news service.

One can reveal-although I think it is well known-that the author of that commitment to adequate funding to enable the ABC to maintain its independence and integrity was Senator Button who, as shadow Minister for Communications over the two years immediately preceding our coming to Government, so strenuously argued for and put forward schemes and plans to enable the ABC, under its new structure, to maintain its independence and integrity. That is why the raising of this matter of public importance has been such a miserable failure. The man whom it is meant to embarrass, the man whose words, spoken publicly in this place, not in some dark and murky corridor of power, are said to have signalled some assault on the independence of the ABC, is renowned in this chamber and, dare I say, in the community at large as the man who laboured most over the last couple of years, as the shadow Minister for Communications, to ensure that a new structure would emerge for the ABC which would ensure its independence and integrity.

I believe that the House of Representatives this evening-certainly the Senate over the next few weeks-will debate the Bill introduced by this Government. It will be given its fullest airing. It is a Bill which all respectable and responsible commentators have applauded. It is a Bill which we intend will provide that charter of independence for the ABC which is required. Clause 6 of the proposed Bill, which sets out the charter of the corporation, amongst other things states:
The Corporation shall take account of-

The responsibility of the Corporation as the provider of an independent national broadcasting and television service to provide a balance between broadcasting programs and television programs of wide appeal and specialized broadcasting programs and television programs;
There is a clause dealing with the duties of the Board. This Government has written into the legislation which is before this Parliament the words:
It is the duty of the Board-
To maintain the independence and integrity of the Corporation;
To ensure that the gathering and presentation by the Corporation of news and information is accurate and impartial according to the recognized standards of objective journalism;

There, I believe, lies the final answer to this matter of public importance raised so shamelessly by the Opposition. This Government, within a few weeks of assuming office and within a few sitting days of this Parliament being brought together by the Governor-General, introduced a Bill which will guarantee the independence of the ABC. In this chamber only a few weeks ago the Governor- General told the assembled parliamentarians:
You will be asked to consider legislation to establish the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to give the ABC a clear charter, a modern structure and effective, businesslike management.

I assert that that is what the legislation which is now before the Parliament embodies. As I say, given the reputation and renown in which Senator Button is held as a fervent advocate of the independence, impartiality and integrity of the ABC, there is no doubt that in its new structure, in the way devised and put forward in the Bill, we will ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will enjoy in the future the reputation which it has so richly deserved in the past.
