DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: First Report on Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietman Veterans- Government Response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GIETZELT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment presented its first report on Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans to Parliament on 25 November 1982. The Government believes this is a helpful report of the Senate on the health of Vietnam veterans based on the then available evidence. It is clear to the Government, however, that there still remains considerable uncertainty in the minds of some Vietnam veterans and many observers about possible effects of exposure to toxic chemicals in Vietnam on the mental and physical health and well-being of themselves and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that the only way that these issues can be answered to the satisfaction of the people directly concerned is to establish a royal commission to inquire fully into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on Vietnam veterans and any problems faced by them and their families. I will be announcing the details of that royal commission soon. Action planned as a result of a number of the recommendations made by the Senate Committee should help to improve the services provided by the Government to Vietnam veterans and veterans generally.

The Government has considered the 18 recommendations in the Senate Committee's report and has prepared responses to them. One of the recommendations was that the case-control study on birth-defects among the children of Vietnam veterans, undertaken by the Commonwealth Institute of Health, be completed as soon as possible. This study has since been completed and the results were released by the then Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, on 20 February 1983. I tabled a copy of the report in the Senate this morning. Its primary finding was that there is no evidence that Army service in Vietnam increased the risk of fathering a malformed child. This, of course, will be considered and further investigated by the proposed royal commission.

Briefly, the Government's responses to the Senate Committee's recommendations on the handling and use of pesticides and the health of Vietnam veterans are: The Department of Defence will shortly disseminate widely within the Defence Force a new manual on the safe handling, storage and use of pesticides; the promotion of understanding among the scientific and medical communities of heritable genetic effects from exposure to certain chemicals will be referred to the National Health and Medical Research Council for recommendations on action to be taken; and the nature and origin of birth defects will be included in public education programs promoted by the Commonwealth Department of Health. The Government has decided that the Commonwealth Institute of Health should proceed with a limited scientifically-based neuropsychiatric investigation among Vietnam veterans. The CIH is charged with the responsibility of proceeding with this study and reporting to the royal commission by early 1984.

The Senate Committee recommended that a morbidity study should proceed with due emphasis being placed on attempting to establish whether psychiatric symptoms in Vietnam veterans are due to a war neurosis or exposure to harmful chemicals. The Government has decided that the morbidity study should not proceed, given the time and expense obviously involved and the need of the royal commission to consider the health problems of Vietnam veterans. As I mentioned already, there will be a neuropsychiatric investigation by the Commonwealth Institute of Health .

The Senate Committee recommended an examination of the way in which repatriation determining authorities apply evidentiary provisions of the legislation. Following a recent re-organisation of the top structure of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the decisions of determining authorities are now being regularly monitored by the Department of Veterans' Affairs to ensure that the legislation is applied correctly; and more effort is being given to ensuring that these authorities fully comprehend and act upon court and tribunal decisions which deal with the onus provisions under the repatriation legislation .

The Committee recommended that the proposed remodelling of the repatriation claims system be undertaken as a matter of urgency. The Government agrees that this is desirable. A priority task is to minimise claims-handling delays, many of which are outside departmental control. As a positive step in reducing the times taken in processing claims, in areas where the Department can help speed up the process, additional staff have been provided to permit the introduction of a new system of delegates of the Repatriation Commission with the power to accept, but not reject, claims. This system should reduce the investigation work load and eliminate the need for referral to Repatriation Boards of straightforward claims for acceptance. The Department has already introduced in all States a system for the fast processing of claims and appeals in cases where normal processing would lead to unreasonable hardship. Other initiatives to minimise delays in the claims investigation process will be sought on a continuing basis. The Government will give urgent consideration to proposals by the Administrative Review Council when they are received.

As a further step to assist veterans living outside the metropolitan area, the Department of Veterans' Affairs has implemented the Telecom Inward Wide Area Telephone Service-INWATS-system on a trial basis in Queensland. This system allows a country veteran to call the branch office in Brisbane for the price of a local call. The effectiveness of the system will be reviewed after six months with a view to making the system permanent in Queensland and in other States. The Department will also implement a program to increase the knowledge of doctors in its local medical officer scheme of the repatriation system and related matters.

The Committee made several recommendations on the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service which advises veterans and their families on their problems. Since the first counselling centre was opened in January 1982, the VVCS has been collecting data on work load and basic statistical information about clients and their problems. The National Advisory Committee, which advises the Minister on the VVCS, has commenced an evaluation of its services, staffing and administration. Long term needs of the counselling service will depend upon the demand made upon it by Vietnam veterans and their families. New centres are to be opened in Townsville and Canberra and the staff numbers at Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth will be increased. Once the evaluation of the VVCS has been completed, the Government will decide on the extent to which the service should be maintained and developed.

The Committee recommended that the Department of Veterans' Affairs maintain statistical data relating to veterans in prison. The Department has no such data and the data are not available elsewhere. Since prisons are primarily a State responsibility, the then Acting Primary Minister wrote to the State Premiers on 10 January 1983 seeking their agreement to discussions between the Department and prison authorities. So far the responses received have been favourable. Nevertheless, the Government believes that this matter now comes within the purview of the proposed royal commission on Vietnam veterans. Another recommendation was that the VVCS provide services to veterans in prison. The Government supports this in principle but, again, the custody and welfare of prisoners are primarily State matters. Access by veterans in prison to the VVCS was raised with State Premiers by the then Acting Prime Minister in his letter of 10 January last and so far assurances of co-operation have been received from all States which have replied.

The Department has reviewed its data collection system and is planning to develop a computerised epidemiological index in all States, on a prospective basis but with selective retrospective data collection, in response to a Committee recommendation along these lines. In evidence to the Senate Committee, the Vietnam Veterans' Action Association made a number of charges against the Department of Veterans' Affairs relating to the unco-operative attitude of staff towards Vietnam veterans and delays in processing claims. The Department has investigated claims of rudeness by departmental staff and found that there is no clear evidence that staff had been unhelpful or rude, either deliberately or otherwise, to the veterans concerned. But the Department recognises the need for special arrangements to deal with veterans' complaints and inquiries. The Department is introducing a Customer Liaison Service in all States which will monitor customer relations, implement training and education programs to ensure that high standards of ace to face dealings with clients are maintained, and provide a focal point for complaints and inquiries and ensure that these are handled promptly.

The initiatives outlined in my statement, which are covered in detail in the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee report, are consistent with the Government's resolve to assist Vietnam veterans and their families with their health and social problems. The Government has further underlined this resolve by announcing its intention to establish the royal commission. I present the following paper:
Government's response to the first report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I welcome the statement made in the chamber this afternoon. It expresses the response of the Government to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment report entitled 'Pesticides and the Health of Australian Vietnam Veterans'. I think it is worth commenting that this report certainly signifies the capacity of a standing committee of the Senate to come to grips with a major problem, to carry out successfully and responsibly an in-depth examination of that problem and to produce recommendations which can be only of service to the Government and the Australian people-and, in this case, particularly Australian Vietnam veterans. I believe that there was an occasion when it was doubted in some areas whether a committee such as this could make a useful and proper contribution on a problem which so many Australians were well and truly aware of . I believe that the report of this Committee indicates quite clearly that it can make and has made a useful and proper contribution on this matter. It is a contribution that is of value to the Parliament, the Government and the Australian people. As I said, it is particularly pleasing in view of the doubts that have been expressed from time to time as to the capacity of such a commitee to do this sort of thing effectively.

Of course, there are always some unanswered problems in any investigation. One can only hope that the matters that still remain to be sought out in this particular area can be successfully covered by the proposed royal commission. If it can contribute to the ultimate solution of these problems it will have been worth while. One thing is clearly evident; that is, the contribution of the Senate Standing Committee in its inquiry must be of significant aid to the royal commission when it begins its investigation. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) noted that the action planned as a result of recommendations should help services to Vietnam veterans and, indeed, veterans generally. One can only agree with that. A study by the Commonwealth Institute of Health which was instigated some time ago by the previous Government has been completed. It revolved around the problem of birth defects. Its findings were that as yet there is no evidence that birth defects are greater in the case of Vietnam veterans or of people who have served in Vietnam than they are in the case of those who have served elsewhere.

The recommendations which the Government highlights and which are to be implemented include: Firstly, that concerning the Department of Defence manual on safe handling, storage and use of pesticides; secondly, the promotion of an understanding of inheritable genetic effects of chemicals being referred to the National Health and Medical Research Council; and, thirdly, the nature and origin of birth defects being included in public education by the Department of Health. These are all substantial and important areas to be covered. I am pleased that the Commonwealth Institute of Health investigation into neuro- psychiatric circumstances among Vietnam veterans is in fact to be continued and, as I read it, to be reported upon by early 1984. I am not quite sure what meaning should be given to the word 'limited'. The Minister may be able to give us some indication. I think it is a matter of regret that the other investigation in train, into morbidity, is to be discontinued. I assume that its findings would be just as important to the royal commission in its research into the problems of health related to pesticides and chemicals in Vietnam as would the findings in the neuro-psychiatric area.

The problem of prisoners, their health and their mental state, has been improved quite significantly by what is clearly close co-operation by the State authorities involved, the Vietnam veterans and the Department. The Customer Liaison Service is a useful and proper response to what was deemed to be a very definite need in the relationship between the Vietnam veterans and the Department. I can only say, as I said earlier, that I am pleased that the Minister has brought down this government response promptly. I believe that it is a constructive and proper response to a very excellent and in-depth observation by the Standing Committee involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment I wish to make only a couple of comments on the response by the Government to that Committee's report, brought down in November 1982. In doing so one has to trace back through the history of the Committee-its establishment, the preparation of its report and its request for a response to it. In November 1982 the Committee brought down its report, in which it made 17 recommendations. It sought from the former Government a response to its recommendations by, at the latest, 31 March 1983. But, as every honourable senator knows, history caught up with the Committee's request.
—And the Minister.

—History certainly caught up with the then Government. As every honourable senator knows, there was an election on 5 March. Little did we members of the Committee realise when we were writing recommendations and seeking a response by the Government by 31 March 1983 that we would be getting a response from a Labor government after an election on 5 March. However, we are again in the Senate chamber. I believe that the response which has been given by the Government is very reasonable and responsible and has been given at the earliest possible date. The requests in the recommendations of the Committee certainly have been met to a great extent in the Government's response.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes without saying that people such as Senator Jessop, the then Chairman of the Committee, ex-Senator Mulvihill-in fact, every member of the Committee- worked very hard to bring down a responsible report which sought from the Government responses that would help in some way to settle the problems suffered by Vietnam veterans. I think the Committee worked very hard towards seeking non- political responses. I see that the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs is nodding his head in agreement. I believe that, even from his point of view, there was a certain amount of co-operation between the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the Minister and the Committee to try to make available an accurate report which argued the case of Vietnam veterans and got for them the best response possible from the government of the day. I believe that that was what the Committee set out to do. I believe that we have that sort of response from the present Government.

The report entitled 'Case-Control Study of Congenital Anomalies and Vietnam Service (Birth Defects Study)' that was tabled this morning by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) was brought down by the previous Minister for Veterans' Affairs prior to the opening of this Parliament. That report, together with the report of the Committee, the transcript of evidence taken by the Committee and the Committee's findings will be of great assistance to the present Government in setting up a royal commission and making available to the commission the evidence and points of view of some of the people who came before the Committee and gave evidence, I believe, in a non-political way. There is not a great deal that I can say on the Government's response at this stage. The Government has stated that it will go ahead with a royal commission. I believe the Committee now has a responsibility to look in detail at the Government's response and to make a further statement to the Senate in relation to that response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) and the new Government for bringing in its first major response to a Senate committee report-in this case its response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. If the Government responds with such alacrity and such detail to subsequent Senate committee reports I think the enourmous amount of work that senators put into those reports will certainly be seen by them as being much more worth while than has often been the case in the past. The Senate Committee's report, of course, was received with some controversy within the veteran community, in particular members of the Vietnam veteran community, who felt that many items that they had brought forward had not been dealt with in the way in which they would have liked. I had some other critical comments to make when the report was tabled last year.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I wish to confine my remarks basically to the Government's response, in particular to those items relating to the Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Government's willingness to seek a new manual on the safe handling, storage and use of pesticides is long overdue, within not only the Department of Defence but all government departments, at both the Commonwealth and the State levels. Increasingly we are coming to understand within the community that pesticides not only are of assistance to society but also can cause enormous cumulative damage. We need much more detailed information about the handling, storage and use of pesticides. Certainly Commonwealth employees should be operating under a relatively rigid manual of operation.

Whilst there still exists within the community a relatively low level of knowledge about the long-lasting effects of many pesticides, sometimes it is very difficult, particularly in the tropical parts of this country, to convince people that they must have adequate protection; in other words, that they must wear gloves, protective clothing and masks, if necessary, when using particular pesticides. This is very difficult as many people using those pesticides are inclined to say: 'It is only a spray; it can't hurt me'. The Government is to be commended for seeking to ensure that at least Commonwealth employees are adequately protected by the new manual. I believe that the Government's initiative in seeking to disseminate, through the Commonwealth Department of Health, more information to the public on the nature and origins of birth defects is to be welcomed for the same reason. We hope that the general community will take more care in the use of these pesticides, many of which are necessary and desirable.

The last point that I wish to raise, although I do not wish to detract from the Government's response in all areas, is the point made in the Minister's tabling statement in regard to additional staff that will be provided for the new system of delegates to the Repatriation Commission. These delegates will have the power to accept, but not reject, claims. This proposition is one which I have been putting forward for quite some time and I know it is a propostion which many members of various veterans' assocations have been canvassing. I think the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs will be speaking on this matter later. I believe this suggestion was one which he may have had a hand in implementing.

I am not sure of the time frame; possibly Senator Messner can clarify that. Certainly the previous Minister instituted the fast lane system, of which this is one aspect. I hope that in the not too distant future the new Minister for Veterans' Affairs may be able to inform the Senate of the operation of the fast lane system and, indeed, of whether the Repatriation Commission is actually getting over its still undesirable backlog of claims. Certainly the notion of the Repatriation Commission having delegates, or even the Department of Veterans ' Affairs accepting claims and rejecting only the ones which are controversial is a necessary element. I hope that the Minister will proceed further with the other suggestion I have made; that is, to have groups of veterans' claims made automatic when they fall under certain designations. I believe we have sufficient material now within the Department-certainly within the computerisation of the data within the Department-to know which claims under which headings are likely to be accepted no matter what system we use. If we look at the claims that are upheld at the tribunal level we get an even clearer view of the fact that certain groups will eventually have their claims upheld. I believe that the cost that is currently involved in taking many of those claims through every level-that is through the Department, through the Repatriation Commission, through appeals and through the Tribunal-could well be avoided with savings to the Budget of this country rather than costs by making automatic many of these claims. I believe that that type of notion is probably one which can be best dealt with in the general review of the Repatriation Act. On behalf of my own State I add that Queenslanders are grateful that the Government has moved for the opening of new centres, in Townsville in particular, which were proposed by the previous Government and which have now come much closer to fruition with the additional staff in Brisbane. However, there is still one outstanding point that I believe it is necessary to address; that is, the possibility of additional travelling entitlements to the staff in Brisbane. Their travelling entitlements are currently severely limited. They generally run out of entitlements very early in the financial year. I believe that the staff ought to have wider travelling entitlements to enable them to undertake very important trips, not only at their own behest but also-as occurs everywhere in Australia- at the behest of many other groups in the community. I will give an instance in Queensland. The police requested the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service in Brisbane to attend a domestic situation which had developed which could have resulted ultimately in the loss of life. The police felt unable to deal with it and they requested that a counsellor from the counselling service should attend. He did so, but he had to use his own car at his own expense. This situation seems to me to be absurd.

These people are professionals. There is a demand for their services. They can be trusted in an extremely delicate situation not to abuse their entitlements. I believe that if we look around this Parliament we will see that many of our staff and many staff attached to ministerial offices and other parts of the Department have unlimited travelling allowances. It seems to me the least we can offer to the veterans in this country is to provide an equal entitlement to those professionals who are engaged in this extremely important task.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly welcome the Government's response to the report of the former Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I would like to add to what Senator Jones has said with respect to the help given to the Committee by former Senator Mulvihill who was the Deputy Chairman. I am sure his assistance in getting over some difficulties with respect to the report was appreciated by us all. This, of course, resulted in a unanimous expression of opinion in the report. We regarded it as quite a significant report because of the emotional effect that agent orange was having on Vietnam veterans and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: We pointed to the need for further scientific and statistical evidence to be produced dealing with the morbidity of certain diseases within the group of veterans who served in Vietnam. That is why I am a little concerned that the Government is not going ahead with the morbidity study. I think it is very important to establish a pattern of incidence of diseases among these people. I am anxious to learn as soon as possible the terms of reference of the royal commission. I do not think it can come to any positive conclusions without the scientific evidence that we have requested. That is the reason why the committee presented its first report. It would have been its intention to proceed following further evidence presented as a result of neuro-psychiatric investigations and the morbidity study. However, I understand that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) will very shortly be presenting the Senate with the terms of reference associated with the royal commission. I look forward to examining those.

It was interesting for me to read the report of the Commonwealth Institute of Health which largely substantiated some comments that we made with respect to birth deformities. I notice that the Minister has referred to that matter. On 20 February this year Senator Messner released a report, which concluded:
. . . there is no evidence that Army service in Vietnam has increased the risk of the birth of a child with an anomaly.

There is a lot of ignorance among the community concerning genetic effects as a result of exposure to pesticides and herbicides. That is why the Committee asked the Government to provide an educational program which would inform people more adequately. I am pleased to see that the Minister has indicated that this is a possibility. It will be a great help if we can get the message through as to the causes and effects of exposure to these pesticides and the possible risk to the foetus. I certainly welcome the Government's responce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this discussion briefly to make a couple of comments relating to the response by the Government. I am pleased to see that the Government has kept almost to the timetable that we requested. The interruption caused by the election made it more difficult for the Government and the Department of Veterans' Affairs to respond. I am also pleased to see the number of recommendations that have been accepted by the Government. I have been a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment when it has put in other reports that have not had so many recommendations accepted. I do not believe this is due to the change of government; I just believe that we were given some very good advice and help on this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I was one of the few people on the Committee with any sort of scientific background. It took me quite a while to understand the nature and cause of birth defects. The matter is fairly complicated. The point that should be emphasised once again is that it is usually the female who has to be exposed to the causative agent, usually at a very critical time during pregnancy. We have all heard of thalidomide. For that drug to take effect it had to be taken and be present in the mother at a certain very short period of the pregnancy. I believe it was only a matter of days. If it were taken at any other time it could not have had any effect. The point I would like to make quite clear to the wives of Vietnam veterans is that in my opinion they should have absolutely no worry about having children. I think that when anybody has a child who is deformed in one way or another they always look for some other reason than themselves for the cuase. They would like to blame something else. But throughout the human species a statistical number of defects will occur in every so many thousand births. It is quite evident from the information we were given that the number of any deformities or whatever in Vietnam veterans' children would be exactly the same as the number in the rest of the community.

If we did nothing other than put that matter to rest I believe the work we did on the Senate Committee was very worth while. It was an important matter, a major problem, and it certainly needed examination. We even found some confusion among some people who were giving us advice as to the cause of defects. It was quite surprising to hear some of the people who came before us as witnesses, people who held reasonably high positions. They just did not understand the situation at all. I am pleased to see in I think, the second response in this statement that the Government recognises that much more attention has to be paid by Australian scientific and medical communities to promoting an understanding of the heritable genetic effects that may result from exposure of humans to mutagenic chemicals. I repeat that it has to be the female who is exposed, not the male.

But one has to remember too that a lot of chemicals within Australia could cause trouble to people if they do not realise how dangerous the chemicals are. As a pharmacist I have had to deal with poisons quite often. One comes to recognise the danger from contact with just very minute quantities of certain substances. When one realises the danger of incorrect use of some of the garden sprays that are relatively easily attainable, I would support quite solidly any education that can be given either to the general community or, particularly, to people who have to handle these substances. I am pleased to see that the Government is doing this.

I want to raise just one other matter. I am not sure-I think I have said this before-that the money being spent on the royal commission will be well spent. I believe the royal commission will most probably come back to the Government at some stage and say: 'We need more information. We do not have enough scientific studies at our disposal'. I believe the money that is to be spent on the royal commission would be much better spent on research throughout the universities, even with special direction from the Government. I have always thought that there should be some direction as to how university money is spent, particularly on matters such as this. I think the money that is going to the royal commission , which will most probably run into millions of dollars over the time of the commission, would be much better spent on examination and research into this whole matter of pesticides and their effects. I know that members of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia have called for a royal commission for a long time but I do not think it will be the answer to their problem either. I think they would be much better off by letting that money be spent in other ways, and that is an opinion from which I do not think I will be easily dissuaded.

Senator Macklin mentioned that there is a need for money, particularly in his large State, to help people in the Department of Veterans' Affairs to travel to help the veterans-not only the veterans of Vietnam but also some of the other veterans who are now getting very old and need a lot more help than they are presently getting. I hope the Government does insist, as it says it will, on helping the Department to put on a more human face. The Government has not said that in those words but that is what I would like to see the Department do. It is a bit frightening for many people, as they get older, when they have to go to a department and they are met by somebody who is not their age. Usually the veteran is a lot older than the person who is looking after him. I think it is very bad if our veterans are not looked after in a pleasant manner.

Those are the only comments I feel I have to make. Of course, I have only just received this Government response. At this stage I would again like to thank Senator Mulvihill. I think he attended just about every Committee meeting we had . As he is no longer a member of this chamber and I think I am sitting in the seat he used to occupy I will try to treat my work on the Senate Committee in the way he would want me to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this response from the Government on the problems of Vietnam veterans and, in particular, the response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment. I might say that had the events of 5 March not changed situations I could very well have brought down the same report as the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, has brought down today. I think the responses included therein certainly are bipartisan, as I think Senator Macklin pointed out to us. In a sense I suppose we could call them tripartisan.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is some need for comment on one or two of the issues raised in the course of Senator Gietzelt's remarks, especially the reference to the establishment of the royal commission. There is no detail in this statement about the terms of reference, the nature of the inquiry or, or course, the people who will be undertaking it. In particular, I would be most concerned to know who will be the royal commissioner or commissioners and who will be the consultants and other people who will be advising the commission on detailed scientific matters from time to time. I think it is of the greatest importance in relation to this issue that justice be done to Vietnam veterans. I believe that would be best served by ensuring that the highest quality scientific people are made available to the commissioner-not only those of quality but also those who might be described as being independent of any group that has taken an interest in this matter until now. I think it is vital at this stage of the game that we have a proper, independent unbiased treatment of the material that has come forward either from sources already identified in Senator Gietzelt's remarks or from other sources which no doubt the commissioner will be seeking from the wider community.

As is well known, the former Government did oppose the establishment of a royal commission in respect of this problem of Vietnam veterans. Senator Townley drew our attention to that problem area and made the point that some of the resources that might now be found to support the establishment of a royal commission could be better used for direct assistance and alleviation of the problems of Vietnam veterans. I believe that is a legitimate point to make. Nevertheless, the Government has made its decision and no doubt we will hear more about that in the not too distant future. Another point to make about why the former Government did not proceed to establish a royal commission is that, in fact, we believed that the royal commission would not achieve its result-that is, determination of the issue of health problems of Vietnam veterans-without receiving and examining very detailed scientific evidence. It seems clear that without that evidence a firm decision would not be reached by any royal commissioner.

I think it is rather significant that in the course of Senator Gietzelt's remarks he admitted that a further neuro-psychiatric investigation of Vietnam veterans would need to be undertaken and presented to the royal commissioner in order for that issue to be settled. I think this makes the point which was made by the former Government that the royal commission, in itself, will probably resolve nothing without its having the full scientific support of studies that are, of course, currently in train or which perhaps still need to be set up and undertaken. Contrary to that point, I am interested to see that the Government has decided not to continue the morbidity study which was in the early stages of development by the Commonwealth Institute of Health in Sydney. No reasons are given for that but it does seem to be somewhat inconsistent with the approach evidenced in the earlier paragraphs of Senator Gietzelt's remarks which indicate that he is establishing another scientific study which will report to the royal commission. However, apparently the morbidity study is not deemed important or necessary and consequently the Institute will not be reporting to the royal commission. I wonder what is the Government's intention in this area. In the final analysis how will it settle the questions of health problems of Vietnam veterans if a properly established scientific examination is not undertaken?

For those reasons, I am just a little concerned about what might be expected from the royal commission. However, I hasten to add that one of the most significant things that may yet be unfolded in the whole vexed area of the problems of Vietnam veterans may very well be the results of scientific inquiries being undertaken overseas, in particular, in the United States of America among the veterans of the Vietnam War. Those inquiries may provide us with more information on these questions and will go a long way towards answering the questions which are in the minds of Australians. Nevertheless, it is well known that those inquiries will take some time before coming to fruition .

The best result that Australian veterans can expect will be from the successful conclusion of the scientific examinations that can be undertaken in this country . For that reason I commend the Government for its response to the Senate Committee report which, as Senator Jones rightly pointed out, was bipartisan. It did reflect very clearly a broad view of the problem without taking political considerations into account. Consequently, I believe it is a very fair analysis of the problem and the Committee's final statement is a very fair view of the examination of the problems of Vietnam veterans. To some extent it did set to rest some of the fears and worries in the minds of Vietnam veterans about the state of their health and of their families. Taken together with the results of the birth defect study, which I announced in the middle of February when I was the Minister, those two things do go a long way towards the achievement of the goal of setting people's minds at rest about the results of their very significant and valiant service in Vietnam on behalf of this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Repre- sentatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide the legislative machinery to give effect to the decision in 1977 by the Australian people to amend the Constitution so that electors in the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory, which includes the Jervis Bay Territory, would in future have the right to vote at referendums.

Members will be aware that prior to 1977 for a referendum amending the Constitution to be carried not only were a majority of the States required to be in favour of the question but also a majority of the electors on a national basis. Prior to the 1977 referendum, however, the national elector population was held to be comprised only of electors of the 6 States. The effect of this of course was to deprive tens of thousands of otherwise eligible Territory electors of the franchise insofar as referendums were concerned.

The unreasonableness of this situation was recognised and in 1977, with the blessing of both sides of this Chamber, it was decided that one of the proposals which should be put before the Australian people at that time was that the electors of the Territories should have a vote in future referendums. The proposal was that their votes should be counted only as part of the national vote-that is to say they would not be regarded as being part of any of the States or of determining the majority view of the States but they would contribute to the determination of the majority view of the nation.
Although this is essentially a machinery Bill and although the question of the rights of Territory electors has already been decided this nevertheless is an important franchise measure in itself.

The Bill provides that the legislation governing the conduct of referendums in the States will, with certain modifications which reflect the different electoral circumstances of the Territories, apply to the conduct of referendums in the Territories. The Bill provides for the appointment of Electoral Officers for the Territories who will have powers and duties similar to those exercised and performed by the Australian Electoral Officers in the States.

The Bill also recognises the independent status of the Northern Territory and makes provision for the forwarding of a copy of the Writ for a referendum and the Statement of Results, to the Administrator. As is the case in the States, the Bill also provides that the Northern Territory may, through its Attorney- General, challenge the results of a referendum by petition to the High Court.

The legislation governing the conduct of referendums is, like the legislation governing the conduct of elections, in need of drastic reform and amendments will be brought forward in the context of the electoral reforms that the Parliament will be asked to consider. In the interim these machinery amendments are designed to ensure that Territory electors are not disenfranchised should Parliament approve a proposal to amend the Constitution being submitted to the people.
I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The message we received set out in some detail a number of proposed terms of reference for the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters. I wish to move a series of amendments to those proposed terms of reference identical with the series of amendments moved in the House of Representatives by my colleague the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to move all amendments together. I indicate that amendment (d) would be consequential upon amendment (e) being agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) At the end of paragraph (1) add ''subject to the following modifications-
(a) Paragraph (1), leave out sub-paragraph (g), insert the following sub- paragraph:
'(g) electoral distribution and numbers of Members of Parliament, procedures and systems.'
(b) paragraph (1), at end of paragraph, add the following sub-paragraph:
'(h) any other matters which are contained in or are affected by the operation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act.'
(c) paragraph (2), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

'(2) The the committee consist of 10 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the National Party in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.'
(d) paragraph (4), at end of paragraph, add 'who shall have both a deliberative and a casting vote'; and
(e) paragraph (15), leave out '31 August', insert '30 November'.''.
(2) At end of paragraph (3) add ''with a request for the concurrence of that House in the Senate's modifications of the Resolutions transmitted to the Senate by that House.''

The second amendment would add a new sub-paragraph at the end of paragraph (1) to make it clear that the Committee to be appointed would have a capacity to look at all matters contained in or affected by the operation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. In other words, a number of matters have been set out. They seem to cover many of the features contained in the Act. If the Committee is to do what the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) indicated it might do when he introduced this matter there would seem to be no disadvantage in agreeing to other matters contained in the Act being included within the purview of the Committee. Alternatively, if the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) indicated in response that the intention of that second amendment is acceptable to the Government, and the Committee would have that capacity, it might be helpful to those who are to serve on the Committee. Neither of those two amendments is a matter of enormous argument or substance; they are small moves which we thought might improve the operation of the Committee from our point of view and we hope they will receive favourable consideration from the Government.

The third amendment, however, is more significant. If this Committee is to do its job and to be representative of the groups within the Parliament, it is important and essential that each major party grouping in the Senate have representation on the Committee. The terms of reference as proposed do not provide a place on the Committee for members of the National Party in the Senate . It seems to me that if what is being sought is an opportunity to develop proposals in relation to electoral matters and to present them to the Parliament in a bipartisan fashion, and if it is intended that the Parliament should then look favourably upon the Committee's findings when they emerge, each grouping within the Senate should be represented. It is possible to do this. Whether it is by inadvertence or whatever, National Party senators have not been included in the membership of this Committee.

The amendment which we have proposed would provide one extra place for the National Party, and that would mean that the Government and non-Government parties within the Parliament would then have an equality of numbers on the Committee. Therefore, the fourth amendment, which is consequential to the third, would provide an assurance to the Government that there is no attempt to remove control of the Committee from its hands. It would also provide that the Government Chairman would have both a deliberative and a casting vote. We are trying, with those two amendments, to ensure a place for one recognised party in the Senate, at present not included, and to provide that the Government be protected; that is, that it have a casting vote and that it would not lose control of the Committee by doing that. I put it to the Government that this would improve the acceptability of the Committee and its findings to the Parliament. It would merely provide a demonstration that all parties in the Senate are represented.

The fifth amendment is merely to give the Committee a little longer time in which to do its work. But it still accepts the Government's principle that it should be a committee with a limited life, with a set reporting date and that is should get its work done within that time. We have suggested within the fifth amendment that 30 November might be more appropriate than 31 August. I invite the Government to respond to each of the amendments. I hope that they are acceptable. They are offered in a genuine hope that we can expedite the work of the Committee and make it a success. Perhaps the amendments will also make it slightly more effective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate, I hope in the same consensual spirit in which Senator Peter Baume wrapped his remarks, that we do not accept the amendments moved by the Opposition. I shall briefly indicate why. We do not really see what the first amendment adds to the motion before the Senate. The motion is for an inquiry to report on all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament, and some matters are then specified thereunder. There is a very broad reference in respect of all matters. The fact that certain matters are specified as being included indicates only that they are matters which the Government is specifically adverting to, but it does not exclude the possibility of other matters being considered by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters.
—Would you consider the matters mentioned in the first two amendments capable of study by the Committee?

—That is a matter for the Committee to consider. They are not excluded, in my view. The second point I wish to make relates to the reference in amendment (b) to 'any other matters which are contained in or affected by the operation of the Commonwealth Electoral Act'. We regard that amendment as too wide because the Commonwealth Electoral Act refers to a vast variety of matters. This is what the Government has in mind as matters which should be considered as matters of priority, as indicated, and we regard that as too much of an ambit claim. The third amendment is to change the composition of the Committee by including, effectively, a National Party senator. We take the view that in terms of the numerical strength of the National Party in the Parliament, as distinct from isolating it into two chambers, its interests will be protected. After all, it is not as though--
—They will have only one representative, will they not, for some 24 people?

—That is so, yes, but the fact of the matter is that it is not as though the majority of the National Party and the Liberal Party in this chamber speak with discordant and diverse voices on matters in this chamber at any time. We are not seeking deliberately to slight the National Party. We believe that the arrangement which the Government has made is fair to all parties concerned. It follows from that view that the consequential amendment has no relevance. The fifth paragraph of the amendment seeks merely to extend the life of the Committee from 31 August to 30 November this year. The Government wants this matter resolved as quickly as possible. The committee is empowered to seek from the Parliament an extension if, for any reason, it feels at the time of the expiration of its life that it is on to something new.

SPEECH.PARA: In connection with this whole matter, the Government is regretful that during the period of the Fraser Government two reports were commissioned by it from the Commonwealth Electoral Office on the matters which are the subject of this discussion. One would have thought that members of the Opposition-certainly those who were Ministers in the previous Government-would have had some opportunity to seek advice from the Electoral Office on the views of that Office on the matters raised in this discussion. Unfortunately, none of those reports by the Electoral Office saw the light of day. We regret that they were not made available to the Parliament. But no doubt members of the Opposition will have copies of those reports and will be able to use them, certainly with the agreement of the Government, in any discussion which takes place during committee hearings. That may well facilitate the discussion and mean that the Committee can comfortably complete its deliberations by 31 August.

While we see the point of the proposed amendments moved by the Opposition, they are not acceptable to the Government. I assure the Senate that if there is any concern about the way the Committee conducts its deliberations, we will no doubt hear about it and respond to it at that time. But we do not believe that that will occur. We would like the Committee to proceed with its deliberations in the manner suggested and report by 31 August.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, the National Party certainly supports the establishment of a joint select committee to examine electoral matters in Australia, to examine the Commonwealth Electoral Act and to make recommendations. I believe it is high time, in this vast country in which the population of electorates has more than doubled since such an examination occurred, that an in-depth investigation of the electoral system was made. At the same time, naturally, I support the amendments moved by the Opposition. I believe that the amendment which in general refers to an extension of time to 30 November for the conclusion of deliberations of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Matters is a responsible one. An immense proposition is being put to the Committee and to assume that it can respond responsibly in less than three months seems to me a little beyond the area of probability. The size of the Parliament is also of interest and I believe it should be examined. It is possible that the motion, even as it stands, will cover that.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention briefly the case that suggests that the National Party in the Senate should be represented on such a committee. We have, after all, made a contribution to this Parliament for a period in excess of 60 years. We represent a vast area of Australia. I believe we have a measure of expertise that is referable to the electoral circumstances in extra-metropolitan Australia. It is my belief that the National Party could, and should, make a constructive contribution to the considerations of this Committee. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to outline the Australian Democrats position in relation to the five amendments moved by the Opposition. The first amendment, seeking to add to the motion the number of members of parliament, certainly has merit and is an element that one would hope would arise in any discussion of electoral redistribution. However, I believe that the comments made by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) are adequate to cover events. I believe that the Committee, once it is established and looks at its terms of reference, would be quite willing to look at the question of the number of members of parliament. Indeed, I am not sure how one would address oneself in any detailed fashion to the notion of electoral redistribution without also addressing oneself to the notion of numbers of members of parliament. I merely draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that since 1949, when the last electoral redistribution of any substance, other than that dealing with movements between States, took place, the total number of electors represented by a member of the House of Representatives has almost doubled. Therefore, I believe that when the Committee addresses this matter it will need to look very closely at that question and also, as a consequence of the nexus which is established within the Constitution, at the number of senators. So I do not believe that the first amendment is necessary for the Committee to be able to undertake that task.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to the second amendment, I do not believe that the Committee will be excluded from looking at any matter within the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I do not agree with the Leader of the Government in the Senate that this is a wide ambit claim. If one looks at the motion moved, both in the House of Representatives and the Senate, one finds that it states:
That a joint select committee be appointed to inquire into and report upon all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament of the Commonwealth and matters related thereto . . .

Indeed, one would assume that all matters within the Commonwealth Electoral Act are matters related to elections. In that sense, I suggest, one would have a very strong claim by simply saying that if a matter appears in the Commonwealth Electoral Act it is a matter relating to Commonwealth elections, and therefore comes under the aegis of this Committee. So the Australian Democrats will not support the second amendment moved by the Opposition.

The third and fourth amendments deal with representation on the Committee. In this instance, in order to understand our position, it is vital to relate some history of the matter. Last year Senator Gietzelt, who was then the Opposition spokesperson on electoral matters, moved a motion for a joint committee to be set up with terms of reference very similar to the ones included in this reference. The Senate passed that motion against the wishes of the then Government-now the Opposition-which voted against the establishment of such a committee only a little over 12 months ago. That resolution then went to the House of Representatives where it lay on the table and was never proceeded with.

The odd thing about the resolution passed in the Senate was that it included the idea that we were in a position immediately to advertise for submissions to that committee. Indeed, many submissions were received from interested bodies but, unfortunately, since no joint committee was in existence, those submissions are now in some type of committee limbo which is a little difficult to understand. I believe that we will probably need a resolution of the Senate to resurrect them out of whatever hole they have gone down. Those submissions were made in response to advertisements placed by this House in national media advertising. People went to a great deal of trouble to make those submissions to this Parliament at our request in response to the motion moved by Senator Gietzelt and I believe that there is an obligation on the new committee to take them up.

If the previous Government had adopted that resolution it would have had a majority on the committee and could have appointed to it as many representatives of the National Party as it wished. We come now, of course, to a different ball game. I am not sure that the present Government was all that keen on having a committee inquire into this matter either. It probably would have been quite happy to proceed, as would most governments, and it might also have been able to argue that it had a mandate to proceed, to electoral reform without going to a committee as a result of the election of 5 March. It put a fairly comprehensive package of election proposals to the Australian electors, which proposals appeared in the complete text of the speech given by the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the opening of the Australian Labor Party campaign. Therefore, I think it could well have argued that it did not have a need for a committee. Some four weeks ago I put to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) the proposition that we ought to proceed to establish a joint committee because it is that proposal that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party supported when the ALP was in opposition and it has the continuing support of the Australian Democrats.

The alternative, of course, was to establish a select committee of the Senate. It does not take terribly much mathematical genius to work out that if there is to be a committee there will be a committee one way or the other. I think the Special Minister of State caught the drift of my comments in relation to that matter and thought that it was probably better, even if he was not contemplating it himself, to proceed with a joint committee. However, I do not in those remarks detract from the congratulations I give to the Government on proceeding with something with which it had no need to proceed. I believe that it is to the Government's credit that it would seek an open inquiry in this regard. I believe that the Commonwealth Electoral Act is the Act par excellence which belongs to the people, not to the politicians. Indeed, it is the Act on which the people ought to have as much say, and into which there ought to be as much inquiry, as it is humanly possible for this Parliament to achieve. So while having sympathy with the third and fourth amendments, but also having regard to the fact that the Government will oppose the amendments, the Australian Democrats cannot support them. As I have pointed out the Committee is to be a joint one. A resolution of this Senate has no binding force upon the other House. For the amendments to be passed the other House would be under an obligation to modify its motion and since there is a government majority in that House there would be no opportunity for that to occur. Therefore, with reluctance, we will not be supporting amendments (c) and (d).

That leaves the last item, which is the date by which the Committee will report . In my discussions with the Special Minister of State he raised what I think was a very genuine concern; that such a committee could very well disrupt the legislative program of the Government. The Government had intended to introduce electoral reform at a particular time and the Committee could very well not enable that to occur within the program that the Government had set out. My response to that was that the Senate had a fair amount of experience in operating short, sharp inquiries, which, nevertheless, have had a fairly traumatic effect upon legislation. I instance but two such inquiries which honourable senators will probably remember. One was the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations into the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill, which managed to get that Bill thrown out of this place about two weeks after the inquiry commenced. The other was the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania which, of course, had the final effect of having a Bill passed through this chamber and also of having another Bill presently under discussion in this chamber.

So I do not see that it is necessary for us to extend the time. I for one am not quite sure whether 30 November or 31 March is the appropriate time. Either one of those dates would do. I think that given the fact that submissions are already in existence and that this Committee can proceed immediately to interview the people who made those submissions, given the fact that we can advertise immediately for more submissions and given the fact that we will have the break between now and the Budget session, I think we have a fairly good chance of getting a report into this chamber and the other place by 31 August. If we do not do so, the Committee will have leave to return to this chamber and request an extension, giving its reasons. Then it will be up to this chamber and the other place to deliberate upon those reasons and to see whether an extension is warranted. That seems to be the way in which previous committees have operated time and again. Those requests on the part of committees have always been treated most sympathetically by this place if the reasons that the committee wishes to adduce have convinced this chamber that such an extension is warranted. So I do not believe that we need concern ourselves over much about the closing date. I merely hope the Committee will go about its task with all due deliberation and that if it needs to seek an extension it will do so. Consequently, the Australian Democrats will not be supporting any of the amendments which have been proposed to the Government's motion to set up a joint committee on electoral matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GIETZELT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the amendments moved by the Opposition. Most of the questions have been canvassed by Senator Macklin. I wish just to remind the Senate that in the five years during which I was shadow Minister for Administrative Services I sought to have some changes made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, principally because the report of the Government's own inquiry and the report it sought from the Chief Australian Electoral Officer had recommended substantial changes to the Act. SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Macklin has suggested, I tried on numerous occasions since 1980, when I was given more specific responsibility for electoral matters, to have the Senate appoint a select committee to look into the Act. DEBATE.TITLE: MR DAVID COMBE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement that was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the House of Representatives a few minutes ago-it is his statement-and to move a motion that the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Events of the last few weeks relating to the expulsion of the Soviet KGB officer Ivanov involve fundamental issues of national security and individual civil liberties. My Government's approach to this matter has involved placing these issues above all other considerations, including political party or personal associations. For my part I have sought to ensure that because the issues of national security extend beyond which political party holds office the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was fully briefed. He expressed complete support for the Government's proposed course of action. I am appalled that the endorsement by the Leader of the Opposition of the Government's approach was of insufficient influence to prevent members of the Opposition making efforts to exploit for political purposes a matter in which issues of national security and individual civil liberties are concerned.

The decision relating to the expulsion of Ivanov had the unanimous support of all members of the Cabinet Sub-committee on National and International Security, comprising the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes). The subsequent decision regarding Mr David Combe's association with the Government had the full support of both my Cabinet and my full Ministry. The basis for the expulsion of Ivanov is not in question, and remains as set out in the Foreign Minister's statement of 22 April. As regards the action relating to Mr Combe, the Government has never been in any doubt about the validity of its decision. At the same time it was concerned that he should not become the object of public censure without some opportunity to defend himself. From the time that the Opposition used his name in the House yesterday, it was essential that he be given this opportunity.

Mr Combe's association with Ivanov, and the subsequent decision made by my Government in regard to his contact with it, had been the subject of several hours of discussions today between Mr Combe and the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, during part of which time the Director-General of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, Mr Harvey Barnett, was present. During these discussions Mr Combe gave his detailed account of his professional activities as a public affairs consultant and his past relationship with the Soviet Union and the Soviet Embassy, and the Attorney-General set out, in the terms summarised in the following paragraphs, the considerations which have determined the Government's course of action. Following those discussions Mr Combe has now advised the Government that, having regard to all the circumstances as they stood at the time the Government made its decision, he 'understands and accepts' the Government's decision that Ministers not deal with him in his capacity as a consultant lobbyist.

The Government's decision, which was made in the first instance by Cabinet in Adelaide on 26 April and endorsed by the full Ministry in Canberra on 2 May, followed a recommendation made by me explicitly based on the following considerations:

Ministers' doors should be, and be seen to be, open without the need for leverage by a party insider; and it was not appropriate that a former Party official, by virtue of that status, have special advantages or access to Government denied to others.

At its meeting on 2 May, the Ministry agreed that the Special Minister of State should bring forward a submission canvassing a possible scheme for the registration of government lobbyists generally, not just those with Labor Party connections.

I now make it clear that there was a further consideration underlying my recommendation to the Cabinet and Ministry which was not explicitly raised with either body at the time, but which had been the subject of prior discussion and agreement by the Cabinet Sub-Committee on National and International Security. The information and advice then available to the Government suggested that Mr Combe's relationship with Ivanov had developed to the point that it gave rise to serious security concern. The view of the National and International Security Sub-committee was that, as events had developed, Mr Combe either had been, or appeared to have been, compromised by Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Government Ministers to deal with him. The deliberate cultivation by Ivanov of the relationship with Mr Combe, and the stage that process had reached on Labor's assumption to office, was one of the reasons-but by no means the only reason-which led to the Government's decision to expel Mr Ivanov from Australia on 22 April. It is the view of the Attorney-General and his Department that, on all the information available to them, no criminal offence has been committed by Mr Combe. There is certainly, in the Government's belief, no foundation for any allegation or imputation that Mr Combe is, or ever was, in any sense a 'Soviet spy'. I repeat that the Leader of the Opposition has been fully briefed on all aspects of the Ivanov matter-including the position of Mr Combe and the advice of the Attorney-General and his Department-both on 21 April, the day the decision to expel Mr Ivanov was taken, and subsequently. He has expressed complete support for the Government's actions in this matter.

Let me stress what I said to the House at the outset of this statement. When issues of national security are at stake, whether they be manifested in terms of foreign espionage activities or by such means as the articles published in the National Times last week, which are prejudicial to the national interest, this Government will not be deterred from resolutely defending that interest, whatever attempt may be made to misrepresent this principled position. Nor shall we attempt to exploit such issues for our own political gains. We will remain committed at the same time to ensuring that in defence of the national interest, there are no transgressions of individual civil liberties. It is perhaps inevitable that there will always be elements of doubt and suspicion in the minds of all Australians in circumstances where there can be less than full disclosure of information. That is a responsibility a Government must accept, and for my part I accept it. But I trust this statement will put to rest the uncertainty of the last few days, and convince all Australians, of whatever political persuasion, of the correctness and fairness of our handling of the matter. A climate of innuendo and deceit, which some have attempted to introduce into that matter, is not one which my Government will be guilty of creating or permitting to flourish. Finally, I am sure that our actions in respect of this matter, and of the National Times articles, will have made it clear to all other governments that in no way will my Government be compromised when matters of our national security are at stake.
I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement which has been put down by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) touches upon very serious matters. It has been available to the Opposition for a little over half an hour. For reasons which I suppose are apparent on the face of the statement, it was not possible for us to get it in the normal two-hour period before the statement was put down. I assume from the fact that discussions were held this afternoon between the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and Mr Combe that that was part of the reason for the statement not being ready in time for us to give it more careful consideration.
—That is the only reason.

—I thank the honourable senator. I will express a preliminary view only on behalf of the Opposition on a number of the points which are raised . I must address some, in part because of the fourth paragraph which refers to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in terms which I think are both unfair and inaccurate. I wish to make the general point-I put all these comments as preliminary comments-that we have before us a statement which, I am sure, honourable senators opposite wish were not before us and indeed honourable senators behind me wish were not before us because we have moved away from what I think has been the appropriate rule in these matters of refusing to comment on matters of security in a way which gives rise to the possibility of information coming out which is prejudicial to the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that only yesterday Mr Hawke quite correctly stated that principle in response to a question which was asked by Mr MacKellar in the other place. He asked the question on the basis of one of the numerous Press reports on security matters which have appeared since last weekend and, indeed, I think as early as last Friday. Mr MacKellar asked a question about a report in the Press yesterday that a senior Labor man who had been one of the most important and influential figures in the Australian Labor Party over the past two decades had been closely associated with the recently expelled Soviet diplomat, Mr Ivanov. There was a longer response than perhaps should have been necessary because there were some interjections during it. At the end of his response Mr Hawke said:

Therefore, I repeat the answer, which seems to escape the honourable member but nevertheless is in terms of the practice which was followed by the previous Government-one of the few practices that it did follow which was correct-that neither I nor any member of my Government will publicly canvass issues in which questions of national security are so obviously involved, as they were in the expulsion of Mr Ivanov.

I welcome the acknowledgment by the Prime Minister that that was the practice of the previous Government. I recall the previous Attorney-General giving answers in those terms in response to questions which were, I think, properly addressed to him when we were in government and properly not answered by him in pursuance of that principle.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Gareth Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you ask all those questions today then?

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator CHANEY The Attorney-General asked me why further questions were asked. That is a reasonable question. I thank him for it. The reason is quite simple: It is quite clear that at the time Mr Hawke made the statement of principle yesterday, with which the Opposition agrees, he had already breached that principle. It came to the attention of the Opposition through the Australian Associated Press report that in the Caucus meeting of yesterday the Prime Minister was not quite as circumspect. He chose to make statements about who was not implicated by the report. The fact is that the Opposition was given a report which was available to all of the media through AAP as to what had occurred at the Caucus meeting earlier that morning. It is quite clear from the Hansard record of the House of Representatives yesterday that further questioning followed the fact. I refer to the question asked by Mr Peacock, who referred to the answer given by the Prime Minister to Mr MacKellar. It states:

I understand from news reports I have to hand now that he has in fact discussed the matter in the Caucus today and told his Party 'that the former senior Australian Labor Party official' is not a member of the Government. Why did the Prime Minister mislead the House?
Mr Hawke, in his reply, said that he had not misled the House and that he would tell the House exactly what transpired in Caucus that morning. He said:

One of the members of the Government raised the point that he had been approached in the light of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald and was asked whether he was the person involved. He indicated that to the best of his knowledge he was not. Of course, when that matter was raised what I told the member of the Government who had raised the question and told the Caucus was that neither he nor any member of the Government was the person involved. That is what I told the Caucus. That was the truth. I always, as distinct from some other members, tell the truth.

The fact is that the principle which the Prime Minister so correctly laid down had been breached. I am not in a position to answer in full detail for the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition has followed the proprieties in this matter and has in no way been involved in the mass of news reports which have appeared with respect to these matters and which indicate that many stories have been floating around in the national capital about them.

On the question by Mr Sinclair, it seems to me that the Government, both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate this morning, has shown a fair degree of carelessness in being prepared to link questions which cover separate reports , some relating to Mr Combe and the question of whether he was going to get any further consultancy work because apparently he was not going to be acceptable to this Government in future. The Government has been quite happy to link those questions to those which were asked about the separate reports about a senior Labor figure. In Question Time here this morning quite separate questions were put by the Opposition.
