The answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Attorney-General made it quite clear that the two separate streams of reports in fact referred to exactly the same person, Mr David Combe. On the face of the statement-again I have had but brief time to look at it-a perfectly honest answer was available to the Prime Minister with respect to the question which was addressed about Mr Combe. If one looks at the statement one finds that, on reasons which were given to the Cabinet and to the Ministry, there were perfectly sound reasons why the Government would not wish to deal with Mr Combe as a consultant. I refer to page 2 of the Prime Minister's statement which points out:

The Government's decision, which was made in the first instance by Cabinet in Adelaide on 26 April and endorsed by the full Ministry in Canberra on 2 May, followed a recommendation made by me explicitly based on the following considerations:

Ministers' doors should be, and be seen to be, open without the need for leverage by a party insider; and it was not appropriate that a former party official, by virtue of that status, have special advantages or access to Government denied to others.

I would have thought that since that is apparently the basis on which the decision was made by the Ministry and the Cabinet, one could have quite honestly put that perfectly acceptable statement of principles before the Parliament without the sort of response that the Government has in fact brought forward over the last two days. What we are left with now is in a sense the worst of all worlds. We have a statement which, in quite an extraordinary way, at the top of page 5, and in the pious style we have come to expect, says:
We will remain committed at the same time to ensuring that, in defence of the national interest, there are no transgressions of individual civil liberties.

Apparently, the means of ensuring that there are no transgressions of individual civil liberties in this case is having the person who is under a cloud spend several hours with the Attorney-General and agreeing that the Government's course of action is acceptable. We are left with a statement which says:

The information and advice then available to the Government suggested that Mr Combe's relationship with Ivanov had developed to the point that gave rise to serious security concern. The view of the National and International Security Sub-Committee was that, as events had developed, Mr Combe either had been or appeared to have been compromised by Mr Ivanov to the extent that it was no longer appropriate for Government Ministers to deal with him.

The deliberate cultivation by Ivanov of the relationship with Mr Combe, and the stage that process had reached on Labor's assumption to office, was one of the reasons-but by no means the only reason-which led to the Government's decision to expel Mr Ivanov from Australia on 22 April.

That is the position we are left with by this statement. Bearing in mind the extraordinary muddle of principles which I think is contained in the statement, some of which are basically important to this country and need careful consideration, I doubt that at this stage prolonged debate of the statement we have had so briefly will promote that consideration. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORLD HERITAGE PROPERTIES CONSERVATION BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 May 1983 on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, which purports to enable the Government to take certain action in relation to properties which are of cultural value. The debate on this Bill in the other place, especially as reported in the Press, has been overwhelmingly of the flavour that this is a Bill on the subject of the proposed dam in South West Tasmania. The Bill involves a lot more than the building of a dam in South West Tasmania, which is not even mentioned, as it happens. The Bill is very much about the Hawke Government's approach to the Constitution and its relations with the States.

SPEECH.PARA: I state at the outset that whatever attempts have been made to misrepresent the previous Liberal government's and this Liberal Opposition's attitude on matters relating to the environment could not be worse founded. The Fraser Government has a proud record on the subject of conservation and the environment. I remind the Senate that all the Australian listings on the World Heritage List to this day were placed there by Liberal-National Party governments, and that the efforts of previous Liberal governments in establishing national parks and in taking a stand on issues related to the environment are very highly regarded. I mention such matters as the Kakadu and Uluru national parks. I draw the attention of the Senate to the declaration of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park . The parallels with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park are probably particularly important in this debate. Lord Howe Island and the Willandra Lakes region were also placed on the World Heritage List by the previous Government. When in government we were vigilant on the subject of the environment. Our record is one of which we are proud. We reject and resist any suggestion that the attitude we have taken on the subject of damming South West Tasmania represents a cavalier attitude towards the value of that part of the National Estate and its value on the World Heritage List. The Fraser Government attempted to resolve the issue and made numerous offers to the Tasmanian Government; most recently it made an offer of $500m and other forms of assistance for alternative sources of power. I think our record on that subject indicated very clearly our attitude on this issue. However, we were not prepared to sweep aside the Constitution.

Parliament, in dealing with this Bill, faces some very serious issues. Individual senators will have to examine their own beliefs and consciences on the subject of the Federation and the Constitution when they come to vote on the Bill. I state at this stage that we will be moving to the motion for the second reading an amendment which would not have the effect of negating the second reading. We intend to support the Bill's going into Committee. We shall be moving a number of amendments when the Bill is considered clause by clause in Committee, in which we will give more detail of our attitude to what is wrong with the detail of the Bill. However, at this stage I confine myself to the general thrust of the Bill and our general objection to sections of it.

What the Government seeks to do under this Bill is based on the four heads of power-the external affairs power, the national power, the corporate power and the racial power. By this means this Government is seeking to intrude into what has been considered to be an area of responsibility of State governments. I draw to the attention of the Senate the views of a member of the Government-then a member of the Opposition-on this subject. I would like to quote from a letter to the editor of the Australian newspaper published on 28 January 1983. The letter, which was written by the Australian Labor Party member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) , states:

Lawyers are arguing whether the High Court would grant the Commonwealth Government power to intervene and prevent the construction of the Tasmanian dam under the external affairs power of the Constitution.
May I, as one who tends to oppose increased government powers of most kinds--
I acknowledge that Dr Klugman is a member who has always been active in the area of individual rights in this Parliament-
caution those Labor supporters who may approve of the extension of such power in this case.

What would prevent an Australian Government signing a treaty with South Africa dealing with 'subversion?' Could an Act endorsing such a treaty then give an Australian government unlimited powers, denied to it by the High Court (and a referendum) in the early 1950s?

Before endorsing the use of the external affairs power to circumvent the Constitution, let us remember that an Australian Government could find a number of foreign governments prepared to sign all kinds of treaties conferring unpleasant powers on our government.

Put in simple terms I think that is a very good point. I understand how tempted the present Government is to try to use the foreign affairs power in the Constitution as a way of extending its power, as a way of determining whether a State government may build a dam and whether a State government has the final right of decision as to how it will generate power in its own State. There has been much debate over the years as to the use of the external affairs power by Commonwealth governments in Australia. I would like to quote briefly from a writing of Chief Justice Latham, as quoted in a book by Sir Robert Menzies on this subject. I quote from it not as an authority on this debate but just to give honourable senators and others an idea of what is involved in attaching this sort of significance to the signing of treaties. Mr Justice Latham states:
The list of bilateral international agreements extends over 18 pages--
This is in a 1935 publication of the then Department of External Affairs-

and the list of general and multilateral international agreements extends over 11 pages. The subjects are so various it is impossible to classify them. They include matters affecting extradition, trade and commerce, navigation, legal proceedings, joint stock companies, war graves, commercial arbitration, international arbitration, tariffs, trade marks and other industrial property, friendship and amity, postal matters, medical practitioners, lunatics, submarine telegraph cables, maritime and land warfare, sanitation, white slave traffic, use of white phosphorous in manufacturing matches, copyright, obscene publications, peace after the Great War, labour matters, contagious diseases, dangerous drugs, economic statistics . . . limitation and reduction of armaments , and other subjects.
Mr Justice Latham goes on:
It is in my opinion, impossible to say . . . that any subject is necessarily such that it could never properly be dealt with by international agreement.

That is a very real caution, as is the caution from the honourable member for Prospect. The Hawke Government, in basing so much of its thrust on this matter on the external affairs power, opens a Pandora's box for itself as well as for future governments. The High Court of Australia, of course, will ultimately decide on the validity of the use of that power. There will be many arguments before the High Court as to whether it is justified. Nevertheless, it must be remembered that this Government has deliberately taken the decision to use that power as its basis for proceeding. This is in strong contrast to the policy of the Australia Labor Party in previous years. I instance in particular the policy of the Federal Labor Party in relation to Tasmania when there was a State Labor government. When the Whitlam Government was previously in power there was a controversy in Tasmania called Lake Pedder. Of course, the actions of that Labor Government were rather different on that issue.

Attention has been drawn previously to the attitude of the Federal Labor Party prior to the accession of Mr Hawke to its leadership. I would like to quote from a letter on this subject written by the previous Leader of the Labor Party, Mr Hayden. On the subject of intervention by the national Parliament in the matter of South West Tasmania, Mr Hayden said:

. . . we would support a Parliamentary Inquiry into how best we could help the State Government preserve the South-West, but not as to interfere with the Tasmanian Government's efforts to produce power but for its people which may involve some construction in that area . . .
The more fundamental matters of concern are very much a State responsibility and outside of the constitutional authority of the National Government.
That was Mr Hayden's attitude in 1981. He also stated:
. . . further negotiations will have to proceed with the responsible authority, and that is the Tasmanian Government.

That was the attitude of the Federal Labor Party, as stated by its Leader, until quite recently. However, the temptation in the end has proved too much for the Labor Party-the temptation to move into this area and to take that extra power. I refer to the difference in attitude of the Labor Party under the leadership of Mr Hayden and under the leadership of Mr Hawke. Mr Hawke's attitude towards the Constitution and the States is extremely well known. Mr Hawke likes to travel Australia now, as he did before he became Leader of the Labor Party, saying that he considers the present Constitution to be an anachronism; that it is no longer relevant. In the Boyer lectures he said some very strong things on the subject of the powers of the States under the Constitution. He said many things, but I will quote just briefly from one section that seems to encapsulate his attitude. I might say that he used some very strong language in relation to the States and their powers on a number of occasions. He said:
There is no justification now, in terms of the interests and the rights of fourteen million Australians, to perpetuate this dangerous anachronism.
The dangerous anachronism to which he is referring is the federal system and a series of parliaments-Commonwealth and State parliaments. He continued:

I believe the logical implication of this analysis is that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is the States-which no longer serve their original purpose and act as a positive impediment to achieving good government in our current community.

There is some argument for saying that the present purpose of the States is not identical with the original purpose. There are certainly many elements of the original purpose which are identical with the current purpose of the States.

We have had a series of referenda over the years in this country on the subject of changing the Constitution. There have been various results. On occasions the people have refused to extend the power of the central government. On occasions they have agreed to extend the power of the central government. It is not good enough for those who look at our Constitution and say: 'It is an anachronism', just as they look at our States and say: 'They are dangerous anachronisms', to try to alter by stealth the balance as it was intended.

The Constitution is, of course, the property of the people. It is the basic political document in Australia. We must always accept the wisdom and the good faith of the people when they vote on matters relating to the Constitution. We must accept, not that the electorate is inherently conservative as those who rail on the subject on occasions are inclined to say, but that the people basically have a good reason for voting the way they do in referenda. That is bad enough but it is utterly unacceptable that one would try to side-step the issue that one ought to face; that is, do Australians really want the central government to have this sort of power?

It is convenient for Mr Hawke to berate the constitutional structure but that does not address the central issue. At the Australian Constitutional Convention the Hawke Government had much to say about people's attitudes towards constitutional change and how important the Constitutional Convention was. It deplored what it claimed were the attitudes of some others towards the process of changing the Constitution. I will quote from an editorial of the Australian Financial Review of 2 May 1983 on this subject. It states:

. . . there is a certain disingenuousness in the complaints of the Commonwealth Attorney-General on the outcome of last week's convention, when before the Federal Parliament this week is a bill which in itself is an attempt totally to bypass the Constitutional Convention or the referendum process as a means of changing the Constitution.

This is the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill. Whatever the merits of the Tasmanian dams issue the four heads of power the Commonwealth is claiming as support for the constitutional validity of this bill would, if confirmed, radically alter the nature of the Australian Federation and the meaning of the Constitution. Yet it seems that at no time did the Commonwealth even consider submitting this bill to the Convention for consideration.

Mr Deputy President, I submit to you that this is fair comment. The purpose of the Government in following this path is to bypass an arrangement, an accepted position in relation to power, that has obtained for a very long time. It does it by stealth.

The Opposition, in the House of Representatives and in this chamber, raises a number of objections to the Bill. I reiterate what I said at the beginning: In no circumstances could it be construed that by moving to improve this Bill we are trying to damage it. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans)-who has taken it on himself to represent the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment ( Mr Cohen) in this chamber-made some comment in the second reading speech which did not specifically address itself to debate in the other place but attempted to move, to some extent, to meet some of the basic objections to the Bill that the Opposition had indicated it had in the Committee stage of the debate. I will refer to that comment very briefly in a few minutes. I do not believe that the Attorney-General has, in any way, met the matters that have been raised through amendments relative to the Federal Court or on the subject of compensation.

Today we had presented to the Senate the first report for 1983 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in this Parliament. The Attorney- General, when he was shadow Attorney-General, was very fond of promoting Scrutiny of Bills reports as some sort of basis for objectivity in consideration of Bills. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee looked at this Bill and has drawn Parliament's attention to several sections of it. Last week the Scrutiny of Bills Committee put out an Alert Digest in which were outlined some problems with this Bill. The Digest was made available so that members of the House of Representatives would have it available to them in their debate on this Bill. The Committee report that came in today contains all that that Alert Digest contained and some additional points. But the Attorney-General did not address himself at all to these objections.

The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has raised particular queries in relation to compensation provisions in this legislation. I do not intend to go right through the report because it has been made available to honourable senators but I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard paragraphs 9 to 12 of the Scrutiny of Bills report presented in the Parliament today, that is, that section which relates to compensation.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Clause 17-Compensation

9. This clause sets out the procedures relating to the determination of any compensation that might be payable for land acquired under the Act or under regulations made pursuant to the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. The procedures are intended to fulfil the Constitutional requirement that the Commonwealth acquire property ''on just terms'' (s. 51 (xxxi)).

10. Once it has been determined that the Commonwealth is liable to pay compensation, the precise amount-the ''just terms''-is determined in accordance with a procedure spelt out in clauses 17 (7) to 17 (14). If the claimed amount is less than $5 million, and the Commonwealth does not agree to this amount, the claimant may apply to the Federal Court for determination of the compensation, under clause 17 (14).

11. However, in cases of disputed claims for $5 million or more, the Governor- General shall establish a Commission of Inquiry to inquire into and report on the compensation payable. Under clause 17 (10), a Commission has 12 months in which to report; and under clause 17 (12), the Governor-General has a further 3 months in which to determine the compensation payable. Although the Committee believes that the Report of the Commission of Inquiry would be admissible as evidence in any Federal Court action taken under this clause, the Committee is concerned that the Report may otherwise not be publicly available, either through tabling in Parliament or release to the claimant. If either the Commission does not report within 12 months or the claimant contests the amount determined by the Governor-General, the claimant may apply to the Federal Court to determine a just amount.

12. The Committee draws attention to the difference in treatment accorded disputed claims which fall either side of the $5 million. Disputed claims of $5 million or more are made subject to a process of resolution which may, in some circumstances, be less speedy and possibly involve undue delay in the payment of amounts for land acquired by the Commonwealth. The Committee draws attention to the departure from the usual procedure set out in the Lands Acquisition Act 1955 which in most instances lends itself to the possibility of a speedy resolution of disputed claims. Insofar as there may be some extension of the time in which compensation is payable for land acquired under this Act, the Committee draws this provision under clause 17 to the attention of the Senate under clause 1 (a) (i) in that it might be regarded as trespassing unduly on personal rights and liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Of course, those points will be a matter of much more debate I am sure as we proceed with this Bill, particularly in the Committee stage. I reiterate that the Attorney-General in his second reading speech has not directed himself to the basic objections to the compensation provisions of the legislation. He has made some comments which do not meet the objections raised either in debate last week or by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The operation of section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution in relation to acquisition of property is, of course, highly relevant. It is always relevant to Commonwealth Government activities in the acquisition of property.

SPEECH.PARA: The view expressed by Senator Evans on this matter is nevertheless unsatisfactory to us in terms of our objections or our suggestions in relation to the Bill. I appeal to the Attorney-General to consider whether, in acceding subsequently in the debate to our request for amendment to the compensation provisions, his Bill is in any way damaged. We do not believe it is. We can only conjecture at the reasons the Government would have for not accepting that someone who claims he has had his land acquired should be able to proceed through the Federal Court, and, if necessary, subsequently go on appeal to the High Court. To make provision in the legislation for the Federal Court does not of course eliminate the High Court. We accept that in a number of instances there would undoubtedly be appeal to the High Court. But to cut out the Federal Court in most cases seems unreasonable and an unduly perverse attitude.

The Attorney-General claims that the Bill's arrangements for compensation are for the benefit of persons whose interests have not been affected by an acquisition of property in the strict sense but who would, nonetheless, have had some change in their position as a result of government action, for example, the employment opportunities that would be lost if the Gordon below Franklin scheme was stopped. If the thrust of the Government is successful in preventing the building of the dam it would always be open to the Commonwealth Government to enter into some negotiations with the Tasmanian Government and to make some offers which would achieve the purpose that Senator Evans outlined in his second reading speech. Acceding to the type of change we have requested to the legislation would not prevent the Government from doing that but would enhance other people's rights in other cases.

At the Committee stage I shall be moving a number of amendments which will be circulated to honourable senators very shortly. I will not canvass them in much detail at the moment because I am sure honourable senators are quite familiar with what happened in the other place. I want to highlight just one other set of amendments for a very particular reason-because they were not included in the amendments moved by the Opposition in the House of Representatives. This is a set of amendments which relate to the Northern Territory. The reason they were not included in the amendments moved in the House of Representatives was that it had not been realised that the Bill had some implications that have now been pointed out by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Today the Honourable Paul Everingham, Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, expressed some concern about the Northern Territory situation under this Bill and requested that we pay some attention to it. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard part of the text of a telex from Mr Everingham.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

It has just been drawn to my attention that the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill which I understand has already passed the House of Representatives and is being considered in the Senate tomorrow has the practical effect of creating a discriminatory approach to the Northern Territory which causes my Government great concern.

The practical effects in the Bill are in summary- (A) To ensure that the legislation would be valid in its application to the Northern Territory (the validity, or lack of it, in its application to the States is at least arguable in some respects);
(B) To enlarge the range of Northern Territory property (as compared with the States) which could be the subject of a proclamation by the Governor-General under clause 6 (3); and

(C) To deny any right of the Chief Minister to nominate a member of a commission of inquiry established to assess compensation in excess of $5,000,000 where operation of the Act amounts to an acquisition of property.
Aside from these effects it is perhaps even more significant that the Bill departs from the established practice to treat the Territory on a basis of equality with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —That document outlines the basis of the reasons for those amendments. I just say that there is no intention of ambushing anyone on these amendments; they were drawn to our attention very late. We thought the objection raised by Mr Everingham was well-founded. We have, therefore, moved in a fresh direction in our amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to seek from the Attorney-General, when he replies to this debate, some assurances about the Government's intention in relation to the legislation. It has been suggested to me that if the legislation is amended either the Government does not intend to proceed with it or it will not accept certain very reasonable amendments-in other words, it will attempt to hold the Opposition in this place to ransom on amendments which do not affect the Government's policy and which do not affect the main thrust of the Bill in a way that would make us appear to have a quite false attitude on the general issue of conservation. I think it is incumbent on the Attorney-General to indicate to the Senate when he replies to the second reading debate what the intentions of the Government are should this Bill be amended at all in the Committee stage.

The Senate is a House of review. It is always our right to seek to improve legislation. Governments of all persuasions seem to find that an uncomfortable situation to be in. It is never predictable how a government will react if a Senate, exercising its review function, quite reasonably moves to amend legislation.

Out of deference for the time available and the flow of the debate I intend to conclude my remarks now. Before concluding I move an amendment to the motion for the second reading, which I indicated earlier I would do. I understand that the amendment has been circulated. It is the same as the amendment moved in the House of Representatives, apart from a very small change in wording to meet the Standing Orders of the Senate. Accordingly, I move:
At end of motion add:
'', but the Senate-

(a) while recognising the need for adequate protection of areas placed on the World Heritage List, urges the Government to amend the Bill to take account of the need for individual listings to be the subject of a joint request by both the Parliament of the State which has made the application and of the Commonwealth; and

(b) is concerned that the Government has failed to develop adequate procedures for the provision of fair and reasonable compensation to States, corporations or individuals whose property may be the subject of proclamation under the Act''.
In conclusion I repeat that it is the intention of the Opposition not to do anything to impede this Bill going into the Committee stage so that we can attempt to improve it.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —State rights have been the main cry of the Tasmanian Liberal Government and most Federal Opposition members in Tasmania but there has been no recognition of the rights of the Tasmanian people to jobs or to information. The obligation of Australia under the United Nations Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage has been ignored. On 2 December 1982, as recorded in Hansard, Senator Peter Rae said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am supporting declared Liberal Party policy, which was a joint policy at the time of the Commonwealth and the State Liberal parties, which has never changed. But a unilateral about turn, without discussion, took place on the part of the State party which wants to take different action. I just make the point because it is part of the explanation of the difficult position and the sadness of the position in which I find myself. I find it particularly so when I hear the argument put about this being an invasion of States' rights. In the first place there was a joint policy in relation to this. In the second place Tasmania , through its lawfully elected Government, took certain steps which meant that, by necessary consequence, it had forgone rights which it might otherwise have had. It requested the Commonwealth Government to apply for World Heritage listing of the South West National Park.

Tasmanians are being misled by Mr Gray and his Liberal Party colleagues, both State and Federal. The actions and attitudes of Premier Gray have brought upon the people of Tasmania undeserved discredit and great distress. One must question the motivation of Mr Gray, his fellow Liberals and his associates. At present his close associate Mr Kelvin McCoy, President of the Organisation for Tasmanian Development, is in Bulgaria studying Marxist trade union philosophy. Yet we hear people in Tasmania accusing the Tasmanian Wilderness Society of being in receipt of communist money. The very facts can cause strange fantasies to arise. Tasmanians are people who want jobs. The people of Tasmania have been denied the unbiased and factual information to help them judge the situation at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. It is quite simple. The honourable senator who is speaking quoted me as recorded in Hansard but she did not define when she had ceased quoting me. I would like her to do so and to make it quite clear what were my comments that she was quoting and what were her own.

—I apologise. The honourable senator's speech ended with the words : 'It requested the Commonwealth Government to apply for World Heritage listing of the South West National Park.' The Liberal Party has been silent in Tasmania about the right of the Tasmanian people to control the exploitation of our resources. The people of Tasmania have not been given the right to know how many jobs will be provided by the energy produced by the proposed Gordon below Franklin Dam. They have the right to know what companies have been invited to set up in Tasmania, where they will set up, who owns them and whether profits will go to Tasmania, the mainland or overseas. The Tasmanian people have not been told what kinds of industries will be invited to Tasmania, whether they are environmentally safe and whether they will be of benefit to Tasmania in the long term or of benefit only to the Hydro-Electric Commission. The Tasmanian Chamber of Commerce states:

SPEECH.PARA: But above all Tasmanians must recognise that when it comes to attracting industry, we can't afford to be choosy. We must make every effort to attract any industry, or the expansion of existing industries for which long term viability exists.
The Australian Industries Development Association stated:

According to the 1977 Callaghan report, the structural problems of the state's economy were related to a number of factors including the highly decentralised nature of Tasmanian population and industry; an industrial strategy emphasising cheap energy which would within the foreseeable future reach the limits of generating capability; and an overall government approach which could not match incentives offered in other states, particularly payroll tax rebates and was unwilling to increase revenues from other government sources to increase its flexibility. There were other structural problems too; a greater reliance on exports than the other states, increasing Tasmania's vulnerability to external forces; an industry structure significantly different from the rest of Australia , with a declining manufacturing and mining sector and no compensating growth in the tertiary sector unlike other states; and an inappropriate industry strategy which had, by encouraging energy-intensive users, attracted industries with only low-linkages into the state's economy, reducing potential employment growth below that which might have resulted from other types of industry and incentive schemes, and in some cases, exacerbated regional dependence on a sole employer.

The Tasmanian people are entitled to have security as well as jobs. More and more people are realising that multinational companies and hydro- industrialisation do not ensure that security. Tasmania and the people of Tasmania are coming to realise that we need to find a new direction. At a seminar held last weekend at the University of Tasmania it was found that Tasmania must seek new economic directions if it wants a better position in the Federal system. The seminar was held by the Tasmania University Political Economy Society at the University. A report on the guest speaker, Dr Frank Stilwell, an Associate Professor of Political Economy at Sydney University, stated:
. . . an active partnership between small, co-operative, and private enterprises and the State Government must be developed.

It was the role of the Government to foster specialised, job-creating enterprises which showed potential in new industries or markets. He said the dependence on overseas-based companies which were energy and capital intensive, were no longer appropriate for Tasmania.

Firms such as Australian Paper Manufacturers Ltd, Repco Corporation Ltd, Temco Pty Ltd, Savage River Mines and Renison Bell and Consolidated Gold Fields Australia Ltd make decisions in boardrooms outside Tasmania which make Tasmanian workers redundant when there is a surplus of supply. We have the instance at Geeveston where APM was closed down, putting 128 families at risk. Since 1981 employment in the mining industry has dropped by 10 per cent yet electricity consumption has increased in some cases. Capital currently earmarked for environmentally harmful or resource wasteful projects could provide more social benefits and many more jobs if invested in alternative, environmentally sound activities. In Tasmania there are alternatives which could create jobs. Other sources of energy could be developed. There could be the development of wind and solar power and the conservation of energy by insulation, which of course the State Government has discouraged. Overseas countries offer incentives to consumers to conserve energy and so create further jobs. Bass Strait, only 70 kilometres from the shores of Tasmania, we are told has a trillion cubic feet of natural gas and could supply some of Tasmania's energy needs.

The Tasmania Government, with its concentration on the Franklin Dam issue, has failed to make urgently needed decisions in the areas of health, education and job creation. The Tasmanian Liberal Government has so far refused to reveal the findings of a report on the Hydro-Electric Commission's future role and pricing policies. The terms of reference include a proposal to establish a supreme energy authority. In the Melbourne Age on Monday, Kenneth Davidson made a number of comments about the economic situation in Tasmania. He pointed out that the zinc, paper and aluminium industries were in decline. The Tasmanian people need industries which consider the needs of the community and which have a viable, permanent future-a future for our children's jobs and for their security. In 1975 an agreement between the Federal Liberal Party and the Liberal Party in Tasmania was reached. The joint statement included these words:
The enlargement of the boundaries--
Of South West Tasmania-

will require sacrifice on the part of the Tasmanian State Government and the Tasmanian people in the national interest. In effect the Australian people will be asking them to forgo revenue that might otherwise flow from unchecked development of the area in order to preserve for the nation an area considered of immense national significance.
. . . we believe Commonwealth assistance to support the project should take two forms,

direct aid in preparing management plans and implementation of them and the provision of technical facilities and appropriate scientific personnel to assist in the maintenance program, a measure of compensation for development opportunities forgone in respect of electricity generation, mining and forests.
The report of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania stated:

Any decision to alter areas as significant as South West Tasmania should only be taken after an extensive examination of the alternatives and only when the decision makers are satisfied that there are no feasible and prudent alternatives. It is the Committee's view that this detailed examination has not been undertaken.

I believe that in the past the people of Tasmania have been very conscious of their natural environment and its value. As early as 1916, they started to declare Ben Lomond, Frenchman's Cap, Freycinet Peninsula, Hartz Mountains, Mount Field and many other such areas as of value. They are the treasured legacy of yesterday's men who, in truth, are still tomorrow's men. Given the more recent alienations, losses and threats, the balance sheet for Tasmania would have been considerably reduced had it not been for the vision of men such as Nicholls, Rodway, Weindorfer and Truchanas. They were men who loved the wild places of Tasmania and they recognised what was special and unique about them. They understood the importance of such places to the sanity of men and women. They sought to ensure that these places remain accessible in the form in which they found them and walked in them and that future generations are also able to find that peace and that naturalness that they found. How can we explain what wilderness means and why it is important? How do we convince someone that to diminish wilderness is to diminish part of man himself? It is very difficult, but at least we can say that in the wilderness-in the natural parts which man has not desecrated for greed-there is the opportunity to communicate with and to experience the wisdom that created it, and in doing that one is able to recreate a part of oneself.

The scientists of this space age have informed us the earth is an inexpressibly unique possession. In the entire solar system it alone possesses the water and oxygen sufficient to nourish a higher life, and every day in every part of the world we are destroying those support sources at an alarming rate. The environment should be destroyed or damaged only if it is to serve the needs of people. Yet so often today we find that economic greed-not the need of people-is being served. We live in a world which is becoming increasingly mechanised, noisy and crowded. Common sense tells us that it is not necessary to destroy the South West and the Franklin River in Tasmania, that there are other ways of providing energy and that there are many other ways of providing jobs. If people use the intelligence of our hearts and the finer sense that says that the economic aspect of the situation is not the only thing to be considered, we may be able to pass on things of value to our children.

Legislation in America allows concerned citizens to sue and to halt projects for which there has been no adequate environmental impact statement. This has provided the legal basis for effective citizens' action against numerous projects, including the Alaska oil pipeline, the Florida Barge Canal and the Everglades airport. Is it too much that the people of Tasmania have the same right to say that part of Tasmania is valuable to them and to their children? Is it not important that our children should realise that some things should not be destroyed for any reason that has an economic base? If the South West is destroyed a part of Tasmania will go, and it will take not only its own value but also part of the value of the dreams of our children and the things that they should be able to hold and realise as an example of what they are called upon to do in the future; that is, to protect this earth. I hope that the people in whose hands the future of the South West depends will use not only their common sense but also the finer sense with which men are endowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are very pleased to see the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983 before this new Parliament because the Bill is, of course, a development of the private member's Bill, the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill 1982, which I introduced into the previous Parliament and which indeed passed the Senate. The Bill asserts what seems to the Australian Democrats a clear principle: The use of the external powers of the Commonwealth provided in the Constitution to preserve and conserve national assets which have an acknowledged international value. We believe that one cannot have one's cake and eat it too. If a State is fortunate enough, as Tasmania is-as Queensland and New South Wales are-to have a region of such acknowledged value in its pristine state that it is on the World Heritage List, it should be willing to accept responsibility for maintaining it intact and undamaged for future generations. This, of course, is a respectable world view.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators who have been able to move around on the ground in Europe will understand that a country such as Holland, which is flat and uninteresting apart from its cities, and most parts of the world now, lack this kind of wilderness area. It is something that the planet has almost lost. Because of that, it must be cherished by the human race at large. People who have charge of a particular area have a particular and peculiar responsibility to take charge of it responsibly, not only on their own behalf but also on behalf of future generations. Those people who prate about State rights and the rights of a State to do whatever damage it likes to whatever it wants do not accept that responsibility. That is a very serious matter indeed to the Australian Democrats . If one does not accept that ground, one must take the view that it will be perfectly okay for a Queensland government-I do not say the present one, but let us say some future Queensland government-to say: 'We are very short of cement in Australia. We do not have any lime to make cement; therefore, we have enormous resources of cement-making facilities in the Great Barrier Reef and we will use them'. It is obvious that that government would feel, in the interests of the State, that this industry would produce income and jobs. Therefore, ipso facto, it should be done. That is the sort of argument that we hear brought forward time and again in the Senate to justify some sort of mitigation and limitation of this Bill or, in its most extreme case-I am referring to what this Bill is really about, that is, South West Tasmania-that it is perfectly all right to proceed not only with the dam but also with cutting down the trees and carrying out all sorts of commercial activities in that area, regardless of the fact that it is a World Heritage property.

Of what use is the external affairs power in the Constitution? What is the point of having a Federation, as we have in this country? What is the point of having a Commonwealth if it is not allowed to exercise reasonable rights? A State government may believe that a municipality or an individual, going down the areas of delegated power and responsibility, is wrong or that an individual' s interest conflicts with that of a municipality. If I build a house by the sea and I want to have a striped green, yellow and red roof, the council may say: ' You can't do that because it is affecting other people'. One could equally scream that that intrudes on my individual rights. That analogy would be just as valid and accurate as that used by people who say that not to be allowed to build a dam in South West Tasmania is an intrusion on Tasmania's State rights. That is absolute balderdash and should be freely acknowledged as such. The people of Tasmania, like the people of New South Wales and the people of Queensland, are, before anything else, Australians. If they are not, they are indulging in an un-Australian activity. They are despising and wilfully going against the views of the rest of their countrymen. I suggest that is not reasonably tolerable.

Of course States have rights. They should exercise them properly. They should be given the power to exercise them within the terms of the agreement between the States and the Commonwealth, which is perfectly clear and which states that matters that concern external affairs or any relationship with the rest of the world are matters for the Commonwealth to decide. That is as it should be. After all, if we did not have that situation, how would it be possible for the nation to deal in any kind of integrated or uniform way with the rest of the world? We might as well say that the States should usurp the defence powers of the Commonwealth, that if a State thinks that it is not provided with enough defence facilities-Western Australia might think that it wants more warships-it should say: 'No, we will have a treaty with Vietnam, Singapore and Indonesia which is separate from the Commonwealth'. The argument over this issue has debased itself to that level. The people putting forward that argument should look at it very carefully before they propose it again.

This Bill is designed ultimately to protect a number of properties as it proves necessary. The Australian Democrats see a considerable responsibility on the Government to ensure that this happens, since the Bill does not now confer automatic protection to all World Heritage properties. I know there may well be good reasons for that. But, be that as it may, it is a cause for considerable concern not only to the Australian Democrats but also, from the feedback I have received from the conservation movement and from many other individuals, to the people of this nation, the majority of whom do not want the dam built and the majority of whom, I suggest, would want all of the other World Heritage properties protected. We are not a poor country. We are not a country without resources. It is not necessary for us to destroy what is good and beautiful and what cannot be replaced. It is certainly not justifiable for us to do so on the specious, dishonourable, and unworthy ground that it might provide a few jobs for a few people for a few years. There are other means of providing jobs.

Many propositions have been put forward to the Tasmanian Government which would be viable and much more useful and flexible for the production of electric power if it wished to do so. That part of Tasmania has been assessed by international experts as possibly by far and away the best part of the world for the use of wind generators. This is not a possibility for the distant future. If we think that, we are back in Rip Van Winkle land. If we go to Hawaii and travel through the larger islands we will find that probably one-third of the properties-farms, businesses and so on-already use wind generators to generate power. There has been a large wind generator for many years on Oahu, the principal island. In Jutland, there is a wind generator that for years has been producing power in the megawatt range. Of course this could be done in Tasmania with much greater flexibility. I propose that if Tasmania wished to do so it could create a new industry to manufacture these machines in various sizes. This could be used to provide a source of power for Tasmania and would then be an export industry. This would be a very sensible approach to the jobs situation. It would not be a one-off case. All of the people will be out of work once the dam is finished. This industry could go on for decades and possibly generations. It would give Tasmania the new industry and the innovative technology which it really needs and which, in the meantime, would have had a genuine conservational effect.

The present Bill, of course, provides for proclamation only if and when a region is damaged. I can best illustrate our concern by referring to the Wallandra Lakes area in New South Wales. This beautiful area is at present under no threat whatsoever of damage from the present State and Federal governments. But if in the future a less conservation minded government were to come to power that area could be in considerable danger. The Governor-General, acting on the advice of this theoretical Federal government of the future, might well consider that a large, multi-storey casino-hotel complex, with tourist roads, tennis courts and a golf course, stuck in the middle of the region, would improve rather than damage it. Many people see this as a respectable point of view. Obviously, Mr Robin Gray in Tasmania does. He believes in development. By development he means that, regardless of any other consideration, one could take a piece of nature and turn it to one's purposes. In that case, of course that theoretical government would not proclaim the Wallandra Lakes under the Act and no further action could be taken. I suggest that, whatever reasons there are, this is still a dangerous gap in the Bill, one which at some stage must be filled, for the reasons which I have stated.

At present the Bill is concerned intimately with South West Tasmania. It is based on whether a hydro-electric scheme to generate 180 megawatts of power, at a cost estimated at as high as $1 billion, should be built on the Gordon River. There are two aspects which have a very close bearing on this matter. One is environmental and the other is economic. Environmentally, the Gordon below Franklin dam has become a bench mark issue of enormous importance in this country. That is as it should be. It is a sign of the progress of this community and this society that that is so. I think one of the most encouraging things about the world in which we now live, its great advantage over the generation which preceded it, has been the growth over the last two decades or so of a large area of opinion that some parts of this unfortunate planet should be pre- served intact and that the monkey-like quality of human beings that allows them to feel free to despoil and destroy anything in nature is no longer good enough. Indeed, that simian activity of the Hydro-Electric Commission has attracted the unfavourable attention of the majority of Australians. A number of polls have shown this to be the case.

One fears such organisations as the Hydro-Electric Commission, which may have many advantages commercially and in other ways but which lack the humanity of the individual person. Organisations of that kind, if they can be said to have a conscience at all, certainly have a much easier conscience than an individual human being might have. Whilst that may seem an obvious statement or a truism, I think it is something which is not always taken sufficiently into account. It is not enough to accept uncritically that a collective group of people hiding behind the facade of an organisation say that something should be so. Of course, the majority of Australians-some 55 per cent, I think, according to the latest poll-have not accepted the view of the Hydro-Electric Commission that there is any justification for this dam. The view of those Australians is quite simple. It has been expressed to me many times. There is no doubt about it. The dam project is regarded as a disgraceful and completely unjustified mauling of a pristine natural wonderland so highly regarded as to be part of the world heritage. This simple fact alone makes it necessary that this Bill be passed as soon as possible and an effective injunction sought from the High Court to stop all work on the dam project as soon as possible.

I used strong words when I said that the project was seen as disgraceful and completely unjustified. The word 'unjustified' brings me to the economic aspect. I could do worse than to quote more extensively the article mentioned by Senator Hearn-Kenneth Davidson's article in the Melbourne Age of 5 May. In deference to Senator Peter Rae I will try to get the quotations in the right place, even though it is not him that I am quoting. Mr Davidson said:
It is clear that mainland generosity is paying for that dam . . .

Compared with the other States, where the electricity commissions now have to borrow all their money for expansion on the open capital market, or from retained earnings which involves higher prices, the Hydro-Electric Commission gets about 20 per cent of its money for investment from the State Treasury, that is, largely from the mainland.
He continued later:
The HEC reckons it will need to meet a demand of 1200 megawatts of capacity by 1990, according to a forecast made in 1979.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you checked to see whether that is accurate?
—I am quoting Mr Davidson. I thought I made that clear to the honourable senator. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: According to an estimate made by the then Department of National Development and Energy in 1982-
This is accurate; I recall it quite well. In fact, it was before a committee, as Senator Walters may recall. Mr Davidson continued:
the demand in 1990 is more likely to be 1000 megawatts, which would postpone the need for the 170 megawatts of average generating capacity provided by the Franklin dam.

I think the point made there is abundantly clear; that according to the estimate of the Department of National Development and Energy of the last Liberal Government-not the present Government-the dam is not necessary. I would have thought that was a perfectly plain and obvious fact that might be taken more into consideration by people who speak to this issue. Mr Davidson further stated :
If the Franklin goes ahead, financed in part from excess funding from the Commonwealth, and the HEC has horrendous excess capacity in 1991 when Franklin is operational, what will Tasmania do?

A hydro power station is not like a thermal one. Particularly, all the costs occur irrespective of whether it is generating electricity or not. This means the HEC will hawk the electricity around the world, for whatever price it can get.
And whose throat will that cut? I hope by now you've guessed it. It will be the eastern State thermal stations . . .

If Mr Hawke has the national interest at heart he must tell Tasmania that irrespective of the High Court decision, excessive funding to Tasmania will be cut, and this will force the Government of Tasmania to look at the Franklin with a commercial, rather than an emotive eye.

This was not me speaking. I do not necessarily endorse that view but I will say that it is expressed by one of the most responsible economic commentators in this country. I will read on a little further. Mr Davidson said:

The fact is, Tasmania is ripping off the Federal system. According to the Grants Commission, Tasmania is getting about $60m a year more than it should from the central pool in order to maintain equality of service and equality of sacrifice with the standard States of Victoria and New South Wales.
This is a lot of money for a tiny State like Tasmania.

To get it in scale let us put it this way: As a senator for New South Wales I say, with all respect to Tasmania, that the total population of Tasmania is about the size of the total population of Blacktown and the surrounding western suburbs of Sydney. If the Mayor of Blacktown came to the Commonwealth asking for an additional $60m a year I think he would be told where he could go. There are other reasons why the extra $60m is allocated. All of us here know why that is so. Mr Davidson continued:
For instance, on the assumption that a decent job-creation scheme would cost $ 40,000 a year per job-
which is high-
that is 1500 jobs a year which the mainland is generating in Tasmania and which should rightfully belong on the mainland.
Or if the Tasmanians wanted to maintain the higher level of services now provided gratis by the mainland, it would involve an increase of $350 a year tax burden on each Tasmanian taxpayer.

I think that sets the matter in perspective. I do not necessarily agree with those points. I think there are good reasons why Tasmanians should have this additional assistance, but surely a place which is pleased to avail itself of this additional advantage from the rest of the community-for good reasons-might also feel that it has a certain responsibility to the rest of the nation. If it is good enough for it to take from the rest of the nation surely it is not unreasonable to ask it to give. I think it would be a very selfish person indeed who did not agree with that. I know perfectly well that those reasonable, responsible people in Tasmania-a place of which I am personally very fond and where I have many good friends-would agree with me on this matter and not with the troglodyte Tasmanian senators in this place who are interested mainly in confirming the power of a small grouping which occupies Parliament House in Hobart. That is really what they are on about. They are not on about the interests of Tasmanians in general at all. They are not interested in Australia. They are interested only in that little group of people who want to maintain their political hold on Parliament House in Hobart.

That is really what this debate is about and that is why we get the story we do from Tasmanian senators in this place. I think the people of Tasmania are reaonable, sensible people who listen to good sense, who understand and who are deeply concerned about the fact that they now have a Premier who is going ahead bullheaded with something which he knows perfectly well, which I know and which they know is dangerously uneconomic. I hope that in the light of these facts all this nonsense we have heard today and will continue to hear in this debate-I see there are about 18 speakers listed for the second reading debate-that all this garbage about State rights will cease. It is not a viable argument in this connection. I repeat that the States have rights; of course they do, but they also have responsibilities and duties to the nation as a whole.

There is a belief among the conservationists that the Hydro-Electric Commission is proceeding rapidly with damage to South West Tasmania because it is deliberately seeking that. I am told that there is a line of thought, which, if it exists, is stupid as well as dangerous, that if the High Court can be told that most of the damage has already been done, that the thing is so far advanced that the Commission might as well go ahead with it, the Court might rule against this Bill. I cannot believe that that is happening. I cannot believe that there are people, even in Tasmania, who would take such a cynical and unpleasant view as that. All I am saying is that there is a belief among conservationists that this is the case.

Appearances in politics and events are almost as important as facts and I think it is very important that this situation should be changed. If Mr Gray wanted to see that that talk ceased he would have a very easy way of doing it. He would say to the people of Tasmania: 'I want to go ahead with this dam but I am in conflict with the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth has brought forward regulations and is passing a Bill which will stop it. It is going to the High Court. I, as a practical, reasonable politician have to say to myself and to you that there is a good chance of this being stopped. Therefore, it is not in your interests that I go ahead and create damage in this area at your cost, at the cost of Tasmanians and other Australians'. That risk exists. If Mr Gray wants to show himself as a statesman who will be remembered for statesman-like qualities and who will have earned the respect of Australians generally, he will have to take only a very small step and say tomorrow that he will stop work on that project until this matter is resolved. I do not see that as an unreasonable request. I would be very interested to hear from honourable senators who differ with me why they think it is an unreasonable request. Of course it is reasonable. It should be done, and the sooner the better.

Today I have an update of the work that is actually going on at the dam site. This is one time that I wish the Senate were televised. If it were it might be possible to show people who are now listening on the radio pictures of the appalling damage which is being done in that area. I cannot begin to describe it . One glance at some of the photographs I have seen would make it quite plain to people that there is no question of this dam being built without damaging the region. As they say: One picture is worth a thousand words. I only regret that that cannot be done. I ask people wherever they see displays in conservation headquarters, through the Australian Conservation Foundation or through the Wilderness Society, to have a good look at them and see what damage is being done to that area. I ask them also to bear in mind what I said earlier: Quite likely this is being done to no good purpose but purely because some people have painted themselves into a pig-headed position from which they are too small- minded or too pig-headed to retreat.

The temporary camp at Warners Landing now, we understand, houses some 40 workers. There are bulldozers there and a roller. The Warners Landing position is being widened and extended, as is the road near the so-called temporary camp. We understand that heating is being put into the cabins there in the expectation , presumably, that work will go on all winter. The road between Warners Landing and the dam site will probably be completed by the end of this week. It is now less than half a kilometre from completion. We understand that work has been speeded up to get it finished so that other more destructive work can commence as soon as possible. I am told that myrtle trees estimated to be between three centuries and four centuries old are being destroyed every day in this area so this work can be carried out. The new drill site directly above the dam site is now some 65 metres in depth. The last drill hole, I understand, struck water. We understand that solid rock for the dam base has still not been located. The other regrettable situation about this is that it appears that all this work is going on without any real knowledge as to whether a dam can be built in that area sensibly or not. It appears from the preliminary audits of exploratory tunnels that the proposed site for the dam may not be suitable anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Their engineering is as bad as their economics.

—Senator Evans said that their engineering is as bad as their economics. If that is so, God help the people of Tasmania because they are likely to have not only a white elephant but also something which is dangerous and useless as well. I think there is good cause to investigate this and for the Premier of Tasmania to make some pretty positive statements about whether or not this project, which he makes so much of, is viable and what its cost really will be. It seems to the Australian Democrats that the prospect for Australia and especially for the Tasmanian people is one of a large immovable object being placed, at enormous cost, in an especially damaging way in a World Heritage area , one of the finest wilderness regions remaining in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to read from a letter which appeared in today's Bulletin. It is all the more appropriate because it was written by a Tasmanian, Mr H. Donald of Westbury. The letter, which is quite short, states:

A scratch across a record, a tear through the Mona Lisa, a stake through the human heart, or a dam in the wilderness affects one per cent or less of the total area. The end result in all cases is the same.

That is the letter in its totality. The analogy presented in the letter is abundantly sound and ought to be an answer to those who say that there is no reason why a proportion of this region should not be despoiled because there will be some left. People who say that have failed to understand, or are incapable of understanding, the attitude of those of us who want the Tasmanian wilderness preserved intact as an asset for future generations. It is something which the world is extremely short of and which cannot be replaced. Those apologists for the dam, for all I know, would be quite satisfied with a Mona Lisa with the nose torn off or the eyes defaced. Again I suggest that the analogy is a reliable one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters would draw a moustache on it.

—Senator Chipp, with all respect to Senator Walters I believe she is a good Tasmanian and in her heart of hearts is very concerned about this matter. I do not really think that Senator Walters wants the dam built. When she speaks to us later I hope she will say to us that she has listened to what we have said and after all this time her better nature, which is there within her, Senator Chipp, has triumphed and she will agree with us. We will see when she comes to speak on this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is because of the analogy of the Mona Lisa and the letter which I read from the Bulletin that I have said some very harsh things in the past on this subject ; that Tasmania, which is a well-loved and valuable part of Australia, is at present temporarily in the hands of barbarians. I say that again. The vandalism going on in South West Tasmania must be stopped and as soon as possible. Viewed from any point of view proceeding with the dam is an unmitigated disaster for Australia. It is a disaster environmentally and it is a disaster economically.

One more aspect of importance is the further rapid growth of new technologies for smelting aluminium. Honourable senators know that Tasmania has the second highest consumption of electricity in the world, not because every Tasmanian has four television sets and three refrigerators but because it takes an appalling amount of electric power to smelt aluminium by the old Bayer process. However, I have been in touch with one of the world's not too small corporations, the Mitsui corporation in Japan. I think everybody would respect that corporation's integrity and ability in research. It has patented in Australia a new blast furnace system for smelting aluminium using a catalyst which expert people with far more knowledge in this area than I have say is likely to be a goer. I have written to Mitsui. It is at the first pilot plant production stage. Mitsui says that it is putting vast amounts of money into it and that pretty soon it will be a goer, in eight or nine years' time-ironically enough just about the time the Gordon below Franklin Dam will be finished if, indeed, it proceeds. I do not believe it should proceed. I do not believe that it will proceed because of the reasons I have mentioned. It is my belief that even in government sources in Tasmania there will eventually be some sanity and some basic intelligence.

The point abut the Mitsui process is that it uses something like one-tenth of the electric power that the old process uses. So the last and most terrible prospect for this dam is that it will be built, will sit there as a great mass of steel and concrete, and in 9 or 10 years' time it will be a white elephant, utterly useless to anybody for anything, capable of generating electric power for which there is no use whatsoever.

Assuming, as I said earlier, that wind generators had been used collectively to provide this power if Tasmania really had to have it, they could be dismantled and sold and exported to Tasmania's profit. But the Gordon below Franklin Dam cannot be pulled down and dismantled. When it becomes a white elephant it will stay there forever. If it is built it will lie there for centuries as a momumental testimony to the stupidity and narrow-mindedness of people in this country who retreat behind the silly hedge of what they perceive as States' rights.

Finally, there are no better champions of genuine States' rights than the Australian Democrats. We are a party at all levels of government. We have members in State parliaments and we respect States' rights. There is no way in the world we would remove ourselves from that position. But this does not mean that peoples of different States can say: 'We are Tasmanians, we are Queenslanders, we are Victorians, we are New South Welshmen; we will do what we like with our little bit if Australia. We will mess up our backyard. To hell with you, you only live next door'. Because of that, I honestly and sincerely commend this Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983 and my attitude to it in the context of events that have developed over the last 18 months. The Senate will recall the Australian Democrats' World Heritage Properties Protection Bill which was mentioned tonight and which was passed on 14 December last year. That was a Bill for an Act to give effect to the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. It was, therefore, limited to the World Heritage Convention. In the second reading debate on that Bill I said that I agreed that Australia must abide by the terms of conventions into which it had entered. However, the Government at that time was considering the action that it should take to protect South West Tasmania. It accepted its obligation with regard to identification and we understood that at that time Cabinet was determining what steps it would take. Therefore, I argued at the second reading stage of that Bill that it was inappropriate that it proceed at that time. However, it did proceed and I, therefore, voted against it.

SPEECH.PARA: On 8 December the now famous ministerial statement on South West Tasmania was put down. In that statement the Government stated that it desired the listing to proceed and noted the qualities of the South West. I quote briefly from that statement. It noted:

. . . the Government's firm belief in the international importance of this area and its outstanding biological and cultural qualities which have been recognised by its inclusion on the Register of the National Estate. Here I would make special reference to the archaeological sites, the Huon pine habitat, the temperate rainforest and the other unique features of this area.

The statement went on to say that the Government did not intend to intervene in the construction of the dam-that is after stating the qualities that I have just mentioned-and then added a somewhat amazing statement in which it accepted the flooding but said that it would nevertheless endeavour to preserve the caves. I quote those few lines from the statement:

Whilst Fraser Cave and other caves of archaeological significance will be flooded by the dam, I am advised by Mr McVeigh that every endeavour will be made to preserve this important part of our heritage.

Of course, that was an amazingly inconsistent statement and, as far as I was concerned, was an abdication of the Government's responsibility under the international heritage convention. So when the third reading of the Democrats' Bill subsequently came on I voted in favour of it. The site, of course, was duly listed on 15 December of last year. It is interesting to note the observations given by the listing authority at that time. These are the observations in relation to the effect of the dam:

The committee is seriously concerned at the likely effect of dam construction in the area on these natural and cultural characteristics which make the property of outstanding universal value in particular, and consider that flooding of parts of the river valleys would destroy a number of cultural and natural features of great significance as identified in the IUCN and International Council for Monuments and Sites Report.
We recommend to the Australian society to take every possible measure to protect the integrity of the site.

That is a highly respected international body which has made that statement. Somewhat embarrassingly the body had to continue to suggest that Australian authorities should ask the World Heritage Committee to place the property on the list of world heritage in danger until the question of dam construction was resolved. Basically the list of world heritage in danger concerns those countries which, for reasons of lack of resources, are unable to protect through their own ability sites that appear on the World Heritage List. I regard as highly embarrassing the fact that this body should suggest to Australia that perhaps it should consider putting South West Tasmania into that category. On 19 January of this year the Government did attempt to make co-operative federalism work. It did so in a statement which I applaud. The Senate will recall that that is the statement in which the Fraser Government made a considerably generous offer to Tasmania. I will quote from two small sections of that statement:

The Commonwealth is prepared to provide a grant of the full capital cost of a modern environmentally-clean, coal-fired power station in Tasmania to generate an amount of electricity equivalent to that which would be generated as a result of damming the Gordon below the Franklin. Further, if it is necessary in order to reduce the cost of thermal power to that of hydro power, the Commonwealth will guarantee to provide on an annual basis a share of the cost of coal (which might be needed to be in the order of 40 per cent) for the life of the power station. . . . The Commonwealth's offer, estimated to cost around $500m at present day prices, comprising $250m for the capital and $250m assistance in meeting the cost of coal, would mean that additional electrical power would be available to Tasmania at the same price as if the Gordon below Franklin were dammed.

Unfortunately, although this was an attempt to involve all Australia in paying for the cost of preservation, it was astonishingly dismissed out of hand. Of course, a change of government occurred in early March. Then the new Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sent a letter to the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, on 18 March 1983 confirming the commitment of his Government in relation to this matter. In a small section of that letter he said:

. . . we repeat our commitment to: ensure the long term energy needs of Tasmania are met; assist in developing a regional economic plan aimed at both short and long term employment needs; and assist the development of a South West Tasmania Management Authority.
Of course, that offer was also rejected by Premier Gray. On 28 March, not long later, Prime Minister Hawke wrote again to Premier Gray. In the letter he said:
In our view the people of Tasmania want:
guaranteed energy supplies to cover both the present and future needs;
equivalent employment opportunities; and
the resolution of this conflict.
These legitimate objectives can only be attained by discussion and negotiation.

We call upon your Government as an act of good faith to declare a moratorium on the current works on the Gordon below Franklin and to commence discussions with my Government on alternative power and employment initiatives.

I know that that letter did not set out specifics but it was clearly an offer to negotiate something that I believe Tasmania really wants and needs. Again, unfortunately, that was rejected out of hand. That leads us to 30 March of this year when the Federal Government made regulations under section 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act purporting to prohibit construction works. Then unfortunately we had the foolish and antagonistic move on the part of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to send the Royal Australian Air Force to Tasmania to gain evidence for the Commonwealth's case.

The Government then introduced this new Bill designed to give it maximum opportunity to succeed, but going far beyond its obligations under the World Heritage Convention. Queensland joined Tasmania in the action. The Labor States fell in behind the Federal Government. So we have in place a classic constitutional confrontation and a tragic and absolute failure of co-operative federalism. Why is it a tragedy? The answer is that all thinking Australians should want to protect South West Tasmania in the same way as Kakadu National Park, the Willandra Lakes Region, the Great Barrier Reef and the Lord Howe Island group-the other four listed Australian assets.

The western Tasmanian wilderness national parks area covers a large part of one of the last remaining temperate wildernesses in the world. As such, its flora and fauna deserve much greater scientific investigation. Its archaeological significance is rapidly growing in stature. Although I have not time on this occasion, I commend to honourable senators the formal nominaton to the World Heritage Commission which details the justification for including this particular area on that highly prestigious international list. In terms of the Convention itself, by simply presenting the land area to the international body both the Commonwealth Government and the Tasmanian Government claimed it to be a natural and cultural heritage of outstanding universal value. Therefore, I would have thought it was almost unthinkable that any government of Australia would condone at least its partial destruction. However, I accept that there will often be a clash of interests between preservation of a natural resource and the commercial development of that resource, and that in assessing development programs there must be a balancing of the resource as part of the natural heritage and the value to be obtained from exploiting that resource in some other way.
