For example, with the milling of native forests, a value must be attached to both resources, the natural on the one hand and the commercial on the other. To some extent those values will be subjective, and on some occasions both can be accommodated. That assessment goes to the heart of our national park network.

I invite the Senate to forget for a moment the obligations that exist under the international convention, which I will get to in a little while, and to look at that weighing process in relation to South West Tasmania. On the one hand, something is accepted as being of outstanding universal value. On the other hand , there is a large dam and a small power station capable of producing about 180 megawatts of power with a number of claimed advantages. The paramount claimed advantage is a cost advantage. I spent about 15 months as a member of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania looking principally at the question of demand for power in Tasmania and alternatives for supplying that demand. The Committee concluded that there was no need from a demand point of view to commence on a major option for at least three years, if at all-the major options being either a coal-fired thermal plant, interconnection with Victoria or the Franklin-Gordon-King integrated or separ- ated schemes-and that contrary to popular belief in certain demand scenarios interconnection with Victoria may not be more expensive than hyrdo-produced power. If we add to the offer of the Fraser Government which offered, as I clearly stated some time ago, to compensate for any additional cost of a coal-fired power station-the offer that has since been made by the Hawke Government-there appears to be no cost advantage to Tasmania at all in proceeding with this project. In fact, it can be said that the offers that have been made are extremely generous.

Also to be weighed on that side of the scales, it is suggested, are the short term jobs that will be maintained through the construction of this dam. That was also covered in the letter of Prime Minister Hawke. I remind the Senate that the jobs being spoken of are short term jobs and that various other small dam alternatives have been identified and were referred to in the Senate report on South West Tasmania, as were the sites upon which the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania has already done a great deal of work. With the right attitude much of the work force could be moved to these alternative sites which do not have the same conservation value. It is also suggested on that side of the scales that if one looks to a coal plant there is the problem of greater pollution. That is technically correct but, I may suggest, not so significant in relation to the size of the small plant of which we are speaking, which is really a minute plant in comparison with coal-fired thermal electricity producing plants. It would also be a plant with modern technology, which has gone a long way to reduce the significance of pollution. Of course, if the interconnection possibility were proceeded with there would be no further pollution in Tasmania whatsoever. Therefore, very little is balanced on the one side against that natural resource which is accepted to be of outstanding international value on the other.

I address the question of whether a compromise could work. The dam cannot be built without the destruction of the Fraser Cave. We know that there have been suggestions that the cave could be in some way transported to another site. This was suggested by a consultant to the Tasmanian Government. This suggestion was taken up by the Committee with Professor Mulvaney and Dr Rhys Jones, archaeologists of great note in Australia. I quote one line by Dr Jones which appears on page 1748 of the transcript of the proceedings of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania. When the question of whether that possibility existed was put to him, he answered:
. . . But once you have removed material out of a context it loses its value.

So that suggestion does not appear to be an open alternative. There is no dispute that the building of the dam will destroy a large area of the wilderness . I have quoted from the international body its reaction to that destruction.

We do have a Convention and obligations under it. Australia is a party to that Convention. Under Article 4 of the Convention the obligation is quite clear: The obligation is upon the party to the Convention to ensure the identification, protection, conservation, presentation and-I particularly ask honourable senators to note-transmission to future generations of the cultural and natural heritage that has been identified. Under Article 5 of the Convention there is an obligation, insofar as it is possible and appropriate, for each country even to take such legal measures as are necessary to protect, preserve and transmit that heritage. If the Commonwealth cannot act constitutionally and exhausts its negotiating power, clearly it is not in breach of the World Heritage Convention because, as we are often reminded in this chamber, we have a Federation.

The Federal Government does not have all powers within the legislative arena. It does have the powers enumerated in section 51 of the Constitution. It does have the so-called implied national power. After Koowarta's case, to me it is quite legitimate for the Commonwealth to claim power under the external affairs power, placitum (xxix). The power has to be interpreted in circumstances of contemporary Australia, not the Australia of 80 years ago. The High Court may find that it is not prepared to extend the power further but on the basis of the Koowarta case I can see no reason whatsoever why the Commonwealth should not legitimately claim that power. It can also legitimately argue that it has power under the 'other races' power, placitum (xxvi). It is certainly arguable that it has power under the 'implied national' power. In fact, I see that as particularly appropriate, because assets such as South West Tasmania are primarily Australian assets, the preservation of which all Australians should have an interest in. However, I accept that primarily land use is a State affair . But when we have a unique national asset of outstanding universal importance it becomes a national asset. If it is to be preserved for all Australians, all Australians have to bear the cost. If a State government determines to destroy it, all Australians have the right to expect the national Government to take whatever legal action is open to it to preserve that asset. I believe that it would be grossly negligent for the Commonwealth Government to fail so to act. But it should never occur because anyone would normally expect the State Government to bend over backwards to achieve the same aim.

If the Tasmanian Government determined to proceed despite all offers made, the action by the Federal Government to protect appears to me to be totally legitimate. It is not the desirable course. The desirable course would have been co-operative federalism. But I regret to say that it appears that Premier Gray has acted with a blind determination to build this dam. I regret saying that because when this matter of South West Tasmania is over I am confident that he will offer good government to Tasmania. I was most impressed during the recent National Economic Summit Conference to hear his speech, which could be themed as getting Australia ready for taking off, his calling for greater confidence and a more positive approach. I thought it was an excellent speech. In the future I have no doubt that he will offer good government. But the matter of South West Tasmania seems to have blinded his direction for the moment

Will legislation to destroy listed areas destroy the Federation? Of course, the answer is no. The High Court of Australia will determine whether the legislation is within the powers. That is how the Federation is designed to work and that is how it is working in this instance. It follows that an Act under which the Commonwealth acts to protect a world heritage listed asset will receive my enthusiastic support. But at this stage I must register my bitter disappointment . The World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill purports to go far beyond what is necessary to achieve that purpose. Clause 6, sub-clause (2) paragraph (a) of the Bill would have been sufficient to have done so. But under the present provisions that the Senate has before it, the Commonwealth could take action where conservation is a matter of international concern 'for any reason'. That is a practically boundless provision. The Commonwealth can take action whenever it appears 'peculiarly appropriate' to do so. I do not know what that means. Further, the Commonwealth can take action to protect whenever it can get an advantage or benefit under a treaty by doing so. What a mysterious provision that is.

I have to stand by how I vote. I am not prepared to vote for such ambiguous and open-handed clauses. I accept that we must go up the road of protection of unique national assets that are not necessarily of universal value. But let us have an open debate on that subject, not an attempt to get it through this Senate under the guise of something else. I do not know why the Government has gone so far with this legislation or why it has drawn it in such wide, vague and ambiguous terms. Some people have suggested that it is part of some expansionary scheme of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. I do not know the answer to that. But certainly the form of the legislation arouses suspicion. It is certainly disappointing to me because unless the Bill can be cut back to the real issue I cannot support it at its third reading, as I desired to do.

The obligation is to transmit to future generations. I have no doubt that if we destroy South West Tasmania, we will be condemned, and rightly so, by future generations for our short-sighted, narrow-minded selfishness. In fact, it is not even selfishness on the basis of the matters that I have put before the Senate tonight which indicate that there is no financial advantage to Tasmania whatsoever. It is not selfishness; it is foolishness. Let us put the Bill in a form that all of us who accept our responsibilities to all Australians can support so that we can act responsibly for the benefit of not only those in this nation today but also future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983 has been introduced to provide for the protection and conservation of places in Australia or under Australian control that are recognised as part of the natural or cultural heritage of our world, not just our country. I think it is interesting to note that, over recent years, there has been an enormous increase-already alluded to by Senator Mason-in awareness of the values that we want to place on things on this planet. This has shifted considerably from what it was in, let us say, the time of our parents. We are now looking at people in our community who place a lot of value on the need to preserve certain areas and sites, not only for ourselves but for the world and our children. One of the things to which this Bill addresses itself is, if you like, adding to the list of the wonders of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was a child there were seven wonders of the world. I never did know them ; I still could not tell honourable senators what they are. But I think we are now saying that there are many wonders in our world. The Leaning Tower of Pisa is one of the wonders that I recall, but I never knew where the Hanging Gardens of Babylon were. I think one of the things that colour the way in which we now look at the wonders of the world is that we do not just want our community to vote for technological advances or wonders. We unashamedly commend things such as the Sydney Opera House or the Taj Mahal. I am sure that people are very pleased to celebrate those mighty technological advances. But at the same time people are placing a great value on things other than technological advances. They are now saying that there is a great value in preserving bushland.

There are many examples of this in Australia. Already areas are preserved which are not on the World Heritage List but which are regarded with great favour by Australian people. In South Australia we have the preservation of what is called Flinders Chase on Kangaroo Island. A large part of that island is natural bushland, as it ever has been. I know that not only South Australians but all Australians are delighted that that piece of original Australian bushland remains. If any honourable senators ever have the chance to visit Flinders Chase they will find pens there to keep in the people and to keep out the animals. Humans are seen as intruders or temporary visitors. Another of the places that are on the World Heritage List or are on record as places of value in this country is Lord Howe Island. We are now talking about South West Tasmania. But other places in our world, such as the Grand Canyon in the United States of America, are not places of technological advance. In fact, the Grand Canyon is probably an ancient place with no technology but only that which has been performed by natural world forces, such as volcanoes and rivers.

To return again to Australia, there are places such as the south coastland of Victoria, the rain forests of eastern Australia and the Flinders Ranges in South Australia. Any number of arguments will now be advanced to support the preserving or maintaining of these places unspoilt, as it were. There are places which some people regard as areas of peace and perspective-places to which people can withdraw and put into perspective their lives in the cities. These are temporary places for people. There are also places that allow the preservation of our native flora and fauna. One thing that is most singular about Australia-in fact, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, Mr John Brown, drew it to our attention last week-is the animal life in this country. Although the Minister is wont to say that there is more about Australia that is marvellous than our kangaroos and koalas, they are very distinctive to this continent and I think they are things that all Australians unashamedly want to see preserved.

Other arguments that people advance for the preservation of such areas become more specific. We hear people talking about the need to preserve our ozone layer and to maintain a sufficient amount of oxygen in the atmosphere. One of the most important arguments for the preservation of rain forests embraces those two points. In fact, the rain forests in this world have been savagely reduced, to the point where they are worrying those people who understand such things as ozone layers. I admit to being one of those people who do not really understand what constitutes an ozone layer or what will happen if we do not have it. But I believe the evidence from people in a position to know who say that these things are most important to continuing life on our planet.

There are other arguments in terms of environmental protection about what is on the ground rather than what is in the atmosphere. Other people advance very strong arguments along anti-pollution lines. What we see now, though, is a huge number of people in our world who are aware of an increasing amount of evidence. They are beginning to realise the significant price we have paid for the advances in our society-advances that we want and that all of us are working for -and I think we have come to a time when people will say: 'We want these advances in perspective, not mindless advances, not chopping down every tree and not destroying our atmosphere'. This argument is entirely different from what would have pertained 100 years ago or more when people in this country would have said: 'We need shelter. We need to chop down trees to build houses and protect ourselves. We need shelter to survive in this primitive country'.

That argument has changed completely. One of the persuading things about it is the number of people who buy the argument now. We have a common view that we need to preserve our heritage. We need to preserve not only our flora and fauna, our ground spaces and wildernesses but also our past or at least places where we can find evidence of our past. Much, of course, is still unknown to us, but we seek a lot for our future by looking at and discovering our past. This points to the significance of the archaeological sites in the South West Tasmanian region. Not only will they tell us about ancient peoples in this world, but they will also tell us much more about the Aboriginal people and their culture and heritage. I am sure all Australians, not only Aboriginal Australians, will be interested in knowing that.

It could be said, I suppose, that this is an argument in favour of the luxury of knowledge but I think many people will support it. I certainly do. The various aspects of the argument, as I am puting it, must not be ignored and will not be ignored by this Government. The interesting thing is that the Opposition in fact agrees. In particular, it believes in the force of this argument in relation to the South West Tasmanian area. I will quote from an editorial in the Australian on 3 April 1983. It states:

Most Australians do not believe the proposed dam should be built. There are powerful environmental arguments against the dam. They are strengthened by anthropological significance of the area which would be flooded.

The economic case for the dam is certainly not so strong-many experts would argue that it is remarkably weak-as to tip the balance in favour of the destruction of a rare and precious area of natural beauty.

The point that I emphasise in the editorial in the Australian is the claim that most Australians do not believe that the proposed dam should be built. Further to the points I have been making, the Sydney Morning Herald on 22 April 1983 refers to Mr Cohen's speech in the House of Representatives in support of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill. The article states:
He pointed to a growing international awareness of heritage values and a 'sense of concern and shared responsibility for the protection of the cultural and natural heritage.' . . .
This bill is to provide a means of protection of last resort . . .

The point I stress is that many people are aware of the importance of a natural heritage. There are a number of references in the Age on 6 May 1983 indicating the Opposition's support for this position. An article written by Simon Balderstone states:
The controversial World Heritage Bill passed through the House of Representatives last night, with members of both sides expressing strong anti- dam feelings.
The Leader of the National Party, Mr Anthony, said that he did not want the dam built . . .
He did go on to say, however, that the debate was about State rights. The article continues:
Dr Edwards (NSW) said . . . many MHR and senators from the Opposition were strongly opposed to the dam and were convinced, as he was, that most Australians did not want the dam to proceed.
Dr Edwards said the attitude was broad-based. 'It is not just the 'greenies', as some so vociferously proclaim, who hold that view' . . .
He said many, if not a majority, of Liberal members in the NSW Parliament held the view, as did the Young Liberal movement and the Australian and New Zealand Academies of Science.
A Liberal frontbencher, Mr Ruddock (NSW) said he was also against the dam.
The former Minister for Environment, Mr Wilson (Lib. SA) spoke at length on the wilderness and heritage values of south-west Tasmania, said the bill was 'very bad' because of its wide powers.

The quotes from those newspaper cuttings are evidence of what we do know; that is, that many members on the Opposition benches are also totally opposed to the dam being built. Their problem, which I will come to, is the nature of the Bill. We know from the last election and from any number of polls that the people of Australia, as well as the politicians of either side, are in opposition to the dam. I will quote from the Adelaide Advertiser of 19 February 1983 which refers to Dr Bob Brown. It captures another perspective which I think is relevant to the broader Australian populace. It states:

As a politician he is determined 'to see the Franklin River running free, and to preserve a heritage which is more pressing than today's major issues, the only issue in this election which is going to affect the lives of Australians 100 years from now.' . . .
The Franklin River is more than a fight for a wild river in a beautiful country -it is a fight against technological over-kill which is engulfing the industrial world . . .

We need a sociological awakening in the general human section of what is going on on this planet if we are going to have this golden age where sanity prevails and we use technology to make life great.

Dr Brown captures a very important range of attitudes that many Australians hold . Many people are confused by economic arguments and arguments by the Hydro- Electric Commission in terms of power but they are very well aware of what they want in terms of the preservation of the beauty of this country.

I also want to comment on the number of young people I know-young can be anywhere from 15 years to 70 years or certainly 15 years to 50 years-who have found themselves so caught up by this issue that they have gone to Tasmania, risking arrest or choosing to be arrested. They have done this at their own cost because of a very passionate commitment to the preservation of this very beautiful area. This captures too another very important dimension; that is that in this deeply troubled time of recession in Australia any number of young people found this as a cause of optimism, something to which they could attach their ideas and ideals. They went to South West Tasmania much in the vein that here was something beautiful about which they could take a stand. They could be part of it and do something instead of sitting around with very little to do and certainly very little optimism.

The whole question of support for the Heritage Bill and listing of this beautiful area of Tasmania is not new. The idea of world heritage listing is something Australia has been involved with since the origin of the World Heritage Convention in 1975. Australia was one of the first countries to support and be involved in that Convention. In 1981 the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser , opened the Fifth Meeting of the World Heritage Committee in Sydney. He gave an address entitled 'Australia's Heritage' in which he referred to the Convention as 'an important milestone in the modern history of man's concern not only for his environment, but also for his cultural roots and origins'. He said that the whole concept was good not only for individual people but also for the whole of mankind and was surely a profound expression of co-operation between people and a willingness to share. We have the record of the Opposition's support for the ideas and ideals of the World Heritage Committee. We have on record its opposition to the dam. We even have its offer of compensation for any loss accruing to Tasmania in terms of potential from the building of the dam, which was so well spelt out by Senator Hill. The big difference between this Government and the Opposition is still what this Government is prepared to do to make sure that this Tasmanian wilderness is preserved. The Government's intention in introducing this Bill is to enable the preservation of that area to be guaranteed. Of course, the Bill not only addresses itself to South West Tasmania, it also addresses itself to any heritage area designated in Australia. But the legislation has the immediate effect of supporting the Government's action and claims for South West Tasmania.

Sometimes the Opposition argues that the question is one of States rights and whether the Federal Government can intervene in the affairs of a State on such matters. I do not think this Government flinches from that business. Although this Government is on record as supporting States rights, as is the Opposition, this Government is also prepared to say that governing is about right minded people drawing distinctions and trying to define what is the exact issue of debate in this chamber. The Government does not flinch from saying that that is what it is about. A general principle may be involved but in this case the Government's view will be different. There have been other examples or precedents and sometimes I am quite surprised at the Opposition's claim that there has been no precedent of this sort. I would have thought that the seeking of oil exploration licences in the Great Barrier Reef area would have been one such example.

If the Tasmanian Government had acted to protect its wilderness, as listed on the World Heritage List, there would have been no need for any consideration of the Federal Government acting in this way to protect this area. This Bill, as people have often claimed, is a means of protection as a last resort. Australian do not want the dam. This Government has introduced this Bill to give effect to that wish of the Australian people. I will not go into the arguments for why this area should be listed in great detail. Again I think they have been very well spelt out by previous speakers. In summary, however, I say that it is a temperate forest wilderness area of great beauty. It has its own special flora and fauna. Most important, I think, are the archaeological findings in the caves . These caves were discovered only very recently and exploration has not really commenced. However, they show evidence that Australian man has been on this continent for perhaps 20,000 years. Other evidence seems to suggest that he has been here for 40,000 years. This throws open all previous evidence about humankind on this planet and that treasure is actually in Australia. I think that for that reason alone we should preserve this area.

The other major argument against the preservation of this area as a heritage area or for continuing with the dam is the argument advanced by the Hydro- Electric Commission, and now the Tasmanian Government, about the need for power and jobs. I cannot actually make a clear case one way or another. I have heard Senator Mason speak about the evidence. He seems to suggest that there is not a good case for the need for electricity, as claimed by the Hydro-Electric Commission. On the evidence I am prepared to say that I do not care whether the Hydro-Electric Commission is right, whether all its estimates for power are as it says they are and whether all the jobs the Commission is prepared to provide are as it says. Even if that is the case, I think the crunch question with which we are faced is whether, in the face of that evidence, we will still act to preserve the wilderness and that rich heritage that is in South West Tasmania. I think it almost becomes a question of whether one would consider damming the Grand Canyon. I suppose that in some ways Australians still flinch from thinking that they have a richness or a wealth in their country of the calibre of the Grand Canyon. I find that that is how I can make a judgment on this matter. In the face of all the evidence for electricity needs and jobs I would still come down on the side of preserving that South West Tasmanian richness.

On many occasions our Government has supported States rights and it has given Tasmania every chance to preserve its rights. It has even offered-as did the previous Government-to compensate Tasmania for electricity needs, alternative dams and job creation schemes. Finally the Government recognised that it had to act in the face of Premier Gray's stand and opposition to that offer. This Government has decided in favour of the majority of the Australian people and for an Australian treasure. Unlike Senator Hill I would say that this Bill is a thoughtful piece of legislation which will provide for the protection and conservation of other Australian treasures besides this one. As has been stated before, it will be necessary to use the legislation enshrined in this Bill only if and when it is required. Many of the areas I listed earlier in this debate do not need world heritage legislation to protect them. Local governments and State governments have already acted to preserve those treasures.

Finally, this Bill enables us to honour our international agreements so that we can be held to be responsible in the international arena. I refer honourable senators to a quote of Mr Wran which appeared in the Australian of 6 April 1983. Mr Wran claimed that this is a 'national issue with international ramifications' . The article reported Mr Wran as saying:
If Australia wants to be in the real world of international affairs then we have to accept our international obligations.
This Bill is one piece of legislation-one act of this Government-which the people of Australia elected us to effect. We will honour that election promise. We support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am fascinated by the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is still talking about his Government of conciliation and consensus and bringing Australians together. What rubbish! It is the first time in the history of Australia that, less than a month after taking power, a Federal government has taken a State to the High Court of Australia and has used the armed forces to gather secret evidence to use in that law case against a State.
—Good on you Shirley; give it to them.
—Senator Grimes had better be quiet because he is really in a lot of trouble back home. Senator Tate, Senator Hearn and Senator Coates are also in real trouble. I will come to that in a few minutes.
—Tell us about the trouble. What trouble?
—You two really scrambled in in the last election, fighting over the last two places on the ballot paper.
—Order! Senator Walters will address the Chair.
—I am not the only person who thinks that the Prime Minister, Mr Bob Hawke, had better watch himself. The editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 8 March stated:

SPEECH.PARA: A major constitutional crisis is really not a good way to kick off a government committed to consultation and unity.
The editorial went on to state:
But there must be a limit to the extent to which the Commonwealth can enter into international agreements in order to override the States.
It also states:
If Mr Hawke is really committed to reconciliation he will have to forget about using a legal bludgeon to bring Tasmania into line.
That article finally states:
What we may end up looking at is not the price of the dam and its alternatives but the price of living in a true federation and maintaining States rights within it.

Labor senators opposite-Senator Coates and Senator Grimes are the only two Tasmanian senators present-may be interested if I mention a few comments made by unionists back home. One comment is: 'Big union ditch ALP over S-W policy'. The Australian Workers Union said that it would not reaffiliate until the Federal Labor Party changed its stance on the dam. Yesterday it was reported in the Examiner newspaper that two more unions, the Amalgamated Metal, Foundry and Shipwrights Union and the Electrical Trades Union, both challenged their presidents because they were taking too much political power into consideration and those unions did not like their executives' attitude in relation to the Gordon below Franklin Dam. Those two unions are standing people against the executive in our State. Three unions are reprimanding Federal Labor senators, saying: 'For God's sake stick up for your State. Do the decent thing'. What do they do? They are caucused. They are not sticking up for their State. They are not sticking up for their true supporters. If they had had the courage-which they surely did not-to electioneer down in the South West and in Tullah as we did then they would have realised what the people there were thinking. We got 62 per cent of the votes in those areas. Having held discussions with Mr Hawke, a report from the Combined Union Council at Tullah states:
He is adamant that NO DAM will be built on the Gordon River. In our estimate-
This is the Combined Union Council at Tullah-
He offered no viable alternative to that scheme.

We might well wonder why this new Government has decided to act in this way. Its theme is bring Australia together and yet it is taking our State of Tasmania to the High Court of Australia within the first couple of weeks of Parliament meeting. We may well ask why the Prime Minister is acting in this way. He has hoodwinked all his back bench members. They have not bothered to really look at what that man is doing. He does not just want to stop the dam. He has tried to convince them, and the Australian population, that all he is interested in doing is stopping the dam being built in Tasmania. He has told the back benchers: 'Don 't worry, we will gather a few votes this way, so all play it cool and we will stop the dam'. What that man is really about is a grab for power from the States . We only have to look at the Boyer Lectures in 1979 when Mr Hawke said:
I believe . . . that Australians would be better served by the elimination of the second tier of government-that is, the States-
He believes in the abolition of the States-

Which no longer serve their original purpose, and act as a positive impediment in achieving good government in our current community. This would give us, like the great majority of other countries, one Parliament with powers available to the government to match the responsibilities upon it of protecting and advancing the interests of Australian citizens.

The back bench had better wake up to its leader because he is not stopping the dam, and this legislation before the Senate proves it beyond a doubt. I will come to that in a few minutes. It has been said that we do not need the power. This has been said by everybody outside Tasmania who has no knowledge of whether we need power. On Thursday 24 March a newspaper article in relation to the Electrolytic Zinc Co. stated:
The Electrolytic Zinc Co. at Risdon said yesterday that it could increase production by a further 10 per cent.
This could be done if it could have cheap electricity and if it did not have to use Bell Bay. The article continued:
. . . Mr Reg Barker, said that for the past year, the plant had been operating at only 90 per cent of capacity.

If the company had further cheap hydro-power it would be able to expand and use the full capacity of its work force. The Australian Newsprint Mills has also said that expansion hinges on power. The Mercury states:
A multi-million dollar expansion program at Australian Newsprint Mills at Boyer hinges on the company being able to obtain adequate electricity at reasonable cost.

Mr Acting Deputy President, how far would honourable senators like me to go? Would they like me to go on and mention a few more industries in our State which want more electricity? Mr Risby also said that he needs more power to expand. He would use it to increase his exports. Let us have a look at what the Hydro- Electric Commission has proposed in Tasmania. The proposition is that we dare to try to increase our energy needs by 2.7 per cent, the lowest of any State in Australia. The other States want to increase their energy needs by between 4 per cent and 10 per cent. If I had time I could go through the needs of the States. We dare to say that we want to increase our energy needs by 2.7 per cent and we are being told by all the other States that that is too much, that Tasmania does not need it. What a hide those States have. It is absolutely incredible. For 20 years our energy needs have increased by 7 per cent. Now, because of the downturn-the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, has said in the other place that new technologies are becoming available-we have as an increase in our power needs 2.7 per cent, and not the 7 per cent that has been the average increase for the past 20 years. Yet we are still told that we do not need the energy.

We have been told that the cost of building the dam is way out of all proportion and that it is not an economic proposition. The hydro costs in our State are the envy of the world. If only the other States could equal them-it is jealousy, nothing more-they too might seek to use more hydro-power. However, it is not available to them and so they have to charge an additional amount. I will cite a few of the facts. The average quarterly bill for the average Tasmanian household without off-peak is $113; in Queensland it is $139; in South Australia $140; in New South Wales $157; in Victoria $173-no wonder we have a lot of Victorians going crook-and in Western Australia $173. We had the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania and the only two parliamentarians on that Committee, who were not already committed and who had not been caucused, were Senator Robert Hill and Senator Brian Archer. All the rest of the Committee members were either caucused or publicly committed to a view before they took that stand in the Senate Committee. We must look for an independent view that came out of that Committee. The independent view came from the McLachlan group. I am sure that Senator Hill would agree that that was a very worthy group. It was certainly not challenged by any member of the Committee. Before it came down on the side of Tasmania, Committee members thought that it was pretty good. I will quote a few of its statements. It stated:

The Gordon below Franklin is a good hydro-electric scheme economically. It can provide 172 megawatts of extra electricity power to the Tasmanian grid if used near its capacity more economically than any other hydro or coal fired thermal options.

When inflation is taken into account it is clearly demonstrated that the Gordon below Franklin will probably be the most economic hydro-electric power station ever built in Tasmania. We have built many hydro-electric power stations that were expensive, but when inflation is taken into account this will probably be the best.

We are told that we do not need the power. Tasmanian Wilderness Society members have been lobbying me. Young public servants say to me: 'Save the dam'. They have a secure job and indeed they cannot even be sacked, so they are all right. The Tasmanian Wilderness Society people say: 'We in Tasmania do not need high power consumption industries. Get rid of Comalco'. When I ask them 'What do you suggest we do?' they say: 'Let us go back to the crafts'. Who would like to go back to the crafts? The Tasmanian people want proper jobs; they do not want to go back to the crafts. That is a ridiculous statement and does little justice to the cause of the wilderness. I also have another quote from Mr McLachlan. He says that there are only two viable alternatives. As usual, we have heard Senator Mason speaking about wind and sun. He said: 'Let us use the wind and sun '. He is as airy-fairy as the wind and the sun. However, the McLachlan group says that we really have only two viable alternatives. I would like to add one because I believe that in future nuclear power will be a very viable alternative . The only thing I have against nuclear power is that I do not believe that it is acceptable in Australia today. It may be acceptable in another 10 or 20 years . However, let us look at the two acceptable alternatives as far as the rest of Australia-not Tasmania but the rest of Australia-is concerned; namely, thermal power and the interstate undersea cable. Again I shall quote this eminent consultant. Referring to the undersea cable he said:

While these technologies are developing, it is not likely that they will have significant cost competitive, reliable supply available at least until the late 1990's. Therefore they are not appropriate as a basic or back-up option for this study period.

Then he said: 'Of course, as far as thermal power goes we have a little pollution problem'. But we have been told that we do not really have a pollution problem and that the new technologies now overcome pollution. Tasmanians are not interested in having their beautiful air polluted by coal. If one suggested that to the people of the Fingal Valley where coal comes from one would be thrown out . Honourable senators should go to the Tamar Valley, suggest that it have coal- fired power and see what the reaction is.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all agree with you.

—Senator Grimes lives near the Tamar Valley. I am quite sure he would shrink from that suggestion. Let us mention the cost to the Tasmanian consumer per unit of thermal power in 1982 figures. When we compare costs we see that coal-fired power is 4.07c a unit, the Gordon below Franklin power is 1.64c a unit and the power from the undersea cable 4.1c a unit. So as far as cost is concerned there is certainly no chance that Tasmania will burden itself with either coal or an undersea cable. We have had a lot of advice from Labor Ministers and Labor back benchers in the other place, and even here tonight, to the effect that we ought to be satisfied with thermal power.
—Who is suggesting thermal power?

—We are not satisfied with thermal power. If Senator Grimes reads the Hansard he will find that his back bench has said that to us. Indeed if he wants names, they are Mr Campbell, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Humphreys and Barry Jones. They said: 'You should use thermal power'. I shall read a letter from Mr Bob Hawke. It is headed: 'A letter to the working people of Tasmania from Bob Hawke, Leader of the Australian Labor Party'. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I am writing to all Tasmanian workers to outline the Labor Party's policies in relation to your State's future energy needs.
Our policy is clear. These are the facts.

He really should have consulted with his party because it had been telling us that we ought to use thermal power. But Bob Hawke did not do that. Honourable senators should not forget that this letter was sent a couple of days before the electors were to vote. Mr Hawke said:
First, the Labor Party is committed to an all Hydro policy for energy development. Coal-fired thermal power stations in Tasmania have been rejected as unsuitable.
Yet members in the House of Representatives last week told us that we in Tasmania had to have thermal power. Mr Hawke went on:
Second, we will maintain the present Hydro-electric Commission workforce as part of our policy of preserving jobs in Tasmania.
He will! He does not employ them; our State employs them. What does he mean, he will employ them? He goes on:
We believe there are skills in the Commission workforce . . .
Then he stated:
Thirdly, with our proposed Hydro Electric schemes--
Get a load of this, Mr Acting Deputy President-
Tullah will continue, as a viable township instead of construction workers and their families being forced even further into the wilderness.

It is all right to send that sort of letter to the Sydney and Victorian mobs-it is quite all right-but it is not all right to send it to the men at Tullah. They ridiculed him. They asked: 'What in the heck is he on about?' When I was campaigning in Tullah I was handed this letter and told: 'Go back and tell Bob Hawke that we are in Tullah; it is no use writing that rubbish to us'. Mr Hawke then stated:
Fourth, for those in isolated areas our policy is to increase the zone . . . allowance . . .

He then went on to try to drop a few lollies. Remember that that letter was delivered to the workers of Tasmania a couple of days before they were to vote in the election. Let us come to the next alternative, the undersea cable. For those who think we ought to have the undersea cable, let us get the matter quite clear. The Victorian State Electricity Commission said: 'I am sorry, mates, it is not available'. Yet Government senators and Government members say we should use it. Victoria cannot supply it but we should still use it! As if Tasmania would line itself up with the problems associated with the industrial disputes in Victoria. Good heavens, we would no more line ourselves up with that rabble than fly. Mr McLachlan's final summary referring to hydro-power, states that its ingredients might be summarised as: Reliability; lowest possible cost to consumer; the use of Tasmania's natural resources, namely hydro-power; and providing employment in Tasmania for Tasmanians. Yet honourable senators opposite say: 'Do not use it. Do not use your natural resources'. I am not referring to short term employment or to the hydro-workers alone. I am not referring to those thousands of men working on the dam or the 29 people it will take to run it. I am referring to the jobs that will be created once we have that additional power-the jobs that industries will take up. As EZ and ANM have already said, industry will be able to expand. This is a Tasmanian issue. Telling Tasmania that it should not use its hydro-electric power is like saying to the Victorians: 'Don't use Yallourn', and telling South Australians that they should not use the Cooper Basin. We made a mistake in Tasmania. We started to build the dam. We debated it for three years, believing it was a Tasmanian issue . We did not take the issue to the mainland of Australia. The Tasmanian Wilderness Society found that it could not get the issue across in Tasmania, that it could not change the Tasmanians' point of view, so it took the issue to the mainland. The Society had money running out of its ears. It produced shopfronts and literature and it advertised in every paper. Indeed, it even set up a shop in Paris while the World Heritage Committee met. It took the issue to the mainland and convinced the Labor Party that it had more votes in Tasmania than it needed to worry about if it supported the Society stand on the issue. I assure the Labor Party that it will never return to government in Tasmania. It will succeed in having elected fewer and fewer Tasmanian senators as the years go by.

I turn to the next three Tasmanian issues. One is the World Heritage Committee, which accepted the area, dam and all. I will read a statement that the previous Government sent to the World Heritage Committee:

. . . the Government has indicated to the World Heritage Committee that the Tasmanian Government is constructing a hydro-electric power scheme in the nominated area . . . . The Government does not intend to intervene . . .

The Government received a letter in response, addressed to the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation, which stated that the area had been inscribed on the World Heritage List. I do not have time to read the letter. As Senator Hill has already done so, I am sure people will know that it set out some concerns that may occur. The Committee knew that the State Government was building a dam and that the Federal Government had said it would not interfere with it. But the Committee said that when the work was completed the area ought to be put on the List of World Heritage in Danger to see whether any real damage had been done. As I said, Senator Hill has already quoted from that document, so it is already in Hansard.

With regard to the constitutional matters, I refer to what the Labor Party said at one stage. I refer to a letter from Mr Hayden. Of course, he was the Leader of the Labor Party at one stage. Do honourable senators remember what Bob Hawke did to Mr Hayden? He did not only knife him in the back; he also changed his view on the Australian Constitution. Mr Hayden said that he did not believe that the Federal Government had any power at all in the area of States rights. In a letter to Mr Kelvin McCoy Mr Hayden stated:
The more fundamental matters of concern are very much a State responsibility and outside of the constitutional authority of the National Government.

Mr Hayden assured us that it was outside the Constitution. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, wants to use the external affairs power which states that because we belong to a convention the Federal Government should have the power to take over a group of areas in various States. Do honourable senators know how many conventions and treaties there are? There are 16,000 conventions and treaties. I am quite sure that by looking at one of those 16,000 conventions and treaties, anyone would be able to find something enabling him to take over some of the responsibilities and areas applying to any State.

Mr Acting Deputy President, my time to speak in this debate has almost expired. I will have to debate during the Committee stage the Bill which is before us tonight. I say now only that the breadth of this Bill is a disgrace and is proof that Mr Hawke is not interested in just the dam but is seeking all the powers of the States. Anyone who says that the Federal Government should take over the States' responsibilities because we are signatories to the World Heritage Convention should understand the situation very clearly. The World Heritage Convention has a schedule, which contains the guidelines by which member countries should abide. Article 34 of the Schedule very clearly states:

The following provisions shall apply to those State Parties to this Convention which have a federal or non-unitary system. . . States, countries, provinces or cantons that are not obliged by the constitutional system of the federation to take legislative measures, the federal government shall inform the . . . States, countries, provinces or cantons of the said provisions, with its recommendation for their adoption.

That Schedule to the World Heritage Convention states that any country that has a federation, such as Australia, which does not have the constitutional power to walk in and order a State to do something or take over an area, has no further obligation but to inform the State of its recommendation. The World Heritage Convention imposes no obligation on the Commonwealth Government to do anything also.

In the few minutes I have left to speak on this matter, may I say that today we heard Senator Crowley tell us that there are some members of the Liberal Party of Australia who believe that the dam should not be built. I will quote what was said by a few members of the Labor Party. I refer to a letter from the honourable member for Prospect, Dr Klugman. He is a very well known Labor member in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is well respected.
—He is a well respected one. Prior to the election he warned his colleagues of the use of the external affairs power of the Constitution. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: May I, as one who tends to oppose increased government powers of most kinds, caution those Labor supporters who may approve of the extension of such power in this case.
What would prevent an Australian government signing a treaty with South Africa dealing with 'subversion'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GRIMES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—You poor fellow. You have been misrepresented. You are always doing it. It is childish.

—I normally do not do this. Senator Walters, in the course of her speech, said that Ministers and backbenchers told us that we, that is, the Tasmanians, should have a thermal power station. I was the only Minister in the chamber at the time. She also mentioned the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, who, incidentally, is opposed to a thermal power station. I point out that I am now, and always have been, opposed to a thermal power station. The only Minister in this place during the last 12 months who was in favour of a thermal station was the Right Honourable Malcolm Fraser, the ex- Prime Minister. We all know what happened to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very sad that in the speech of Senator Walters, which preceded my contribution to the discussion on the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill 1983, there was no recognition at all of the values that lay behind the presentation of this Bill. This Bill is concerned with asserting that there are places, both man-made and natural, throughout the world which are of such outstanding universal value that they are recognised as part of the cultural and natural heritage of the world. This growing international awareness of heritage values and a sense of international concern and responsibility for our cultural and natural heritage and its protection has obviously passed Senator Walters by. It would not be so bad if, having recognised and acknowledged the growth and validity of these values, the honourable senator had gone on to say that nevertheless there are countervailing values peculiar to Tasmania's economic situation or the need to provide work or energy for its people which overbalanced the considerations which might lead one to take a certain course of action if one had an eye simply on the preservation of our natural heritage. But no; there was not even this recognition of the values which genuinely, I believe, lie behind the Bill, its presentation and the support of the Australian people in the last election for the action which is embodied in this legislation. The Bill attempts to carry into effect the recognition that the disappearance of any item of great cultural or natural heritage constitutes a great impoverishment of mankind-not only the present generation but the many hundreds of years of human civilisation which, putting aside the threat of nuclear holocaust that hovers over us all, we hope will be the lot of human beings into the distant future.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very sad that there is no recognition of those values in much of the opposition to this Bill. I think it is also rather sad that there was no recognition in Senator Walters's speech of the fact that the Australian people and the Australian Labor Party-I say this quite openly-grew in their understanding of the issues and the Tasmanian people's point of view over the past 12 to 18 months. I say that that understanding grew in no large measure because of the contribution by Tasmanian senators, in particular, from both sides of this chamber. We have tried to say to our fellow Australians-we are Australians-that Tasmanians are not unmindful of aesthetic and environmental values. In fact, I believe that no people in Australia are more akin to, conscious of and likely to engage in activities involving the enjoyment of our natural environment. This is because of the nature of the towns and cities in which we live and the type of recreation which we pursue. Tasmanians are very well aware of environmental values. But what we needed to convince our fellow Australians was that for Tasmanians the issue was not the environment but jobs- jobs for present families and for children and grandchildren to come.

I believe that the Governor-General's Speech delivered in this chamber only some weeks ago paid due recognition to the need of the Parliament to address itself to both those issues. Sir Ninian Stephen at the opening of Parliament, in setting forth the Government's program, having noted that the Australian people overwhelmingly endorsed the Australian Labor Party's intended action in relation to South West Tasmania, said explicitly that it was recognised that the generation of energy and the generation of jobs were equally important to this Government in dealing with all the issues raised by the prevention of this project going ahead in South West Tasmania. I believe that in the correspondence between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Mr Gray, the energy requirements of Tasmanians and the need to create jobs were well recognised. Indeed, I refer to the magnanimous statement of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, on election night. We can all recall that in the flush of victory, having suffered a humiliating defeat in Tasmania, he nevertheless said quite openly that there would be no discrimination against Tasmania and that Tasmania and Tasmanians would share in the generation of jobs generally which is, of course, the key objective of this Government. I believe that opposition to this Bill would be better served by recognition of those values which have grown in international understanding and, I believe, in the understanding of Australia and the Austraian Labor Party.

I see my task tonight as quite minor in the context of the many speeches which will be made on this Bill. I have followed some excellent contributions from both sides of the chamber-I emphasise the word 'some'-and I know that more will follow. It is my intention to add two points to the debate. They can be made quite shortly and are directed simply to exposing some of the hypocrisy and partial truths which are being peddled by opponents to this Bill. In the Senate late last year, in the spirit of Christmas cheer-it may have been in the cheer of Christmas spirit-a Liberal senator came into the chamber and of the South West Tasmania issue said:
. . . whilst it may be convenient to say that a democratic decision was taken whereby 51 out of 54 members of the new State Parliament said something, the lawful Government of the State--
He was speaking of Tasmania-
at the appropriate stage said something else and asked the Commonwealth to act. The Commonwealth did act in consequence of that request. I do not think it--
That is, the Commonwealth Government-
has been given sufficient credit for the fact that it acted in good faith upon what was asked of it by the lawful Government of the State of Tasmania acting on behalf of the people of Tasmania.

The senator who came into the chamber and alerted us to that fact was, of course , Senator Peter Rae. I think we need to keep that point very firmly in mind. When people speak of action by the Australian Government in submitting South West Tasmania for inclusion on the World Heritage List as being a tearing-up of the Constitution, a repudiation of federal values and the presaging of a completely unitary State, one has to keep in mind that that action was a direct result of co-operative federalism. In 1975 the then Leader of the Opposition, Malcolm Fraser, put forward as part of his national policy a particular objective in respect of the establishment of a wilderness of world significance in South West Tasmania. That policy commitment made by Mr Fraser in 1975-Senator Peter Rae has spoken of it in this chamber-led to many years of inter- governmental negotiations. Those negotiations were undertaken quite properly between the Federal Liberal Government and the Tasmanian Labor Government of the day. It was only as a result of those many years of negotiation, that example in practice of co-operative federalism, that formal nomination of the area for World Heritage listing came from the Tasmanian Government in accordance with the convention. My authority for saying that that was the sequence of events is none other than the Tasmanian Premier of that time, Mr Doug Lowe, who only a couple of weeks ago at the Australian Constitutional Convention in Adelaide stated:
The commitment that was always given to me, as Premier of Tasmania, by the former Prime Minister of Australia--
he was speaking of Mr Fraser-
was that he would see that World Heritage listing honoured in every respect, and that is what the present Federal Government is simply endeavouring to achieve.

The continuity of events adds up to an exercise in co-operative federalism. There has been by no means a trampling of the rights and an ignoring of the sensibilities of the State Government, lawfully elected to engage in these sorts of negotiations with the national Government as a prelude to the submission of the area to the World Heritage Committee. In that respect I hope that that piece of history lays to rest some of the argument that is put from the other side of the chamber. It also exposes some of the hypocrisy that has entered into this debate.

I think one needs to recall that in May 1982, some 12 months ago, in the High Court of Australia, a judgment was delivered in the case of Koowarta against Bjelke-Petersen and others and the State of Queensland against the Commonwealth of Australia. That case concerned the following situation: In 1975 the Aboriginal Land Fund Commission contracted to buy a Crown freehold pastoral property in north Queensland. However, consent to transfer the lease was refused by the State Minister for Lands pursuant to a policy of the Government to view unfavourably proposals to acquire large areas of freehold or leasehold land for development by Aboriginal groups. The plaintiff, Koowarta, had been active in procuring the purchase and expected the land to be used by himself and other members of the Winychanam group of Aboriginal people. That Aboriginal sued members of the Queensland Government under the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act on the basis of breaches of sections 9 and 12. Without going into any technical details, the fact is that the High Court, by a majority, upheld the validity of that Commonwealth legislation which had the effect, therefore, of overriding decisions by the Queensland Government in relation to the disposal of freehold or leasehold land in Queensland. I think anyone would agree that this is a very large entry by the Commonwealth Government into a field of activity which is generally regarded as being more commonly the province of State governments.

The point I wish to make, quite apart from the precedent value of that decision , is that Sir Maurice Byers, the Solicitor-General of the Commonwealth, was sent into the High Court to argue as vigorously and robustly as he could on behalf of a notion of the external affairs power supporting the Racial Discrimination Act and therefore the overriding of State law in relation to freehold and leasehold land and the granting of tenures. He was sent there to argue that it is quite proper, in fulfilment of an internationally assumed obligation, to legislate internally in a way which modifies the usual balance of powers and activities domestically and internally within Australia. He was sent in to conduct that argument by a Liberal Commonwealth Government. I notice that the argument was conducted in the first week of March 1982.

I thought it might be of interest to honourable senators to see who was in the Ministry at the time that Sir Maurice Byers was instructed by the Commonwealth Liberal Government to argue so vigorously for the validity of that legislation, internal in effect, but carrying into domestic law an obligation assumed under an international treaty. The Government of the day was led by the Prime Minister , the Right Honourable John Malcolm Fraser. The Deputy Prime Minister was the Right Honourable John Douglas Anthony who led the attack on this Bill in the House of Representatives. If one looks for honourable senators in the list of Ministers one finds the following names: The Minister for National Development and Energy, Senator the Honourable Sir John Carrick; the Minister for Finance, Senator the Honourable Dame Margaret Guilfoyle; the Attorney-General, Senator the Honourable Peter Durack; the Minister for Social Security, Senator the Honourable Fred Chaney; the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator the Honourable Tony Messner; and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator the Honourable Peter Baume. All those honourable senators, all those Ministers, in fact all members of the Fraser Ministry, concurred in the direction to Sir Maurice Byers that he go into the High Court and argue vigorously and robustly that the external affairs power enable some intrusion into what might normally be regarded as a proper area for State government activity. The argument put so forcefully by Sir Maurice Byers-I read the transcript only an hour or so ago-was accepted by a majority of the High Court.

As I said, in the short time available to me I wanted to bring those fresh elements into the debate. In doing so I hope that I have helped bring about a more rational environment in which we can conduct our consideration of the Bill. I thank honourable senators for listening attentively.
Debate (on motion by Senator Robertson) adjourned.
