DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women

PROCTEXT.PARA: United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women
Motion (by Senator Ryan) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last week or so many honourable senators have received petitions urging that the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women be not ratified by Australia. Those of us who wish to dissociate ourselves from that position will, of course, make certain that those petitions are presented. I think it might be useful though to take this occasion to explain the facts of the Convention and to put to rest some of the inaccuracies which are currently being circularised. The history of this Convention is that it was initiated as the Declaration on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women in 1945 at the Third Session of the United Nations. In the years intervening this Declaration has been supported by all the reputable international women's organisations. They have been working over the decades to the point where in 1979 the Declaration became a convention and was ready to be presented at the 1980 mid-decade conference of the International Decade for Women.

SPEECH.PARA: All reputable Australian women's organisations over those decades have also supported first the Declaration and now the Convention. Those organisations include such prestigious bodies as the National Council of Women, with its 583 affiliated organisations and a total of more than one million members; the United Nations Association of Australia Status of Women Committee; various branches of the Soroptimists; the Women's Electoral Lobby; the Young Women's Christian Association; the National Women's Advisory Council; the Federal Women' s Conference of the Liberal Party of Australia; and the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. In Copenhagen in 1980 this Convention was signed by Mr Ellicott, the then Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment, despite noisy opposition from a small group of Australian women who represented no one but their own small group of wealthy, sheltered women who want, we believe, to be dependent women and who appear to want to raise that dependency to a virtue or an art form. It is strongly suspected that these 4Ws, as they are known, are supported by the 4Ms-macho males for the maintenance of misogyny.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean 'male, middle-aged and married'.

—I thank the honourable senator. It is also widely acknowledged that the League of Rights, an organisation which is known for its extremely reactionary and regressive policies, is lending comfort and support to this campaign of opposition to the Convention. This Convention is one of very many which have been used as a basis for human rights legislation over the years by Australia and by many other countries which are members of the United Nations. An example of these is the International Labour Organisation Convention No. 111 ratified by the Whitlam Government in 1973 and used as the basis for our 1974 race discrimination legislation which, as all honourable senators have been aware and as was pointed out by my colleague Senator Tate this evening, was used as the test case known as the Koowarta case before the High Court last year. Another widely known convention is the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which is the basis for the Australian human rights legislation and the establishment of our Human Rights Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Convention which is the subject of my speech tonight is to be used as the basis for the sex discrimination legislation which will be introduced very soon by this Government. The interpretation of the Convention as reflected in the petitions being sent to this place is misrepresentation at its best and mischievous falsehood at its worst. Were the issue not so important, one might be highly amused at the notion that any government, even if it would, could legislate to eradicate gender differences, to draft women into combat services or to drag wailing babies from their mothers and segregate them in state care. I wonder how many of the signatories to these petitions have actually read the Convention or even a dispassionate summary of the Convention. Copies are available from United Nations Association offices in each capital city. Unfortunately an understanding of such international institutions and instruments is lacking in this country-apart from acknowledgments of the Year of the Tree, the Year of the Child or the Year of Disabled Persons, very worthy acknowledgments but rather superficial in a sense when compared with the very important instruments which underlie so many of the laws of this and of other countries. The Convention has an excellent introduction which in part states:

A major step towards the attainment of the goal of equal rights for women was taken on 18 December 1979, when the General Assembly adopted the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. The 30-article Convention sets out in legally binding form internationally accepted principles and measures to achieve equal rights for women everywhere. Its adoption climaxed consultations over a five-year period by various working groups, the Commission on the Status of Women and the General Assembly.

The comprehensive Convention reflects the depth of the exclusion and restriction practised against women solely on the basis of their sex, by calling for equal rights for women, regardless of their marital status, in all fields- political, economic, social, cultural and civil. It calls for national legislation to ban discrimination; recommends temporary special measures to speed equality in fact between men and women, and action to modify social and cultural patterns that perpetuate discrimination.

The Convention acknowledges the fact that laws are relatively simple to change but that customs and attitudes take a great deal longer to adapt. Measures to be taken to modify social and cultural patterns of men and women with a view to eliminating prejudice based on the inferiority or superiority of either of the sexes or on stereotyped roles for men and women are very clearly specified in one of the articles of the Convention. 'Different' does not mean better or worse ; it simply means different. We are all a mixture of masculine and feminine characteristics which have little to do with our intrinsic worth. Children encouraged to recognise the common responsibility of men and women in their upbringing and development and to recognise maternity as a social function have a greatly expanded view of society and of their own potential.

Surely all women and all men wish for their children this expanded range of models from which to make their own decisions. This has been denied disproportionately to our mothers, to us and to our daughters. There is no hint in the Convention of reducing society to a dreary sameness, which would ' massively distort the natural interrelationships of the sexes in society', to quote from one of the documents accompanying the petition. One could well argue that there is nothing natural in a society in which the skills, intelligence and wisdom of 50 per cent of the population are circumscribed or wasted on the basis of ancient biological shibboleths. Choice and expanded opportunity toward equality is the tone of the whole Convention. To this end, many measures are required. In Australia we have made a modest start in providing community health services, family planning, pregnancy support and child care-the sort of support services which will allow for greater actualisation of parents and children alike.

As yet, we have not tackled the much more difficult task of persuading the average husband and father that his responsibilities are changing too. In my office I have a beautiful poster of an ordinary looking chap poised by a kitchen stove saying: 'I am Joe Average. My family means more to me than anything else. That is why I share the responsibility of the housework and caring for the kids' . This poster is published, I am happy to say, by the Australian Government. Eighty-nine countries including Australia have signed the Convention. Fourty- four have ratified it, as Australia intends to do. Of the ratifying countries, Sweden, Norway and Austria are probably closest to Australians in level of industrialisation and standard of living. None of those countries gives any indication of rushing headlong into gender free purgatory; quite the contrary. Women are better represented at all levels of society. Health and education standards are high. Unemployment and inflation are much lower than in Australia.

Under the Convention such countries, among a wide range of others, could be involved in a committee set up by the United Nations to consider reports submitted annually by ratifying nations and to report annually to the General Assembly of the United Nations, a procedure similar to that attending ratification of all the other instruments signed by Australia. The committee of experts shall be elected with consideration of the different forms of civilisation as well as the principal legal systems. That shows the care that is taken by the United Nations to make certain that the committee of experts is not judging member nations by the standards of any one group of nations or any one particular nation. It is quite wrong-dishonest in fact-to oppose ratification of the covenant on the grounds that Australia will thereby be placed under the control of foreign powers, as claimed by the Committee for Family Freedom, alias the '4Ws'. If it were so, such has been the case for the 60 years since Australia ratified early conventions of the International Labour Organisation. Another grim warning of these fear and confusion merchants is that we are moving along the way to world government. Would that it were so. The hysterical emphasis on the sanctity of the family and well-being of children which is used to threaten and distress those who have no better information is a shabby and unworthy ploy copied from the American opponents of the Equal Rights Amendment, the so-called 'moral majority' who are neither moral nor a majority.

TALK.START.PARA: —And awfully noisy.

—Indeed, they are. Under the Australian Labor Party Government, Australians now have the opportunity to move out of the straitjacket of the past . Not only will women benefit from this; society generally will be richer. It is the best chance for equal relationships to flourish and for children to develop their skills and potential as befits the precious resource that they are. Scandinavian women talk now of 'equivalence' rather than equality. It seems an easier concept with which to proselytise. I invite the Women Who Want to be Women to claim their equivalence and joint their sisters in supporting the Convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the same subject as Senator Giles. Along with other senators, I have been receiving a quantity of mail and petitions. The content of an amount of that mail distresses me very much. It is very clear that a number of the people who are writing those letters are very genuine in the worries that they have on the subject of the ratification of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. However, a number of the letters have had attached to them a single sheet of paper which is obviously the basis of the letters. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to have this sheet of paper incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Last Monday, March 28th, it was reported in the Press by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, that the Federal Government will move quickly to ratify the United Nations Convention on:
The Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women.
The Attorney-General said that such legislation would operate nationwide.
Some of the implications are as follows:

1. The changing and wiping out of our traditional ''gender'' roles of man and woman. In order to bring about this change of thinking among the young people there would be revision of school textbooks so as to eliminate male and female roles. This would be done in the books from kindergarten level upwards. Changes are already being made to the Bible so as to obliterate differences between the roles of masculine and feminine.
2. If such changes were controlled by law it would involve an intrusion into the privacy of private individuals and families.
3. The above Treaty or Convention expresses strong incentives for mothers to join the workforce. Mothering would, by implication, become a second class calling or profession.

4. A network nationwide of baby creches and childcare centres is already planned, so that the mothers can be freed to go out to work from the early weeks of the child's life. In the long term the result would be that the State would have the care and control of the child from infancy to maturity with the opportunity and power to mould its emotional life and its thinking.

5. One of the results would be the likely development of emotional problems among the children and young people as a result of early separation from both parents. Such deprivation can be a serious cause of childhood psychiatric illness.

6. The exchange of sex roles, or ''gender'' roles, within a marriage, with the women becoming the main breadwinner and the man doing houshold work which is the traditional sphere of the woman, is likely to cause further increase of marriage insecurity and even further marriage breakdown.

7. One serious and far reaching implication is that Australia's ratification of this internation treaty places her under the control of foreign powers; she is no longer free; she has to submit to laws and regulations imposed by international courts and powers.
8. The cost of such legislation would be exceedingly great. The taxpayer-the rank and file of the nation-is the one who pays the bill.

The next sitting of Parliament in Canberra will be in May. Petitions are being sent to both Houses and to the Governor-General asking that the Australian Government refrain from ratifying this United Nations Convention because of its profound, long lasting and widespread effects on the family life of our nation.
For further information telephone-
Dr A. Rendle-Short
Mrs Jackie Butler
Mrs Robyn Sully

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment very briefly on the statements made in this document because it is a grotesque misrepresentation of the provisions of the United Nations convention on discrimination against women. It says, for example, that:

SPEECH.PARA: Changes are already being made to the bible so as to obliterate differences between the roles of masculine and feminine . . . Mothering would, by implication, become a second class calling or profession. . . . In the long term the result would be that the State would have the care and control of the child from infancy to maturity with the opportunity and power to mould its emotional life and its thinking . . . One of the results would be the likely development of emotional problems among the children and young people as a result of early separation from both parents. Such deprivation can be a serious cause of childhood psychiatric illnesses . . . Australia's ratification of this international treaty places here under the control of foreign powers; she is no longer free; she has to submit to laws and regulations imposed by international courts and powers.

That piece of paper, which I gather is very widely distributed-certainly in my State of Queensland and apparently in other States as well-bears on it the names of three individuals who certainly know better. They certainly have access to the Convention and know what it says. Unfortunately, the Convention is a very long document. Much as I would like to have it incorporated in Hansard, it is too long for practical purposes to do that. However, it is my intention to send to everybody who writes to me or contacts me copies of the Convention so that people who are genuinely concerned about its contents can read the words for themselves and judge for themselves just how obscenely they are misled by this document which has on it the names Rendle-Short, Butler and Sully. I might say however that everybody who has contacted my office on this to date has been sent a copy of the Convention. As Senator Giles pointed out, copies are available from United Nations offices. They are also freely available from parliamentary sources. So nobody even has to spend any money if he really wants to know what is in the Convention.

In contrast to that wretched document from which I just read extracts, I would like to draw a few words from the Convention to give some idea of just how strong the contrast is. The fact that I do not mention certain parts of it should not be construed to mean that I am trying to conceal anything that is in the Convention, because I reiterate that I will provide the full Convention to anyone who wants it, whether or not he is genuinely interested. The Convention contains such sentiments as faith in fundamental human rights and the dignity and worth of the human person and in the equal rights of men and women. Equal rights are not the same as being carbon copies or sameness. It states:
All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights.
It affirms the equal right of men and women to enjoy all economic, social, cultural, civil and political rights. It is concerned to promote equality of rights of men and women. It states:
. . . discrimination against women violates the principles of equality of rights and respect for human dignity . . . hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family . . .

It, far from denigrating the family as is claimed, very strongly supports the family and the significance of woman's role in the family. It is opposed to taking advantage of women who are mothers in a way that would put them at a disadvantage to other members of society. It recognises:

. . . the great contribution of women to the welfare of the family and to the development of society, so far not fully recognised, the social significance of maternity and the role of both parents in the family and in the upbringing of children, and aware that the role of women in procreation should not be a basis for discrimination but that the upbringing of children requires a sharing of responsibility between men and women and society as a whole.

I do not intend to quote further at any length. I think just those few pieces show the essence of the terrible lie that is being promoted by the people who are conducting this campaign. One is tempted to treat it with the contempt that it deserves. However, I know from experience that these sorts of campaigns genuinely alarm people with very genuine beliefs on matters. These people are not radicals or fringe lunatic groups at all, they are people who consider the Bible to be an important document, who put a very high value on mothering-be they men or women-who are concerned about the welfare of children and who are concerned that Australia remains a sovereign nation and free, not having to submit to laws and regulations imposed by any other country or power. To those people who have that sincere concern I say: Since you have taken the trouble to involve yourself in this issue please take the trouble to read the document you have been urged to denigrate and draw your own conclusions about the motives of those who have so upset you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —With my colleagues from the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia I add my support to the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women. The Australian Democrats intend to support the ratification of that Convention. It is particularly distressing, as has already been said this evening, to note that the debate on this issue is anything but rational, is based on anything but logic and seems to be designed to frighten people-male and female alike-rather than to educate them on what is the purpose of this Convention and Australia's ratification of it. I say to those women who want to be women, who I suspect are really women who want to be doormats: If at the moment what they want to be is women will they please tell me what they are now so that I have some way of knowing how to discuss things rationally with them. I have always believed myself-perhaps mistakenly-to be a woman. However, I believe that I am a person; an individual in my own right.

SPEECH.PARA: It is rights that we are talking about in this Convention-the right to choose what we are, what we do and what we become. The petitions that are pouring in, the letters that are accompanying them and the rather oddly worded broadsheets that are coming in, talk a lot about the dangers of removing the concept of stereotyping. Something far more dangerous is the continuation of stereotyping, which is an essentially restricting practice. It restricts not only women in society but also men. It means that both men and women as individuals have their own individual inclinations and rights made very secondary to the inclinations and rights of so-called social traditions. No one is forcing women or men, through this Convention, into the work force. It gives both sexes the right to choose and the right to develop the talents that they have in the way that they wish.

For too long the talents of women in business, in politics, in industry and in the community generally have been overlooked and wasted, to the detriment of Australian society. By the same token, the male has been forced to forgo any inclination he has to develop his role in the family as a partner in child rearing. I do not happen to believe that 'real men don't eat quiche' or that ' real women don't pump gas'. Not only do I do the latter but also my husband does the former. Indeed, he bakes quiches that are greeted with some considerable acclaim by my children, both of whom are female, both of whom assert that male drivers are worse than female drivers and both of whom are aware of the fact that they have no restrictions placed upon them by either my husband or myself on what they want to do in the future. If they choose to take up parenting as a full time role that will suit me fine, although I do not know where they would get the inclination from-certainly not from me. Nevertheless, they will be entitled to do so. If they want to pursue a career in politics of course I will try to dissuade them, but they are entitled to pursue any other area as far as I am concerned.

This Convention does not force people to do anything; it allows them to do some of the things they have always wanted to do. Nobody is telling these women who want to be parents, women, mothers or anything else that they have to be something different. Nobody is trying to turn them into surrogate males, much less actual males. We are simply saying: Allow freedom of choice; remove the shackles that are placed on both men and women in society and society as a whole will benefit. I point out that anybody walking down the corridor to my office will come across a poster which probably encapsulates as well as anything my views on the matter. It has the headline 'Anything a woman does she has to do twice as well as a man to be considered half as good'. Under those words appears the following statement: 'Fortunately, this is not difficult'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is indeed indebted to the three honourable senators who have contributed to the adjournment debate this evening. Each from her own perspective has clarified the nature of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, which is the subject of this evening's adjournment debate. Each said things which should be very reassuring to those women and men in our society who have been led by the very mischievous campaign against the Convention. It is the Government's intention to proceed to the ratification of this Convention at the earliest opportunity. I gather from the contributions that have been made in the Senate this evening that this step will have bipartisan, or shall I say tripartisan, support.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very heartening occasion in this Senate. We have support across all the major political parties which represent women and men in this place for action by the Government which, as Senator Haines said in her contribution, will not restrict possibilities for anybody but in fact will increase possibilities for women and men. It is particularly heartening that this support is being given at a time when the Senate has a record number of women members. During the adjournment debate tonight it was evident that women senators were greatly in the majority in the chamber, although it is very pleasing to see some male fellow travellers in the chamber supporting our cause.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague was one of them.
—Senator Teague wishes his name to be placed on record.
—And me.

—I must place it on record that my new colleague from Western Australia, Senator Cook, has supported this. Senator Chaney, the Leader of the Opposition in this place, has just come into the chamber so I am not entirely sure whether his late appearance betokens support of our tripartisan effort here tonight. I hope that it does. I think that the Senate and those who will have the opportunity of reading the record of this adjournment debate will be indebted to the contributions that have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Giles recounted the history of what was originally the declaration concerning the rights of women to live free of discrimination and described to us how that declaration became a convention-the United Nations Convention. In 1979 it was presented to a mid-decade conference in Copenhagen and subsequently ratified at the United Nations Assembly in the same year. Senator Martin concentrated, in a way that I think was very constructive, on the mischief and the distress that are caused to genuine people, the victims of these mischievous campaigns, with regard to the misleading allegations that are being made about the Convention. I hope that the people who have been writing to Senator Martin will accept her advice and read the Convention which she has undertaken to send them.

Senator Haines also expressed her support and the support of the Australian Democrats for the ratification of the Convention and contributed to the debate by elucidating the provisions in the Convention which will enable both women and men to have wider choices. It is important I think, when the Australian Government is undertaking a major reform such as the ratification of the Convention and, of course, is prepared to undertake the legislative reforms with the Commonwealth which will give expression to that Convention, that such measures are widely supported throughout the Parliament.

I said at the outset that I am very heartened at the support of Senator Martin who is a shadow Minister in the Opposition, Senator Haines who is a spokesperson of the Australian Democrats and, of course, my own colleague Senator Giles from Western Australia who has a long and very proud history of supporting civil liberties and reforms, nationally and internationally.

I conclude the adjournment debate this evening by reaffirming the Government's intention to ratify the Convention at the earliest possible opportunity and to enact the legislation which will give effect to the intentions of that Convention which will, as all honourable senators have pointed out tonight, not restrict in any way the freedoms of any man, woman or child in our society but, indeed, will enhance and expand them in a way that all persons concerned with the development of the human spirit must heartily endorse.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
